Text

‘ Now , what [I]2765-i want is , [Facts]70-facts . Teach [these boys]2766-these boys and [girls]2767-girls nothing but Facts . Facts alone are wanted in life . Plant nothing else , and root out everything else . [You]2768-you can only form the minds of reasoning animals upon Facts : nothing else will ever be of any service to [them]2766-these boys . This is the principle on which [I]232-the speaker bring up [[my]232-the speaker own children]2769-my own children , and this is the principle on which [I]232-the speaker bring up [these children]2770-these children . Stick to Facts , [sir]2771-sir ! ’[232-the speaker] The scene was a plain , bare , monotonous vault of [a school - room]231-a school - room , and [the speaker]232-the speaker ’s square forefinger emphasized [his]232-the speaker observations by underscoring every sentence with a line on [the schoolmaster]233-the schoolmaster ’s sleeve . The emphasis was helped by [the speaker]232-the speaker ’s square wall of a forehead , which had [his]232-the speaker eyebrows for its base , while [his]232-the speaker eyes found commodious cellarage in two dark caves , overshadowed by the wall . The emphasis was helped by [the speaker]232-the speaker ’s mouth , which was wide , thin , and hard set . The emphasis was helped by [the speaker]232-the speaker ’s voice , which was inflexible , dry , and dictatorial . The emphasis was helped by [the speaker]232-the speaker ’s hair , which bristled on the skirts of [his]232-the speaker bald head , a plantation of firs to keep the wind from its shining surface , all covered with knobs , like the crust of a plum pie , as if the head had scarcely warehouse - room for the hard facts stored inside . [The speaker]232-the speaker ’s obstinate carriage , square coat , square legs , square shoulders , — nay , [his]232-the speaker very neckcloth , trained to take [him]232-the speaker by the throat with an unaccommodating grasp , like a stubborn fact , as it was , — all helped the emphasis . ‘ In this life , [we]2772-we want nothing but Facts , [sir]2771-sir ; nothing but Facts ! ’[232-the speaker] [The speaker]232-the speaker , and [the schoolmaster]233-the schoolmaster , and [the third grown person present]241-the third grown person present , all backed a little , and swept with [their]242-their eyes the inclined plane of little vessels then and there arranged in order , ready to have imperial gallons of facts poured into them until they were full to the brim . [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom , [sir]2771-sir . [A man of realities]244-a man of realities . [A man of facts and calculations]245-a man of facts and calculations . [A man who proceeds upon the principle that two and two are four , and nothing over , and who is not to be talked into allowing for anything over]246-a man who proceeds upon the principle that two and two are four , and nothing over , and who is not to be talked into allowing for anything over . [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom , [sir]2771-sir — peremptorily [Thomas]71-tom — [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom . With a rule and a pair of scales , and the multiplication table always in [his]71-tom pocket , [sir]2771-sir , ready to weigh and measure any parcel of human nature , and tell [you]249-you exactly what it comes to . It is a mere question of figures , a case of simple arithmetic . [You]249-you might hope to get some other nonsensical belief into the head of [George Gradgrind]72-george , or [Augustus Gradgrind]73-augustus gradgrind , or [John Gradgrind]74-john gradgrind , or [Joseph Gradgrind]75-joseph gradgrind ( [all supposititious , non - existent persons]250-all supposititious , non - existent persons ) , but into the head of [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom — no , [sir]2771-sir ! In such terms [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom always mentally introduced [himself]71-tom , whether to [his]71-tom private circle of acquaintance , or to [the public]252-the public in general . In such terms , no doubt , substituting the words ‘ [boys]2774-boys and [girls]2767-girls , ’[71-tom] for ‘ [sir]2771-sir , ’[71-tom] [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom now presented [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom to [the little pitchers before [him]71-tom]253-the little pitchers before him , [who were to be filled so full of facts]254-who were to be filled so full of facts . Indeed , as [he]71-tom eagerly sparkled at [them]254-who were to be filled so full of facts from the cellarage before mentioned , [he]71-tom seemed a kind of cannon loaded to the muzzle with facts , and prepared to blow them clean out of the regions of childhood at one discharge . [He]71-tom seemed a galvanizing apparatus , too , charged with a grim mechanical substitute for the tender young imaginations that were to be stormed away . ‘ [Girl number twenty]2777-girl number twenty , ’[71-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom , squarely pointing with [his]71-tom square forefinger , ‘ [I]71-tom do n’t know [that girl]2778-that girl . Who is [that girl]2778-that girl ? ’[71-tom] ‘ [Sissy Jupe]76-sissy , [sir]2771-sir , ’[255-number twenty] explained [number twenty]255-number twenty , blushing , standing up , and curtseying . ‘ [Sissy]76-sissy is not a name , ’[71-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom . ‘ Do n’t call [yourself]76-sissy [Sissy]76-sissy . Call [yourself]76-sissy [Cecilia]76-sissy . ’[71-tom] ‘ It ’s [father]2781-father as calls [me]256-the young girl [Sissy]76-sissy , [sir]2771-sir , ’[256-the young girl] returned [the young girl]256-the young girl in a trembling voice , and with another curtsey . ‘ Then [he]2781-father has no business to do it , ’[71-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom . ‘ Tell [him]2781-father [he]2781-father must n’t . [Cecilia Jupe]76-sissy . Let [me]71-tom see . What is [[your]76-sissy father]2783-your father ? ’[71-tom] ‘ [He]2781-father belongs to the horse - riding , if [you]2771-sir please , [sir]2771-sir . ’[71-tom] [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom frowned , and waved off the objectionable calling with [his]71-tom hand . ‘ [We]2785-us do n’t want to know anything about that , here . [You]2771-sir must n’t tell [us]2785-us about that , here . [[Your]76-sissy father]2783-your father breaks horses , do n’t [he]2783-your father ? ’[71-tom] ‘ If [you]2771-sir please , [sir]2771-sir , when [they]2788-they can get any to break , [they]2788-they do break horses in the ring , [sir]2771-sir . ’[71-tom] ‘ [You]2771-sir must n’t tell [us]2785-us about the ring , here . Very well , then . Describe [[your]76-sissy father]2783-your father as [a horsebreaker]2791-a horsebreaker . [He]2783-your father doctors sick horses , [I]71-tom dare say ? ’[71-tom] ‘ Oh yes , [sir]2771-sir . ’[71-tom] ‘ Very well , then . [He]2783-your father is [a veterinary surgeon]2793-a veterinary surgeon , [a farrier]2794-a farrier , and [horsebreaker]2795-horsebreaker . Give [me]71-tom [your]2771-sir definition of a horse . ’[71-tom] ( [Sissy Jupe]76-sissy thrown into the greatest alarm by this demand . ) ‘ Girl number twenty unable to define a horse ! ’[71-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom , for the general behoof of [all the little pitchers]257-all the little pitchers . ‘ [Girl number twenty]2777-girl number twenty possessed of no facts , in reference to one of the commonest of animals ! [Some boy]2797-some boy ’s definition of a horse . [Bitzer]77-bitzer , [yours]2771-sir . ’[71-tom] The square finger , moving here and there , lighted suddenly on [Bitzer]77-bitzer , perhaps because [he]77-bitzer chanced to sit in the same ray of sunlight which , darting in at one of the bare windows of [the intensely white - washed room]258-the intensely white - washed room , irradiated [Sissy]76-sissy . For , [the boys]259-the boys and [girls]2767-girls sat on the face of the inclined plane in two compact bodies , divided up the centre by a narrow interval ; and [Sissy]76-sissy , being at the corner of a row on the sunny side , came in for the beginning of a sunbeam , of which [Bitzer]77-bitzer , being at the corner of [a row on the other side]261-a row on the other side , a few rows in advance , caught the end . But , whereas [the girl]262-the girl was so dark - eyed and dark - haired , that [she]262-the girl seemed to receive a deeper and more lustrous colour from the sun , when it shone upon [her]262-the girl , [the boy]263-the boy was so light - eyed and light - haired that the self - same rays appeared to draw out of [him]263-the boy what little colour [he]263-the boy ever possessed . [His]263-the boy cold eyes would hardly have been eyes , but for the short ends of lashes which , by bringing them into immediate contrast with something paler than [themselves]264-themselves , expressed [their]264-themselves form . [His]263-the boy short - cropped hair might have been a mere continuation of the sandy freckles on [his]263-the boy forehead and face . [His]263-the boy skin was so unwholesomely deficient in the natural tinge , that [he]263-the boy looked as though , if [he]263-the boy were cut , [he]263-the boy would bleed white . ‘ [Bitzer]77-bitzer , ’[71-tom] said [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom . ‘ [Your]77-bitzer definition of a horse . ’[71-tom] ‘ Quadruped . Graminivorous . Forty teeth , namely twenty - four grinders , four eye - teeth , and twelve incisive . Sheds coat in the spring ; in [marshy countries]2798-marshy countries , [sheds hoofs]2799-sheds hoofs , too . Hoofs hard , but requiring to be shod with iron . Age known by marks in mouth . ’[77-bitzer] Thus ( and much more ) [Bitzer]77-bitzer . ‘ Now [girl]2800-girl number twenty , ’[71-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom . ‘ [You]77-bitzer know what a horse is . ’[71-tom] [She]265-she curtseyed again , and would have blushed deeper , if [she]265-she could have blushed deeper than [she]265-she had blushed all this time . [Bitzer]77-bitzer , after rapidly blinking at [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom with both eyes at once , and so catching the light upon [his]263-the boy quivering ends of lashes that they looked like the antennæ of busy insects , put [his]263-the boy knuckles to [his]263-the boy freckled forehead , and sat down again . [The third gentleman]266-the third gentleman now stepped forth . [A mighty man at cutting and drying]267-a mighty man at cutting and drying , [he]266-the third gentleman was ; [a government officer]268-a government officer ; in [his]266-the third gentleman way ( and in [most other people]269-most other people ’s too ) , [a professed pugilist]270-a professed pugilist ; always in training , always with a system to force down the general throat like a bolus , always to be heard of at the bar of [[his]266-the third gentleman little Public - office]271-his little public - office , ready to fight all [England]1-england . To continue in fistic phraseology , [he]266-the third gentleman had a genius for coming up to the scratch , wherever and whatever it was , and proving [himself]266-the third gentleman [an ugly customer]272-an ugly customer . [He]266-the third gentleman would go in and damage any subject whatever with [his]266-the third gentleman right , follow up with [his]266-the third gentleman left , stop , exchange , counter , bore [[his]266-the third gentleman opponent]273-his opponent ( [he]266-the third gentleman always fought All [England]1-england ) to the ropes , and fall upon [him]273-his opponent neatly . [He]266-the third gentleman was certain to knock the wind out of common sense , and render [that unlucky adversary]274-that unlucky adversary deaf to the call of time . And [he]266-the third gentleman had it in charge from high authority to bring about the great public - office Millennium , when [Commissioners]275-commissioners should reign upon [earth]276-earth . ‘ Very well , ’[277-this gentleman] said [this gentleman]277-this gentleman , briskly smiling , and folding [his]277-this gentleman arms . ‘ That ’s a horse . Now , let [me]277-this gentleman ask [you]279-the children [girls]2767-girls and [boys]2774-boys , Would [you]279-the children paper [a room with representations of horses]2803-a room with representations of horses ? ’[277-this gentleman] After a pause , [one half of [the children]279-the children]278-one half of the children cried in chorus , ‘ Yes , [sir]2771-sir ! ’[278-one half of the children] Upon which [the other half]280-the other half , seeing in [the gentleman]281-the gentleman ’s face that Yes was wrong , cried out in chorus , ‘ No , [sir]2771-sir ! ’[280-the other half] — as the custom is , in these examinations . ‘ Of course , No . Why would n’t [you]279-the children ? ’[281-the gentleman] A pause . [One corpulent slow boy]282-one corpulent slow boy , with a wheezy manner of breathing , ventured the answer , Because [he]282-one corpulent slow boy would n’t paper [a room]283-a room at all , but would paint it . ‘ [You]279-the children must paper it , ’[281-the gentleman] said [the gentleman]281-the gentleman , rather warmly . ‘ [You]279-the children must paper it , ’[71-tom] said [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom , ‘ whether [you]279-the children like it or not . Do n’t tell [us]2806-us [you]279-the children would n’t paper it . What do [you]279-the children mean , [boy]2807-boy ? ’[71-tom] ‘ [I]281-the gentleman ’ll explain to [you]279-the children , then , ’[281-the gentleman] said [the gentleman]281-the gentleman , after another and a dismal pause , ‘ why [you]279-the children would n’t paper [a room with representations of horses]2803-a room with representations of horses . Do [you]279-the children ever see horses walking up and down the sides of [rooms]2809-rooms in reality — in fact ? Do [you]279-the children ? ’[281-the gentleman] ‘ Yes , [sir]2771-sir ! ’[71-tom] from [one half]286-one half . ‘ No , [sir]2771-sir ! ’[287-the other] from [the other]287-the other . ‘ Of course no , ’[281-the gentleman] said [the gentleman]281-the gentleman , with an indignant look at [the wrong half]289-the wrong half . ‘ Why , then , [you]279-the children are not to see anywhere , what [you]279-the children do n’t see in fact ; [you]279-the children are not to have anywhere , what [you]279-the children do n’t have in fact . What is called Taste , is only another name for Fact . ’[281-the gentleman] [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom nodded [his]71-tom approbation . ‘ This is a new principle , a discovery , a great discovery , ’[281-the gentleman] said [the gentleman]281-the gentleman . ‘ Now , [I]281-the gentleman ’ll try [you]279-the children again . Suppose [you]279-the children were going to carpet [a room]283-a room . Would [you]279-the children use a carpet having a representation of flowers upon it ? ’[281-the gentleman] There being a general conviction by this time that ‘ No , [sir]2771-sir ! ’[281-the gentleman] was always the right answer to [this gentleman]277-this gentleman , the chorus of No was very strong . [Only a few feeble stragglers]292-only a few feeble stragglers said Yes : among [them]292-only a few feeble stragglers [Sissy Jupe]76-sissy . ‘ [Girl]2800-girl number twenty , ’[281-the gentleman] said [the gentleman]281-the gentleman , smiling in the calm strength of knowledge . [Sissy]76-sissy blushed , and stood up . ‘ So [you]279-the children would carpet [[your]279-the children room]2815-your room — or [[[your]279-the children husband]2816-your husband ’s room]2817-your husband ’s room , if [you]279-the children were [a grown woman]2818-a grown woman , and had [a husband]2819-a husband — with representations of flowers , would [you]279-the children ? ’[281-the gentleman] said [the gentleman]281-the gentleman . ‘ Why would [you]279-the children ? ’[281-the gentleman] ‘ If [you]281-the gentleman please , [sir]2771-sir , [I]262-the girl am very fond of flowers , ’[262-the girl] returned [the girl]262-the girl . ‘ And is that why [you]281-the gentleman would put tables and chairs upon them , and have [people]2821-people walking over [them]2821-people with heavy boots ? ’[262-the girl] ‘ It would n’t hurt [them]2821-people , [sir]2771-sir . [They]2821-people would n’t crush and wither , if [you]281-the gentleman please , [sir]2771-sir . [They]2821-people would be the pictures of what was very pretty and pleasant , and [I]281-the gentleman would fancy — ’[281-the gentleman] ‘ Ay , ay , ay ! But [you]281-the gentleman must n’t fancy , ’[281-the gentleman] cried [the gentleman]281-the gentleman , quite elated by coming so happily to [his]281-the gentleman point . ‘ That ’s it ! [You]281-the gentleman are never to fancy . ’[281-the gentleman] ‘ [You]281-the gentleman are not , [Cecilia Jupe]76-sissy , ’[281-the gentleman] [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom solemnly repeated , ‘ to do anything of that kind . ’[71-tom] ‘ Fact , fact , fact ! ’[281-the gentleman] said [the gentleman]281-the gentleman . And ‘ Fact , fact , fact ! ’[71-tom] repeated [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom . ‘ [You]281-the gentleman are to be in all things regulated and governed , ’[281-the gentleman] said [the gentleman]281-the gentleman , ‘ by fact . [We]2824-we hope to have , before long , [a board of fact]2825-a board of fact , composed of [commissioners of fact]2826-commissioners of fact , who will force [the people]2827-the people to be [a people of fact , and of nothing but fact]2828-a people of fact , and of nothing but fact . [You]281-the gentleman must discard the word Fancy altogether . [You]281-the gentleman have nothing to do with it . [You]281-the gentleman are not to have , in any object of use or ornament , what would be a contradiction in fact . [You]281-the gentleman do n’t walk upon flowers in fact ; [you]281-the gentleman can not be allowed to walk upon flowers in carpets . [You]281-the gentleman do n’t find that foreign birds and butterflies come and perch upon [your]281-the gentleman crockery ; [you]281-the gentleman can not be permitted to paint foreign birds and butterflies upon [your]281-the gentleman crockery . [You]281-the gentleman never meet with quadrupeds going up and down walls ; [you]281-the gentleman must not have quadrupeds represented upon walls . [You]281-the gentleman must use , ’[281-the gentleman] said [the gentleman]281-the gentleman , ‘ for all these purposes , combinations and modifications ( in primary colours ) of mathematical figures which are susceptible of proof and demonstration . This is the new discovery . This is fact . This is taste . ’[281-the gentleman] [The girl]262-the girl curtseyed , and sat down . [She]262-the girl was very young , and [she]262-the girl looked as if [she]262-the girl were frightened by the matter - of - fact prospect [the world]301-the world afforded . ‘ Now , if [Mr. M’Choakumchild]78-mr. m’choakumchild , ’[281-the gentleman] said [the gentleman]281-the gentleman , ‘ will proceed to give [his]78-mr. m’choakumchild first lesson here , [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom , [I]281-the gentleman shall be happy , at [your]71-tom request , to observe [his]78-mr. m’choakumchild mode of procedure . ’[281-the gentleman] [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom was much obliged . ‘ [Mr. M’Choakumchild]78-mr. m’choakumchild , [we]2829-we only wait for [you]78-mr. m’choakumchild . ’[71-tom] So , [Mr. M’Choakumchild]78-mr. m’choakumchild began in [his]78-mr. m’choakumchild best manner . [He]78-mr. m’choakumchild and [some one hundred and forty other schoolmasters]303-some one hundred and forty other schoolmasters , had been lately turned at the same time , in [the same factory]304-the same factory , on the same principles , like so many pianoforte legs . [He]78-mr. m’choakumchild had been put through an immense variety of paces , and had answered volumes of head - breaking questions . Orthography , etymology , syntax , and prosody , biography , astronomy , geography , and general cosmography , the sciences of compound proportion , algebra , land - surveying and levelling , vocal music , and drawing from models , were all at the ends of [his]78-mr. m’choakumchild ten chilled fingers . [He]78-mr. m’choakumchild had worked [his]78-mr. m’choakumchild stony way into [[Her]305-her Majesty ’s most Honourable Privy Council ’s Schedule B]2-her majesty ’s most honourable privy council ’s schedule b , and had taken the bloom off the higher branches of mathematics and physical science , French , German , Latin , and Greek . [He]78-mr. m’choakumchild knew all about [all the Water Sheds of all [the world]301-the world]306-all the water sheds of all the world ( whatever [they]306-all the water sheds of all the world are ) , and all the histories of [all the peoples]308-all the peoples , and all the names of all [the rivers and mountains]309-the rivers and mountains , and all the productions , manners , and customs of [all the countries]310-all the countries , and all [their]306-all the water sheds of all the world boundaries and bearings on the two and thirty points of the compass . Ah , rather overdone , M’Choakumchild . If [he]78-mr. m’choakumchild had only learnt a little less , how infinitely better [he]78-mr. m’choakumchild might have taught much more ! [He]78-mr. m’choakumchild went to work in this preparatory lesson , not unlike [Morgiana]79-morgiana in [the Forty Thieves]311-the forty thieves : looking into all the vessels ranged before [him]78-mr. m’choakumchild , one after another , to see what they contained . Say , [good M’Choakumchild]80-m’choakumchild . When from [[thy]78-mr. m’choakumchild boiling store]312-thy boiling store , [thou]78-mr. m’choakumchild shalt fill each jar brim full by - and - by , dost [thou]78-mr. m’choakumchild think that [thou]78-mr. m’choakumchild wilt always kill outright the robber Fancy lurking within — or sometimes only maim [him]78-mr. m’choakumchild and distort [him]78-mr. m’choakumchild ! [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom walked homeward from [the school]313-the school , in a state of considerable satisfaction . It was [[his]71-tom school]314-his school , and [he]71-tom intended it to be [a model]315-a model . [He]71-tom intended [every child in it]316-every child in it to be [a model]315-a model — just as [the young Gradgrinds]318-the young gradgrinds were [all models]319-all models . There were [five young Gradgrinds]320-five young gradgrinds , and [they]320-five young gradgrinds were [models every one]321-models every one . [They]320-five young gradgrinds had been lectured at , from [their]320-five young gradgrinds tenderest years ; coursed , like little hares . Almost as soon as [they]320-five young gradgrinds could run alone , [they]320-five young gradgrinds had been made to run to [the lecture - room]322-the lecture - room . The first object with which [they]320-five young gradgrinds had an association , or of which [they]320-five young gradgrinds had a remembrance , was a large black board with [a dry Ogre chalking ghastly white figures on it]323-a dry ogre chalking ghastly white figures on it . Not that [they]320-five young gradgrinds knew , by name or nature , anything about [an Ogre Fact forbid]324-an ogre fact forbid ! [I]0-i only use the word to express a monster in [a lecturing castle]325-a lecturing castle , with [Heaven]81-heaven knows how many heads manipulated into one , taking [childhood]326-childhood captive , and dragging it into gloomy statistical dens by the hair . No little [Gradgrind]71-tom had ever seen a face in the moon ; it was up in the moon before it could speak distinctly . [No little Gradgrind]71-tom had ever learnt the silly jingle , Twinkle , twinkle , little star ; how [I]0-i wonder what [you]327-you are ! [No little Gradgrind]71-tom had ever known wonder on the subject , each little Gradgrind having at five years old dissected [the Great Bear]82-the great bear like [a Professor Owen]83-a professor owen , and driven [Charles]84-charles ’s Wain like [a locomotive engine - driver]328-a locomotive engine - driver . [No little Gradgrind]71-tom had ever associated a cow in [a field]329-a field with that famous cow with the crumpled horn who tossed the dog who worried the cat who killed [the rat who ate the malt]330-the rat who ate the malt , or with that yet more famous cow who swallowed [Tom Thumb]85-tom thumb : it had never heard of [those celebrities]331-those celebrities , and had only been introduced to a cow as [a graminivorous ruminating quadruped with several stomachs]332-a graminivorous ruminating quadruped with several stomachs . To [[his]71-tom matter - of - fact home]333-his matter - of - fact home , which was called [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge , [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom directed [his]71-tom steps . [He]71-tom had virtually retired from the wholesale hardware trade before [he]71-tom built [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge , and was now looking about for a suitable opportunity of making [an arithmetical figure in Parliament]334-an arithmetical figure in parliament . [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge was situated on a moor within a mile or two of [a great town]335-a great town — called [Coketown]4-coketown in the present faithful guide - book . A very regular feature on the face of [the country]336-the country , [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge was . Not the least disguise toned down or shaded off that uncompromising fact in the landscape . [A great square house]337-a great square house , with a heavy portico darkening the principal windows , as [its master]338-its master ’s heavy brows overshadowed [his]338-its master eyes . A calculated , cast up , balanced , and [proved house]339-proved house . Six windows on this side of the door , six on that side ; a total of twelve in [this wing]340-this wing , a total of twelve in [the other wing]341-the other wing ; four - and - twenty carried over to the back wings . [A lawn and garden]342-a lawn and garden and [an infant avenue]343-an infant avenue , all ruled straight like a botanical account - book . Gas and ventilation , drainage and water - service , all of the primest quality . Iron clamps and girders , fire - proof from top to bottom ; mechanical lifts for [the housemaids]344-the housemaids , with all [their]344-the housemaids brushes and brooms ; everything that heart could desire . Everything ? Well , [I]0-i suppose so . [The little Gradgrinds]86-the little gradgrinds had cabinets in various departments of science too . [They]86-the little gradgrinds had a little conchological cabinet , and a little metallurgical cabinet , and a little mineralogical cabinet ; and the specimens were all arranged and labelled , and the bits of stone and ore looked as though they might have been broken from the parent substances by those tremendously hard instruments [their]86-the little gradgrinds own names ; and , to paraphrase the idle legend of [Peter Piper]87-peter piper , who had never found [his]87-peter piper way into [[their]86-the little gradgrinds nursery]345-their nursery , If [the greedy little Gradgrinds]346-the greedy little gradgrinds grasped at more than this , what was it for good gracious goodness ’ sake , that [the greedy little Gradgrinds]346-the greedy little gradgrinds grasped it ! [[Their]86-the little gradgrinds father]2831-their father walked on in a hopeful and satisfied frame of mind . [He]2831-their father was [an affectionate father]2832-an affectionate father , after [his]2831-their father manner ; but [he]2831-their father would probably have described [himself]2831-their father ( if [he]2831-their father had been put , like [Sissy Jupe]76-sissy , upon a definition ) as ‘[2833-an eminently practical ’ father] [an eminently practical ’ father]2833-an eminently practical ’ father . [He]2831-their father had a particular pride in the phrase eminently practical , which was considered to have a special application to [him]2831-their father . Whatsoever the public meeting held in [Coketown]4-coketown , and whatsoever the subject of such meeting , [some Coketowner]2834-some coketowner was sure to seize the occasion of alluding to [[his]2834-some coketowner eminently practical friend]2835-his eminently practical friend [Gradgrind]71-tom . This always pleased [the eminently practical friend]2836-the eminently practical friend . [He]2831-their father knew it to be [his]2831-their father due , but [his]2831-their father due was acceptable . [He]2831-their father had reached the neutral ground upon [the outskirts of [the town]2838-the town]2837-the outskirts of the town , which was [neither town]2839-neither town nor [country]2840-country , and yet was either spoiled , when [his]2831-their father ears were invaded by the sound of music . The clashing and banging band attached to the horse - riding establishment , which had there set up [its]2841-its rest in a wooden pavilion , was in full bray . A flag , floating from the summit of [the temple]2842-the temple , proclaimed to [mankind]2843-mankind that it was ‘[2833-an eminently practical ’ father] [Sleary]88-mr. sleary ’s Horse - riding ’ which claimed [their]2843-mankind suffrages . [Sleary]88-mr. sleary [himself]88-mr. sleary , a stout modern statue with a money - box at its elbow , in an ecclesiastical niche of early Gothic architecture , took the money . [Miss Josephine Sleary]89-josephine , as some very long and very narrow strips of printed bill announced , was then inaugurating the entertainments with [her]89-josephine graceful equestrian Tyrolean flower - act . Among the other pleasing but always strictly moral wonders which must be seen to be believed , [Signor Jupe]90-signor jupe was that afternoon to ‘[2833-an eminently practical ’ father] elucidate the diverting accomplishments of [his]88-mr. sleary highly trained performing dog Merrylegs . ’ [He]90-signor jupe was also to exhibit ‘[88-mr. sleary] [his]88-mr. sleary astounding feat of throwing seventy - five hundred - weight in rapid succession backhanded over [his]88-mr. sleary head , thus forming a fountain of solid iron in mid - air , a feat never before attempted in this or [any other country]347-any other country , and which having elicited such rapturous plaudits from [enthusiastic throngs]348-enthusiastic throngs it can not be withdrawn . ’ The same [Signor Jupe]90-signor jupe was to ‘[88-mr. sleary] enliven the varied performances at frequent intervals with [his]88-mr. sleary chaste Shaksperean quips and retorts . ’ Lastly , [he]88-mr. sleary was to wind them up by appearing in [his]88-mr. sleary favourite character of [Mr. William Button]91-mr. william button , of [Tooley Street]5-tooley street , in ‘[88-mr. sleary] the highly novel and laughable hippo - comedietta of [The Tailor]349-the tailor ’s Journey to [Brentford]6-brentford . ’ [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom took no heed of these trivialities of course , but passed on as [a practical man]2844-a practical man ought to pass on , either brushing the noisy insects from [his]71-tom thoughts , or consigning them to [the House of Correction]2845-the house of correction . But , the turning of [the road]2846-the road took [him]71-tom by the back of the booth , and at the back of the booth [a number of [children]2848-children]2847-a number of children were congregated in a number of stealthy attitudes , striving to peep in at the hidden glories of [the place]2849-the place . This brought [him]71-tom to a stop . ‘[88-mr. sleary] Now , to think of [these vagabonds]350-these vagabonds , ’ said [he]71-tom , ‘[350-these vagabonds] attracting [the young rabble]351-the young rabble from [a model school]352-a model school . ’ A space of stunted grass and dry rubbish being between [him]71-tom and [the young rabble]351-the young rabble , [he]71-tom took [his]71-tom eyeglass out of [his]71-tom waistcoat to look for [any child [he]71-tom knew by name]2851-any child he knew by name , and might order off . Phenomenon almost incredible though distinctly seen , what did [he]71-tom then behold but [his]71-tom own metallurgical [Louisa]92-louisa , peeping with all [her]92-louisa might through a hole in a deal board , and [his]71-tom own mathematical [Thomas]71-tom abasing [himself]71-tom on the ground to catch but a hoof of the graceful equestrian Tyrolean flower - act ! Dumb with amazement , [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom crossed to the spot where [[his]71-tom family]2852-his family was thus disgraced , laid [his]71-tom hand upon [each erring child]2853-each erring child , and said : ‘[351-the young rabble] [Louisa]92-louisa ! ! [Thomas]71-tom ! ! ’ [Both]2854-both rose , red and disconcerted . But , [Louisa]92-louisa looked at [[her]92-louisa father]2855-her father with more boldness than [Thomas]71-tom did . Indeed , [Thomas]71-tom did not look at [him]2855-her father , but gave [himself]71-tom up to be taken [home]2856-home like a machine . ‘[71-tom] In the name of wonder , idleness , and folly ! ’ said [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom , leading [each]2857-each away by a hand ; ‘[351-the young rabble] what do [you]92-louisa do here ? ’ ‘[92-louisa] Wanted to see what it was like , ’ returned [Louisa]92-louisa , shortly . ‘[92-louisa] What it was like ? ’ ‘[2781-father] Yes , [father]2781-father . ’ There was an air of jaded sullenness in [them]2854-both both , and particularly in [the girl]262-the girl : yet , struggling through the dissatisfaction of [her]262-the girl face , there was a light with nothing to rest upon , a fire with nothing to burn , a starved imagination keeping life in itself somehow , which brightened its expression . Not with the brightness natural to cheerful youth , but with uncertain , eager , doubtful flashes , which had something painful in them , analogous to the changes on a blind face groping its way . [She]262-the girl was [a child now , of fifteen or sixteen]2859-a child now , of fifteen or sixteen ; but at no distant day would seem to become [a woman all at once]2860-a woman all at once . [[Her]262-the girl father]2855-her father thought so as [he]2855-her father looked at [her]262-the girl . [She]262-the girl was pretty . In [the formal drawing - room of [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge]2889-the formal drawing - room of stone lodge , standing on the hearthrug , warming [himself]93-mr. bounderby before the fire , [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby delivered some observations to [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind on the circumstance of its being [his]93-mr. bounderby birthday . [He]93-mr. bounderby stood before the fire , partly because it was a cool spring afternoon , though the sun shone ; partly because the shade of [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge was always haunted by the ghost of damp mortar ; partly because [he]93-mr. bounderby thus took up a commanding position , from which to subdue [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind . ‘[93-mr. bounderby] [I]0-i had n’t a shoe to [my]0-i foot . That was the cot of [my]0-i infancy ; an old egg - box . As soon as [I]0-i was big enough to run away , of course [I]0-i ran away . Then [I]0-i became [a young vagabond]376-a young vagabond ; and instead of [one old woman]377-one old woman knocking [me]0-i about and starving [me]0-i , [everybody of all ages]378-everybody of all ages knocked [me]0-i about and starved [me]0-i . [They]379-they were right ; [they]379-they had no business to do anything else . [I]0-i was [a nuisance , an incumbrance]380-a nuisance , an incumbrance , and [a pest]381-a pest . [I]0-i know that very well . ’ [His]0-i pride in having at any time of [his]0-i life achieved such a great social distinction as to be [a nuisance]2896-a nuisance , [an incumbrance]2897-an incumbrance , and [a pest]381-a pest , was only to be satisfied by three sonorous repetitions of the boast . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i was to pull through it , [I]0-i suppose , [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind . Whether [I]0-i was to do it or not , [ma’am]361-ma’am , [I]0-i did it . [I]0-i pulled through it , though [nobody]365-nobody threw [me]0-i out a rope . [Vagabond]96-vagabond , [errand - boy]384-errand - boy , vagabond , [labourer]385-labourer , [porter]386-porter , [clerk]387-clerk , [chief manager]388-chief manager , [small partner]389-small partner , [[Josiah Bounderby]97-bounderby of [Coketown]4-coketown]390-josiah bounderby of coketown . Those are the antecedents , and the culmination . [Josiah Bounderby]97-bounderby of [Coketown]4-coketown learnt [his]97-bounderby letters from [the outsides of [the shops]392-the shops]391-the outsides of the shops , [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind , and was first able to tell the time upon a dial - plate , from studying the steeple clock of [St. Giles ’s Church]7-st. giles ’s church , [London]8-london , under the direction of [a drunken cripple]393-a drunken cripple , who was [a convicted thief]394-a convicted thief , and [an incorrigible vagrant]395-an incorrigible vagrant . In truth , [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind ’s stock of facts in general was woefully defective ; but [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom in raising [her]95-mrs. gradgrind to [her]95-mrs. gradgrind high matrimonial position , had been influenced by two reasons . Let [us]2933-us strike the key - note , [Coketown]4-coketown , before pursuing [our]2933-us tune . [It]4-coketown was [a town of red brick]2934-a town of red brick , or [of brick that would have been red if the smoke and ashes had allowed]2935-of brick that would have been red if the smoke and ashes had allowed [it]4-coketown ; but as matters stood , [it]4-coketown was [a town of unnatural red and black like the painted face of a savage]2936-a town of unnatural red and black like the painted face of a savage . [It]4-coketown was [a town of machinery]2937-a town of machinery and tall chimneys , out of which [interminable serpents of smoke trailed themselves for ever and ever , and never got uncoiled]2938-interminable serpents of smoke trailed themselves for ever and ever , and never got uncoiled . [It]4-coketown had [a black canal]2939-a black canal in [it]4-coketown , and [a river that ran purple with ill - smelling dye]2940-a river that ran purple with ill - smelling dye , and vast piles of building full of windows where there was a rattling and a trembling all day long , and where the piston of [the steam - engine]2941-the steam - engine worked monotonously up and down , like the head of an elephant in a state of melancholy madness . [It]4-coketown contained [several large streets]2942-several large streets all very like one another , and [many small streets]2943-many small streets still more like one another , inhabited by [people equally like one another]2944-people equally like one another , who all went in and out at the same hours , with the same sound upon [the same pavements]2945-the same pavements , to do the same work , and to whom every day was the same as yesterday and to - morrow , and every year the counterpart of the last and the next . These attributes of [Coketown]4-coketown were in the main inseparable from the work by which it was sustained ; against them were to be set off , comforts of life which found their way all over [the world]301-the world , and elegancies of life which made , [we]2947-we will not ask how much of [the fine lady]2948-the fine lady , who could scarcely bear to hear the place mentioned . The rest of [its]4-coketown features were voluntary , and they were these . [You]2949-you saw nothing in [Coketown]4-coketown but what was severely workful . If [the members of a religious persuasion]2950-the members of a religious persuasion built [a chapel]2951-a chapel [there]425-there — as [the members of eighteen religious persuasions]2953-the members of eighteen religious persuasions had done — [they]2953-the members of eighteen religious persuasions made it [a pious warehouse of red brick]2954-a pious warehouse of red brick , with sometimes ( but this is only in highly ornamental examples ) a bell in a birdcage on the top of it . All the public inscriptions in [the town]2838-the town were painted alike , in severe characters of black and white . [The jail]2958-the jail might have been [the infirmary]2959-the infirmary , [the infirmary]2959-the infirmary might have been [the jail]2958-the jail , [the town - hall]2962-the town - hall might have been either , or both , or anything else , for anything that appeared to the contrary in the graces of [their]2962-the town - hall construction . Fact , fact , fact , everywhere in the material aspect of [the town]2838-the town ; fact , fact , fact , everywhere in the immaterial . [The M’Choakumchild school]2964-the m’choakumchild school was all fact , and [the school of design]2965-the school of design was all fact , and the relations between [master]2966-master and [man]2967-man were all fact , and everything was fact between [the lying - in hospital]2968-the lying - in hospital and [the cemetery]2969-the cemetery , and what [you]2970-you could n’t state in figures , or show to be purchaseable in the cheapest market and saleable in the dearest , was not , and never should be , world without end , Amen . [A town]2971-a town so sacred to fact , and so triumphant in [its]2971-a town assertion , of course got on well ? Why no , not quite well . No ? Dear [me]0-i ! No . [Coketown]4-coketown did not come out of [[its]4-coketown own furnaces]2972-its own furnaces , in all respects like gold that had stood the fire . First , the perplexing mystery of [the place]2849-the place was , Who belonged to the eighteen denominations ? Because , whoever did , [the labouring people]2974-the labouring people did not . It was very strange to walk through [the streets]2975-the streets on a Sunday morning , and note how few of [them]2974-the labouring people the barbarous jangling of bells that was driving [the sick and nervous mad]2976-the sick and nervous mad , called away from [[their]2974-the labouring people own quarter]2977-their own quarter , from [[their]2974-the labouring people own close rooms]2978-their own close rooms , from the corners of [[their]2974-the labouring people own streets]2979-their own streets , where [they]2974-the labouring people lounged listlessly , gazing at [all the [church]2981-church and [chapel]2982-chapel going]2980-all the church and chapel going , as at a thing with which [they]2974-the labouring people had no manner of concern . Nor was it merely [the stranger who noticed this]2983-the stranger who noticed this , because there was [a native organization in [Coketown]4-coketown [itself]4-coketown , whose members]2984-a native organization in coketown itself , whose members were to be heard of in [the House of Commons]2985-the house of commons every session , indignantly petitioning for acts of parliament that should make [these people religious by main force]2986-these people religious by main force . Then came [the Teetotal Society]2987-the teetotal society , who complained that [these same people]2988-these same people would get drunk , and showed in tabular statements that [they]2988-these same people did get drunk , and proved at tea parties that no inducement , human or Divine ( except a medal ) , would induce [them]2988-these same people to forego [their]2988-these same people custom of getting drunk . Then came [the chemist and druggist]2989-the chemist and druggist , with other tabular statements , showing that when [they]2974-the labouring people did n’t get drunk , [they]2974-the labouring people took opium . B.]103-a. b. , aged twenty - four next birthday , and committed for eighteen months ’[0-i] solitary , had [himself]443-he said ( not that [he]443-he had ever shown [himself]443-he particularly worthy of belief ) [his]443-he ruin began , as [he]443-he was perfectly sure and confident that otherwise [he]443-he would have been [a tip - top moral specimen]444-a tip - top moral specimen . Then came [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom and [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , [the two gentlemen at this present moment walking through [Coketown]4-coketown , and both eminently practical , who could , on occasion , furnish more tabular statements derived from [their]446-their own personal experience , and illustrated by cases [they]446-their had known and seen , from which it clearly appeared — in short , it was the only clear thing in the case]445-the two gentlemen at this present moment walking through coketown , and both eminently practical , who could , on occasion , furnish more tabular statements derived from their own personal experience , and illustrated by cases they had known and seen , from which it clearly appeared — in short , it was the only clear thing in the case — that [these same people]2988-these same people were a bad lot altogether , [gentlemen]448-gentlemen ; that do what [you]449-you would for [them]2988-these same people [they]2988-these same people were never thankful for it , [gentlemen]448-gentlemen ; that [they]2988-these same people were restless , [gentlemen]448-gentlemen ; that [they]2988-these same people never knew what [they]2988-these same people wanted ; that [they]2988-these same people lived upon the best , and bought fresh butter ; and insisted on Mocha coffee , and rejected all but prime parts of meat , and yet were eternally dissatisfied and unmanageable . In short , it was the moral of the old nursery fable : There was [an old woman]452-an old woman , and what do [you]449-you think ? [She]452-an old woman lived upon nothing but victuals and drink ; Victuals and drink were the whole of [her]452-an old woman diet , And yet [this old woman]453-this old woman would NEVER be quiet . Is it possible , [I]0-i wonder , that there was any analogy between the case of [the Coketown population]454-the coketown population and the case of [the little Gradgrinds]86-the little gradgrinds ? Surely , none of [us]455-us in [our]455-us sober senses and acquainted with [figures]456-figures , are to be told at this time of day , that one of the foremost elements in the existence of [the Coketown working - people]457-the coketown working - people had been for scores of years , deliberately set at nought ? That there was any Fancy in [them]2988-these same people demanding to be brought into healthy existence instead of struggling on in convulsions ? That exactly in the ratio as [they]2988-these same people worked long and monotonously , the craving grew within [them]2988-these same people for some physical relief — some relaxation , encouraging good humour and good spirits , and giving [them]2988-these same people a vent — some recognized holiday , though it were but for an honest dance to [a stirring band of music]458-a stirring band of music — some occasional light pie in which even [M’Choakumchild]80-m’choakumchild had no finger — which craving must and would be satisfied aright , or must and would inevitably go wrong , until the laws of the Creation were repealed ? ‘ [This man]2994-this man lives at [Pod ’s End]9-pod ’s end , and [I]71-tom do n’t quite know [Pod ’s End]2995-pod ’s end , ’[71-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom . ‘ Which is it , [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ? ’[71-tom] [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby knew it was somewhere [down town]459-down town , but knew no more respecting [it]460-it . So [they]2988-these same people stopped for a moment , looking about . Almost as [they]2988-these same people did so , there came running round the corner of [the street]461-the street at a quick pace and with a frightened look , [a girl whom [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom]462-a girl whom mr. gradgrind recognized . ‘ [Halloa]104-halloa ! ’[71-tom] said [he]71-tom . ‘ Stop ! Where are [you]104-halloa going ! [The Pegasus]107-the pegasus ’s legs might have been more to the purpose ; but , underneath the winged horse upon the sign - board , [the Pegasus]107-the pegasus ’s Arms was inscribed in Roman letters . As it had grown too dusky without , to see the sign , and as it had not grown light enough within to see the picture , [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom and [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby received no offence from these idealities . [They]492-they followed [the girl]262-the girl up [some steep corner - stairs]494-some steep corner - stairs without meeting [any one]495-any one , and stopped in the dark while [she]262-the girl went on for a candle . It was [a mean , shabbily furnished room]498-a mean , shabbily furnished room , with a bed in [it]498-a mean , shabbily furnished room . [She]76-sissy came bounding down again in a great hurry , opened a battered and mangy old hair trunk , found it empty , and looked round with [her]76-sissy hands clasped and [her]76-sissy face full of terror . ‘ [Father]108-father must have gone down to [the Booth]3032-the booth , [sir]2771-sir . Where the one began , and the other ended , [nobody]365-nobody could have told with any precision . [This gentleman]277-this gentleman was mentioned in the bills of the day as [Mr. E. W. B. [I]0-i mean , ’ said [Mr. Childers]109-mr. childers , with a nod , ‘[515-this unmannerly boy] that [he]515-this unmannerly boy has cut . [He]515-this unmannerly boy was goosed last night , [he]515-this unmannerly boy was goosed the night before last , [he]515-this unmannerly boy was goosed to - day . [He]515-this unmannerly boy has lately got in the way of being always goosed , and [he]515-this unmannerly boy ca n’t stand it . ’ ‘[515-this unmannerly boy] Why has [he]515-this unmannerly boy been — so very much — [Goosed]114-goosed ? ’ asked [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom , forcing the word out of [himself]71-tom , with great solemnity and reluctance . ‘[515-this unmannerly boy] [His]515-this unmannerly boy joints are turning stiff , and [he]515-this unmannerly boy is getting used up , ’ said [Childers]109-mr. childers . ‘[515-this unmannerly boy] [He]515-this unmannerly boy has [his]515-this unmannerly boy points as [a Cackler]518-a cackler still , but [he]515-this unmannerly boy ca n’t get a living out of them . ’ ‘[115-a cackler] [A Cackler]115-a cackler ! ’ [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby repeated . ‘[115-a cackler] Here [we]519-we go again ! ’ ‘[520-a speaker] [A speaker]520-a speaker , if [the gentleman]281-the gentleman likes it better , ’ said [Mr. E. W. B. Childers]109-mr. childers , superciliously throwing the interpretation over [his]109-mr. childers shoulder , and accompanying it with a shake of [his]109-mr. childers long hair — which all shook at once . ‘[520-a speaker] Now , it ’s a remarkable fact , [sir]2771-sir , that it cut [that man]523-that man deeper , to know that [[his]523-that man daughter]2865-his daughter knew of [his]523-that man being goosed , than to go through with it . ’ ‘[2865-his daughter] Good ! ’ interrupted [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . ‘[2865-his daughter] This is good , [Gradgrind]71-tom ! Think of it , [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , in that point of view . ’[71-tom] Meanwhile , [the various members of [Sleary]88-mr. sleary ’s company]549-the various members of sleary ’s company gradually gathered together from [the upper regions]550-the upper regions , where [they]549-the various members of sleary ’s company were quartered , and , from standing about , talking in low voices to [one another]551-one another and to [Mr. Childers]109-mr. childers , gradually insinuated [themselves]549-the various members of sleary ’s company and [him]109-mr. childers into [the room]2901-the room . There were [two or three handsome young women among [them]549-the various members of sleary ’s company , with [[their]553-two or three handsome young women among them , with their two or three husbands , and their two or three mothers , and their eight or nine little children , who did the fairy business when required two or three husbands]554-their two or three husbands , and [[their]553-two or three handsome young women among them , with their two or three husbands , and their two or three mothers , and their eight or nine little children , who did the fairy business when required two or three mothers]555-their two or three mothers , and [[their]553-two or three handsome young women among them , with their two or three husbands , and their two or three mothers , and their eight or nine little children , who did the fairy business when required eight or nine little children]556-their eight or nine little children , who did the fairy business when required]553-two or three handsome young women among them , with their two or three husbands , and their two or three mothers , and their eight or nine little children , who did the fairy business when required . [The father of one of the families]557-the father of one of the families was in the habit of balancing [the father of another of [the families]559-the families]558-the father of another of the families on the top of a great pole ; [the father of [a third family]561-a third family]560-the father of a third family often made a pyramid of [both those fathers]562-both those fathers , with [Master Kidderminster for the apex]563-master kidderminster for the apex , and [himself]109-mr. childers for the base ; [all the fathers]564-all the fathers could dance upon rolling casks , stand upon bottles , catch knives and balls , twirl hand - basins , ride upon anything , jump over everything , and stick at nothing . [All the mothers]565-all the mothers could ( and did ) dance , upon the slack wire and the tight - rope , and perform rapid acts on bare - backed steeds ; [none of [them]565-all the mothers]566-none of them were at all particular in respect of showing [their]565-all the mothers legs ; and one of [them]565-all the mothers , alone in [a Greek chariot]567-a greek chariot , drove six in hand into [every town [they]565-all the mothers came to]568-every town they came to . [They]565-all the mothers all assumed to be mighty rakish and knowing , [they]565-all the mothers were not very tidy in [their]565-all the mothers private dresses , [they]565-all the mothers were not at all orderly in [their]565-all the mothers domestic arrangements , and the combined literature of [the whole company]569-the whole company would have produced but a poor letter on any subject . Yet there was a remarkable gentleness and childishness about [these people]570-these people , a special inaptitude for any kind of sharp practice , and an untiring readiness to help and pity [one another]551-one another , deserving often of as much respect , and always of as much generous construction , as the every - day virtues of [any class of people in [the world]301-the world]572-any class of people in the world . Last of all appeared [Mr. Sleary]88-mr. sleary : [a stout man as already mentioned , with one fixed eye , and one loose eye]574-a stout man as already mentioned , with one fixed eye , and one loose eye , a voice ( if it can be called so ) like the efforts of a broken old pair of bellows , a flabby surface , and a muddled head which was never sober and never drunk . ‘ Thquire ! ’[88-mr. sleary] said [Mr. Sleary]88-mr. sleary , who was troubled with asthma , and whose breath came far too thick and heavy for the letter s , ‘ [Your]88-mr. sleary thervant ! [she]540-your friend has come back ! ’ Then came [Sissy Jupe]76-sissy , running into [the room]2901-the room as [she]76-sissy had run out of [it]2901-the room . And when [she]89-josephine saw [them]3082-the two piebald ponies all assembled , and saw [their]3082-the two piebald ponies looks , and saw [no father]3084-no father there , [she]89-josephine broke into a most deplorable cry , and took refuge on the bosom of [the most accomplished tight - rope lady ( [herself]89-josephine in the family - way ) , who knelt down on the floor to nurse [her]89-josephine , and to weep over [her]89-josephine]3085-the most accomplished tight - rope lady ( herself in the family - way ) , who knelt down on the floor to nurse her , and to weep over her . ‘[108-father] Ith an internal thame , upon [my]0-i thoul it ith , ’ said [Sleary]88-mr. sleary . ‘[108-father] O [[my]0-i dear father]580-my dear father , [[my]0-i good kind father]581-my good kind father , where are [you]580-my dear father gone ? [You]580-my dear father are gone to try to do [me]0-i some good , [I]0-i know ! [You]580-my dear father are gone away for [my]0-i sake , [I]0-i am sure ! And how miserable and helpless [you]580-my dear father will be without [me]0-i , [poor , poor father]582-poor , poor father , until [you]580-my dear father come back ! ’ It was so pathetic to hear [her]262-the girl saying many things of this kind , with [her]262-the girl face turned upward , and [her]262-the girl arms stretched out as if [she]262-the girl were trying to stop [his]0-i departing shadow and embrace it , that [no one]3086-no one spoke a word until [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ( growing impatient ) took the case in hand . ‘[583-good people] Now , [good people]583-good people all , ’ said [he]93-mr. bounderby , ‘[583-good people] this is wanton waste of time . [[Your]580-my dear father father]2783-your father has absconded — deserted [you]580-my dear father — and [you]580-my dear father must n’t expect to see [him]2783-your father again as long as [you]580-my dear father live . ’ [They]583-good people cared so little for plain Fact , [these people]570-these people , and were in that advanced state of degeneracy on the subject , that instead of being impressed by [the speaker]232-the speaker ’s strong common sense , [they]583-good people took it in extraordinary dudgeon . [The men]3089-the men muttered ‘[2783-your father] Shame ! ’ and [the women]3090-the women ‘[2783-your father] Brute ! ’ and [Sleary]88-mr. sleary , in some haste , communicated the following hint , apart to [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i tell [you]580-my dear father what , Thquire . [They]586-they ’re [a very good natur’d people]3091-a very good natur’d people , [[my]0-i people]3092-my people , but [they]586-they ’re[0-i] accuthtomed to be quick in [their]586-they movementh ; and if [you]580-my dear father do n’t act upon [my]0-i advithe , [I]0-i ’m damned if [I]580-my dear father do n’t believe [they]586-they ’ll pith [you]580-my dear father out o ’[580-my dear father] winder . ’ [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby being restrained by this mild suggestion , [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom found an opening for [his]71-tom eminently practical exposition of the subject . ‘[580-my dear father] It is of no moment , ’ said [he]71-tom , ‘[120-thquire] whether [this person]587-this person is to be expected back at any time , or the contrary . [He]587-this person is gone away , and there is no present expectation of [his]587-this person return . That , [I]0-i believe , is agreed on all hands . ’ ‘[0-i] Thath agreed , [Thquire]120-thquire . Thick to that ! ’ From [Sleary]88-mr. sleary . ‘[120-thquire] Well then . [I]0-i , who came here to inform [the father of [the poor girl]3078-the poor girl]588-the father of the poor girl , [Jupe]76-sissy , that [she]3078-the poor girl could not be received at [the school]313-the school any more , in consequence of there being practical objections , into which [I]0-i need not enter , to the reception there of [the children of [persons so employed]592-persons so employed]591-the children of persons so employed , am prepared in these altered circumstances to make a proposal . [I]0-i am willing to take charge of [you]120-thquire , [Jupe]76-sissy , and to educate [you]120-thquire , and provide for [you]120-thquire . But what [I]120-thquire thay , [Thquire]120-thquire , ith , that good tempered or bad tempered , [I]120-thquire never did [a horthe a injury]3095-a horthe a injury yet , no more than thwearing at [him]71-tom went , and that [I]120-thquire do n’t expect [I]120-thquire thall begin otherwithe at [my]120-thquire time of life , with [a rider]3096-a rider . [I]120-thquire never wath much of [a Cackler]518-a cackler , [Thquire]120-thquire , and [I]120-thquire have thed [my]120-thquire thay . ’[120-thquire] The latter part of this speech was addressed to [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom , who received it with a grave inclination of [his]71-tom head , and then remarked : ‘ The only observation [I]71-tom will make to [you]120-thquire , [Jupe]76-sissy , in the way of influencing [your]120-thquire decision , is , that it is highly desirable to have a sound practical education , and that even [[your]120-thquire father]2783-your father [himself]2783-your father ( from what [I]71-tom understand ) appears , on [your]120-thquire behalf , to have known and felt that much . ’[71-tom] The last words had a visible effect upon [her]596-her . [She]596-her stopped in [her]596-her wild crying , a little detached [herself]596-her from [Emma Gordon]123-emma gordon , and turned [her]596-her face full upon [[her]596-her patron]597-her patron . [The whole company]569-the whole company perceived the force of the change , and drew a long breath together , that plainly said , ‘ [she]596-her will go ! ’[569-the whole company] ‘ Be sure [you]596-her know [your]596-her own mind , [Jupe]76-sissy , ’[71-tom] [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom cautioned [her]596-her ; ‘ [I]71-tom say no more . Be sure [you]596-her know [your]596-her own mind ! ’[71-tom] ‘ When [father]2781-father comes back , ’[262-the girl] cried [the girl]262-the girl , bursting into tears again after a minute ’s silence , ‘ how will [he]2781-father ever find [me]262-the girl if [I]262-the girl go away ! ’[262-the girl] ‘ [You]596-her may be quite at ease , ’[71-tom] said [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom , calmly ; [he]71-tom worked out the whole matter like a sum : ‘ [you]596-her may be quite at ease , [Jupe]76-sissy , on that score . In such a case , [[your]596-her father]2783-your father , [I]71-tom apprehend , must find out [Mr.]3101-mr. — ’[71-tom] ‘ [Thleary]66-thleary . Thath [my]262-the girl name , [Thquire]120-thquire . Not athamed of it . Known all over [England]1-england , and [alwayth]3102-alwayth paythe ith way . ’[262-the girl] ‘ Must find out [Mr. Sleary]88-mr. sleary , who would then let [him]2781-father know where [you]596-her went . [I]71-tom should have no power of keeping [you]596-her against [his]2781-father wish , and [he]2781-father would have no difficulty , at any time , in finding [Mr. Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom of [Coketown]4-coketown . [I]71-tom am well known . ’[71-tom] ‘ Well known , ’[88-mr. sleary] assented [Mr. Sleary]88-mr. sleary , rolling [his]88-mr. sleary loose eye . ‘ [You]596-her ’re[88-mr. sleary] one of [the thort , Thquire]600-the thort , thquire , that keepth a prethiouth thight of money out of the houthe . But never mind that at prethent . ’ There was another silence ; and then [she]596-her exclaimed , sobbing with [her]596-her hands before [her]596-her face , ‘[88-mr. sleary] Oh , give [me]0-i [my]0-i clothes , give [me]0-i [my]0-i clothes , and let [me]0-i go away before [I]0-i break [my]0-i heart ! ’ [The women]3090-the women sadly bestirred [themselves]3090-the women to get the clothes together — it was soon done , for [they]3090-the women were not many — and to pack them in a basket which had often travelled with [them]3090-the women . [Sissy]76-sissy sat all the time upon the ground , still sobbing , and covering [her]76-sissy eyes . [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom and [[his]71-tom friend]2921-his friend [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby stood near the door , ready to take [her]76-sissy away . [Mr. Sleary]88-mr. sleary stood in the middle of [the room]2901-the room , with [the male members of [the company]3107-the company]3106-the male members of the company about [him]88-mr. sleary , exactly as [he]88-mr. sleary would have stood in the centre of the ring during [[his]71-tom daughter]2865-his daughter [Josephine]89-josephine ’s performance . [He]88-mr. sleary wanted nothing but [his]88-mr. sleary whip . The basket packed in silence , [they]3090-the women brought [her]76-sissy bonnet to [her]76-sissy , and smoothed [her]76-sissy disordered hair , and put it on . Then [they]3090-the women pressed about [her]76-sissy , and bent over [her]76-sissy in very natural attitudes , kissing and embracing [her]76-sissy : and brought [the children]279-the children to take leave of [her]76-sissy ; and were [a tender - hearted , simple , foolish set of women]3110-a tender - hearted , simple , foolish set of women altogether . ‘[0-i] Now , [Jupe]76-sissy , ’ said [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom . ‘[76-sissy] If [you]76-sissy are quite determined , come ! ’ But [she]76-sissy had to take [her]76-sissy farewell of [the male part of the company]3111-the male part of the company yet , and [every one of [them]3090-the women]3112-every one of them had to unfold [his]3112-every one of them arms ( for [they]3090-the women all assumed the professional attitude when [they]3090-the women found [themselves]3090-the women near [Sleary]88-mr. sleary ) , and give [her]76-sissy a parting kiss — [Master Kidderminster]111-master kidderminster excepted , in whose young nature there was an original flavour of the misanthrope , who was also known to have harboured matrimonial views , and who moodily withdrew . [Mr. Sleary]88-mr. sleary was reserved until the last . Opening [his]88-mr. sleary arms wide [he]88-mr. sleary took [her]76-sissy by both [her]76-sissy hands , and would have sprung [her]76-sissy up and down , after the riding - master manner of congratulating [young ladies]3113-young ladies on [their]3113-young ladies dismounting from a rapid act ; but there was no rebound in [Sissy]76-sissy , and [she]76-sissy only stood before [him]88-mr. sleary crying . ‘[76-sissy] Good - bye , [[my]0-i dear]601-my dear ! ’ said [Sleary]88-mr. sleary . ‘[76-sissy] [You]601-my dear ’ll make [your]601-my dear fortun , [I]0-i hope , and [none of [[our]603-our poor folkth]604-our poor folkth]602-none of our poor folkth will ever trouble [you]601-my dear , [I]0-i ’ll pound it . [I]0-i with [[your]601-my dear father]2783-your father had n’t taken [hith]606-hith dog with [him]2783-your father ; ith a ill - conwenienth to have the dog out of the billth . But on thecond thoughth , [he]2783-your father would n’t have performed without [hith mathter]607-hith mathter , tho ith ath broad ath ith long ! ’ With that [he]88-mr. sleary regarded [her]601-my dear attentively with [his]88-mr. sleary fixed eye , surveyed [[his]88-mr. sleary company]3114-his company with [his]88-mr. sleary loose one , kissed [her]601-my dear , shook [his]88-mr. sleary head , and handed [her]601-my dear to [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom as to a horse . ‘[2783-your father] There the ith , Thquire , ’ [he]88-mr. sleary said , sweeping [her]601-my dear with a professional glance as if [she]601-my dear were being adjusted in [her]601-my dear seat , ‘[2783-your father] and the’ll do [you]601-my dear juthtithe . Good - bye , [Thethilia]122-thethilia ! ’ ‘[76-sissy] Good - bye , [Cecilia]76-sissy ! ’ ‘[76-sissy] Good - bye , [Sissy]76-sissy ! ’ ‘[76-sissy] God bless [you]601-my dear , [dear]3016-dear ! ’ In a variety of voices from [all the room]3115-all the room . But [the riding - master eye]3116-the riding - master eye had observed the bottle of the nine oils in [her]601-my dear bosom , and [he]0-i now interposed with ‘[601-my dear] Leave the bottle , [[my]0-i dear]601-my dear ; ith large to carry ; it will be of no uthe to [you]601-my dear now . Give it to [me]0-i ! ’ ‘[0-i] No , no ! ’ [she]601-my dear said , in another burst of tears . ‘[0-i] Oh , no ! Pray let [me]0-i keep it for [father]2781-father till [he]2781-father comes back ! [He]2781-father will want it when [he]2781-father comes back . [He]2781-father had never thought of going away , when [he]2781-father sent [me]0-i for it . ( [You]601-my dear [thee]601-my dear how it ith , Thquire ! ) Farewell , [Thethilia]122-thethilia ! [My]0-i latht wordth to [you]601-my dear ith thith , Thtick to the termth of [your]601-my dear engagement , be obedient to [the Thquire]120-thquire , and forget uth . But if , when [you]601-my dear ’re grown up and married and well off , [you]601-my dear come upon any horthe - riding ever , do n’t be hard upon it , do n’t be croth with it , give it a Bethpeak if [you]601-my dear can , and think [you]601-my dear might do wurth . [People]2821-people mutht be amuthed , Thquire , thomehow , ’[88-mr. sleary] continued [Sleary]88-mr. sleary , rendered more pursy than ever , by so much talking ; ‘ [they]2821-people ca n’t be [alwayth]3118-alwayth a working , nor yet [they]2821-people ca n’t be alwayth a learning . Make the betht of uth ; not the wurtht . [I]88-mr. sleary ’ve got [my]88-mr. sleary living out of the horthe - riding all [my]88-mr. sleary life , [I]88-mr. sleary know ; but [I]88-mr. sleary conthider that [I]88-mr. sleary lay down the philothophy of the thubject when [I]88-mr. sleary thay to [you]3119-you , [Thquire]120-thquire , make the betht of uth : not the wurtht ! ’[88-mr. sleary] The Sleary philosophy was propounded as [they]612-they went [downstairs]613-downstairs and the fixed eye of Philosophy — and its rolling eye , too — soon lost [the three figures]614-the three figures and the basket in the darkness of [the street]461-the street . [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby being [a bachelor]616-a bachelor , [an elderly lady]617-an elderly lady presided over [[his]93-mr. bounderby establishment]618-his establishment , in consideration of a certain annual stipend . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit was [this lady]619-this lady ’s name ; and [she]619-this lady was a prominent figure in attendance on [[Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s car]620-mr. bounderby ’s car , as [it]620-mr. bounderby ’s car rolled along in triumph with the Bully of humility inside . For , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit had not only seen different days , but was highly connected . [She]126-mrs. sparsit had [a great aunt living in these very times called [Lady Scadgers]127-lady scadgers]621-a great aunt living in these very times called lady scadgers . [Mr. Sparsit]128-mr. sparsit , deceased , of whom [she]619-this lady was [the relict]622-the relict , had been by [the mother]623-the mother ’s side what [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit still called ‘ [a Powler]3120-a powler . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] [Strangers of limited information and dull apprehension]624-strangers of limited information and dull apprehension were sometimes observed not to know what [a Powler]3120-a powler was , and even to appear uncertain whether it might be a business , or [a political party , or a profession of faith]626-a political party , or a profession of faith . [The better class of minds]627-the better class of minds , however , did not need to be informed that [the Powlers]129-the powlers were an ancient stock , who could trace [themselves]129-the powlers so exceedingly far back that it was not surprising if [they]129-the powlers sometimes lost [themselves]129-the powlers — which [they]129-the powlers had rather frequently done , as [respected horse - flesh , blind - hookey , Hebrew monetary transactions]628-respected horse - flesh , blind - hookey , hebrew monetary transactions , and [[the Insolvent Debtors]629-the insolvent debtors ’ Court]3121-the insolvent debtors ’ court . [The late Mr. Sparsit]128-mr. sparsit , being by [the mother]623-the mother ’s side [a Powler]3120-a powler , married [this lady]619-this lady , being by [the father]438-the father ’s side [a Scadgers]3126-a scadgers . [Lady Scadgers]127-lady scadgers ( [an immensely fat old woman]3127-an immensely fat old woman , with an inordinate appetite for butcher ’s meat , and a mysterious leg which had now refused to get out of bed for fourteen years ) contrived the marriage , at a period when [Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit was just of age , and chiefly noticeable for a slender body , weakly supported on two long slim props , and surmounted by no head worth mentioning . [He]128-mr. sparsit inherited a fair fortune from [[his]128-mr. sparsit uncle]3128-his uncle , but owed it all before [he]128-mr. sparsit came into it , and spent it twice over immediately afterwards . Thus , when [he]128-mr. sparsit died , at twenty - four ( the scene of [his]128-mr. sparsit decease , [Calais]130-calais , and the cause , brandy ) , [he]128-mr. sparsit did not leave [[his]128-mr. sparsit widow]3129-his widow , from whom [he]128-mr. sparsit had been separated soon after the honeymoon , in affluent circumstances . [That bereaved lady]3130-that bereaved lady , fifteen years older than [he]128-mr. sparsit , fell presently at deadly feud with [[her]3130-that bereaved lady only relative]3131-her only relative , [Lady Scadgers]127-lady scadgers ; and , partly to spite [her]3130-that bereaved lady ladyship , and partly to maintain [herself]3130-that bereaved lady , went out at a salary . And here [she]3130-that bereaved lady was now , in [her]3130-that bereaved lady elderly days , with the Coriolanian style of nose and the dense black eyebrows which had captivated [Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , making [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s tea as [he]93-mr. bounderby took [his]93-mr. bounderby breakfast . If [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby had been [a Conqueror]3132-a conqueror , and [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit [a captive Princess whom [he]128-mr. sparsit took about as a feature in [his]128-mr. sparsit state - processions]3133-a captive princess whom he took about as a feature in his state - processions , [he]128-mr. sparsit could not have made a greater flourish with [her]3130-that bereaved lady than [he]128-mr. sparsit habitually did . Just as it belonged to [his]128-mr. sparsit boastfulness to depreciate [his]128-mr. sparsit own extraction , so it belonged to [it]3134-it to exalt [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s . In the measure that [he]128-mr. sparsit would not allow [his]128-mr. sparsit own youth to have been attended by a single favourable circumstance , [he]128-mr. sparsit brightened [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s juvenile career with every possible advantage , and showered waggon - loads of early roses all over [[that lady]3135-that lady ’s path]3136-that lady ’s path . ‘[2771-sir] And yet , [sir]2771-sir , ’ [he]0-i would say , ‘[2771-sir] how does it turn out after all ? Why here [she]631-she is at a hundred a year ( [I]0-i give [her]631-she a hundred , which [she]631-she is pleased to term handsome ) , keeping [the house of [Josiah Bounderby]97-bounderby of [Coketown]4-coketown]632-the house of josiah bounderby of coketown ! ’ Nay , [he]128-mr. sparsit made this foil of [his]128-mr. sparsit so very widely known , that [third parties]3137-third parties took it up , and handled it on some occasions with considerable briskness . It was one of the most exasperating attributes of [Bounderby]97-bounderby , that [he]97-bounderby not only sang [his]97-bounderby own praises but stimulated [other men]3138-other men to sing them . There was a moral infection of clap - trap in [him]97-bounderby . [Strangers]3139-strangers , modest enough elsewhere , started up at dinners in [Coketown]4-coketown , and boasted , in quite a rampant way , of [Bounderby]97-bounderby . [They]3139-strangers made [him]97-bounderby out to be [the Royal arms]3140-the royal arms , [the Union - Jack]3141-the union - jack , [Magna Charta]16-magna charta , [John Bull]131-john bull , [Habeas Corpus]17-habeas corpus , the Bill of Rights , [[An Englishman]3142-an englishman ’s house]3143-an englishman ’s house is [[his]3142-an englishman castle]3144-his castle , Church and State , and God save [the Queen]3145-the queen , all put together . And as often ( and it was very often ) as [an orator of this kind]3146-an orator of this kind brought into [his]2771-sir peroration , ‘[97-bounderby] [Princes]633-princes and [lords]634-lords may flourish or may fade , A breath can make them , as a breath has made , ’ — it was , for certain , more or less understood among [the company]3107-the company that [he]2771-sir had heard of [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit . ‘[93-mr. bounderby] [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘[93-mr. bounderby] [you]93-mr. bounderby are unusually slow , [sir]2771-sir , with [your]93-mr. bounderby breakfast this morning . ’ ‘[93-mr. bounderby] Why , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’ [he]0-i returned , ‘[361-ma’am] [I]0-i am thinking about [Tom Gradgrind]71-tom ’s whim ; ’ [Tom Gradgrind]71-tom , for a bluff independent manner of speaking — as if [somebody]3148-somebody were always endeavouring to bribe [him]0-i with immense sums to say [Thomas]71-tom , and [he]0-i would n’t ; ‘[71-tom] [Tom Gradgrind]71-tom ’s whim , [ma’am]361-ma’am , of bringing up [the tumbling - girl]638-the tumbling - girl . ’ ‘[361-ma’am] [The girl]262-the girl is now waiting to know , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘[361-ma’am] whether [she]262-the girl is to go straight to [the school]313-the school , or up to [the Lodge]641-the lodge . ’ ‘[262-the girl] [She]262-the girl must wait , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’ answered [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ‘[262-the girl] till [I]0-i know [myself]0-i . Very thoughtful of [you]0-i ! ’ [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s Coriolanian nose underwent a slight expansion of the nostrils , and [her]126-mrs. sparsit black eyebrows contracted as [she]126-mrs. sparsit took a sip of tea . ‘[0-i] It ’s tolerably clear to [me]0-i , ’ said [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ‘[0-i] that [the little puss]646-the little puss can get small good out of such companionship . ’ ‘[0-i] Are [you]0-i speaking of [young Miss Gradgrind]132-miss gradgrind , [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ? ’ ‘[0-i] Yes , [ma’am]361-ma’am , [I]0-i ’m speaking of [Louisa]92-louisa . ’[0-i] ‘ [Your]0-i observation being limited to “ little puss , ” ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘ and there being [two little girls in question]3149-two little girls in question , [I]126-mrs. sparsit did not know which might be indicated by that expression . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] ‘ [Louisa]92-louisa , ’[93-mr. bounderby] repeated [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . ‘ [Louisa]92-louisa , [Louisa]92-louisa . ’[93-mr. bounderby] ‘ [You]93-mr. bounderby are quite another father to [Louisa]92-louisa , [sir]2771-sir . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit took a little more tea ; and , as [she]126-mrs. sparsit bent [her]126-mrs. sparsit again contracted eyebrows over [her]126-mrs. sparsit steaming cup , rather looked as if [her]126-mrs. sparsit classical countenance were invoking the infernal gods . ‘ If [you]2771-sir had said [I]126-mrs. sparsit was [another father to [Tom]71-tom]3151-another father to tom — [young Tom]71-tom , [I]126-mrs. sparsit mean , not [[my]126-mrs. sparsit friend]508-my friend [Tom Gradgrind]71-tom — [you]2771-sir might have been nearer the mark .
