Otherwise , [I]0-i know it is one of those subjects [I]0-i shall never hear the last of . ’ When [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom had presented [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby , [Sissy]76-sissy had suddenly turned [her]76-sissy head , and looked , in wonder , in pity , in sorrow , in doubt , in a multitude of emotions , towards [Louisa]92-louisa . [Louisa]92-louisa had known it , and seen it , without looking at [her]92-louisa . From that moment [she]92-louisa was impassive , proud and cold — held [Sissy]76-sissy at a distance — changed to [her]92-louisa altogether . [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s first disquietude on hearing of [his]93-mr. bounderby happiness , was occasioned by the necessity of imparting it to [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit . [He]93-mr. bounderby could not make up [his]93-mr. bounderby mind how to do that , or what the consequences of the step might be . Whether [she]126-mrs. sparsit would instantly depart , bag and baggage , to [Lady Scadgers]127-lady scadgers , or would positively refuse to budge from [the premises]746-the premises ; whether [she]126-mrs. sparsit would be plaintive or abusive , tearful or tearing ; whether [she]126-mrs. sparsit would break [her]126-mrs. sparsit heart , or break the looking - glass ; [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby could not all foresee . However , as it must be done , [he]93-mr. bounderby had no choice but to do it ; so , after attempting several letters , and failing in them all , [he]93-mr. bounderby resolved to do it by word of mouth . On [his]93-mr. bounderby way [home]2856-home , on the evening [he]93-mr. bounderby set aside for this momentous purpose , [he]93-mr. bounderby took the precaution of stepping into [a chemist ’s shop]3606-a chemist ’s shop and buying a bottle of the very strongest smelling - salts . ‘[0-i] By [George]72-george ! ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ‘[72-george] if [she]1046-she takes it in the fainting way , [I]0-i ’ll have the skin off [her]1046-she nose , at all events ! ’ But , in spite of being thus forearmed , [he]93-mr. bounderby entered [[his]93-mr. bounderby own house]3607-his own house with anything but a courageous air ; and appeared before the object of [his]93-mr. bounderby misgivings , like a dog who was conscious of coming direct from [the pantry]3608-the pantry . ‘[0-i] Good evening , [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ! ’ ‘[93-mr. bounderby] Good evening , [ma’am]361-ma’am , good evening . ’ [He]93-mr. bounderby drew up [his]93-mr. bounderby chair , and [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit drew back [hers]126-mrs. sparsit , as who should say , ‘[93-mr. bounderby] [Your]93-mr. bounderby fireside , [sir]2771-sir . [I]0-i freely admit it . It is for [you]2771-sir to occupy it all , if [you]2771-sir think proper . ’ ‘[2771-sir] Do n’t go to [the North Pole]29-the north pole , [ma’am]361-ma’am ! ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . ‘[361-ma’am] Thank [you]2771-sir , [sir]2771-sir , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , and returned , though short of [her]126-mrs. sparsit former position . [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby sat looking at [her]126-mrs. sparsit , as , with the points of a stiff , sharp pair of scissors , [she]126-mrs. sparsit picked out holes for some inscrutable ornamental purpose , in a piece of cambric . An operation which , taken in connexion with the bushy eyebrows and the Roman nose , suggested with some liveliness the idea of a hawk engaged upon the eyes of a tough little bird . [She]126-mrs. sparsit was so steadfastly occupied , that many minutes elapsed before [she]126-mrs. sparsit looked up from [her]126-mrs. sparsit work ; when [she]126-mrs. sparsit did so [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby bespoke [her]126-mrs. sparsit attention with a hitch of [his]93-mr. bounderby head . ‘[2771-sir] [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , putting [his]93-mr. bounderby hands in [his]93-mr. bounderby pockets , and assuring [himself]93-mr. bounderby with [his]93-mr. bounderby right hand that the cork of the little bottle was ready for use , ‘[126-mrs. sparsit] [I]0-i have no occasion to say to [you]126-mrs. sparsit , that [you]126-mrs. sparsit are not only [a lady born and bred]1052-a lady born and bred , but [a devilish sensible woman]1053-a devilish sensible woman . ’ ‘[2771-sir] [Sir]2771-sir , ’ returned [the lady]3277-the lady , ‘[2771-sir] this is indeed not the first time that [you]2771-sir have honoured [me]0-i with similar expressions of [your]2771-sir good opinion . ’ ‘[2771-sir] [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ‘[126-mrs. sparsit] [I]0-i am going to astonish [you]126-mrs. sparsit . ’ ‘[2771-sir] Yes , [sir]2771-sir ? ’ returned [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , interrogatively , and in the most tranquil manner possible . [She]126-mrs. sparsit generally wore mittens , and [she]126-mrs. sparsit now laid down [her]126-mrs. sparsit work , and smoothed those mittens . ‘[2771-sir] [I]0-i am going , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’ said [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ‘[0-i] to marry [[Tom Gradgrind]71-tom ’s daughter]1058-tom gradgrind ’s daughter . ’ ‘[361-ma’am] Yes , [sir]2771-sir , ’ returned [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit . ‘[2771-sir] [I]0-i hope [you]2771-sir may be happy , [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . [I]0-i hope [I]0-i shall be . ’ ‘[2771-sir] Do [you]2771-sir , [sir]2771-sir ! ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , with great affability . ‘[2771-sir] But naturally [you]2771-sir do ; of course [you]2771-sir do . ’ A very awkward pause on [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s part , succeeded . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit sedately resumed [her]126-mrs. sparsit work and occasionally gave a small cough , which sounded like the cough of conscious strength and forbearance . ‘[2771-sir] Well , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’ resumed [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ‘[2771-sir] under these circumstances , [I]0-i imagine it would not be agreeable to a character like [yours]361-ma’am to remain [here]366-here , though [you]361-ma’am would be very welcome here . ’ ‘[361-ma’am] Oh , dear no , [sir]2771-sir , [I]0-i could on no account think of that ! ’ [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit shook [her]126-mrs. sparsit head , still in [her]126-mrs. sparsit highly superior manner , and a little changed the small cough — coughing now , as if the spirit of prophecy rose within [her]126-mrs. sparsit , but had better be coughed down . ‘[361-ma’am] However , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’ said [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ‘[361-ma’am] there are apartments at [the Bank]3524-the bank , where [a born and bred lady]1070-a born and bred lady , as [keeper of [the place]2849-the place]1071-keeper of the place , would be rather a catch than otherwise ; and if the same terms — ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i beg [your]2771-sir pardon , [sir]2771-sir . Therefore , [sir]2771-sir , [I]0-i accept [your]2771-sir offer gratefully , and with many sincere acknowledgments for past favours . It was in vain for [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby to bluster or to assert [himself]93-mr. bounderby in any of [his]93-mr. bounderby explosive ways ; [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit was resolved to have compassion on [him]93-mr. bounderby , as [a Victim]3610-a victim . [She]126-mrs. sparsit was polite , obliging , cheerful , hopeful ; but , the more polite , the more obliging , the more cheerful , the more hopeful , the more exemplary altogether , [she]126-mrs. sparsit ; [the forlorner Sacrifice]3611-the forlorner sacrifice and [Victim]156-victim , [he]93-mr. bounderby . [She]126-mrs. sparsit had that tenderness for [his]93-mr. bounderby melancholy fate , that [his]93-mr. bounderby great red countenance used to break out into cold perspirations when [she]126-mrs. sparsit looked at [him]93-mr. bounderby . Meanwhile the marriage was appointed to be solemnized in eight weeks ’[0-i] time , and [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby went every evening to [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge as [an accepted wooer]1086-an accepted wooer . Love was made on these occasions in the form of bracelets ; and , on all occasions during the period of betrothal , took a manufacturing aspect . Dresses were made , jewellery was made , cakes and gloves were made , settlements were made , and an extensive assortment of Facts did appropriate honour to the contract . The business was all Fact , from first to last . The Hours did not go through any of those rosy performances , which [foolish poets]1087-foolish poets have ascribed to [them]1087-foolish poets at such times ; neither did the clocks go any faster , or any slower , than at other seasons . The deadly statistical recorder in [the Gradgrind observatory]1088-the gradgrind observatory knocked every second on the head as it was born , and buried it with [his]93-mr. bounderby accustomed regularity . So the day came , as all other days come to [people who will only stick to reason]1089-people who will only stick to reason ; and when it came , there were married in [the church of the florid wooden legs]1090-the church of the florid wooden legs — that popular order of architecture — [Josiah Bounderby]97-bounderby Esquire of [Coketown]4-coketown , to [Louisa eldest daughter of [Thomas Gradgrind Esquire]157-tom gradgrind of [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge , M.P. for [that borough]1092-that borough]1091-louisa eldest daughter of thomas gradgrind esquire of stone lodge , m.p. for that borough . And when [they]1093-you were united in holy matrimony , [they]1093-you went [home]2856-home to breakfast at [Stone Lodge aforesaid]3-stone lodge . There was [an improving party assembled on the auspicious occasion]1095-an improving party assembled on the auspicious occasion , who knew what everything [they]1093-you [had to eat and drink was made of , and how it was imported or exported , and in what quantities , and in what bottoms , whether native or foreign , and all about it]1096-had to eat and drink was made of , and how it was imported or exported , and in what quantities , and in what bottoms , whether native or foreign , and all about it . [The bridesmaids]1097-the bridesmaids , down to [little Jane Gradgrind]100-jane , were , in an intellectual point of view , [fit helpmates for [the calculating boy]1099-the calculating boy]1098-fit helpmates for the calculating boy ; and there was no nonsense about any of [the company]3107-the company . After breakfast , [the bridegroom]3562-the bridegroom addressed [them]1093-you in the following terms : ‘ [Ladies]667-ladies and [gentlemen]448-gentlemen , [I]3562-the bridegroom am [Josiah Bounderby of [Coketown]4-coketown]390-josiah bounderby of coketown . Since [you]1093-you have done [[my]3562-the bridegroom wife]3615-my wife and [myself]3562-the bridegroom the honour of drinking [our]3616-our healths and happiness , [I]3562-the bridegroom suppose [I]3562-the bridegroom must acknowledge the same ; though , as [you]1093-you all know [me]3562-the bridegroom , and know what [I]3562-the bridegroom am , and what [my]3562-the bridegroom extraction was , [you]1093-you wo n’t expect a speech from [a man who , when [he]3617-a man who , when he sees a post sees [a Post]3618-a post]3617-a man who , when he sees a post , says “ that ’s a Post , ” and when [he]3617-a man who , when he sees a post sees a Pump , says “ that ’s a Pump , ” and is not to be got to call a Post a Pump , or a Pump a Post , or either of [them]3619-them a Toothpick . [I]3562-the bridegroom am not [[your]1093-you man]3622-your man . However , if [I]3562-the bridegroom feel a little independent when [I]3562-the bridegroom look around this table to - day , and reflect how little [I]3562-the bridegroom thought of marrying [[Tom Gradgrind]157-tom gradgrind ’s daughter]1058-tom gradgrind ’s daughter when [I]3562-the bridegroom was [a ragged street - boy]3624-a ragged street - boy , who never washed [his]3617-a man who , when he sees a post face unless it was at a pump , and that not oftener than once a fortnight , [I]3562-the bridegroom hope [I]3562-the bridegroom may be excused . [I]3562-the bridegroom do feel independent . Now [I]3562-the bridegroom have mentioned , and [you]1093-you have mentioned , that [I]3562-the bridegroom am this day married to [[Tom Gradgrind]157-tom gradgrind ’s daughter]1058-tom gradgrind ’s daughter . [I]3562-the bridegroom am very glad to be so . It has long been [my]3562-the bridegroom wish to be so . [I]3562-the bridegroom have watched [her]1058-tom gradgrind ’s daughter bringing - up , and [I]3562-the bridegroom believe [she]1058-tom gradgrind ’s daughter is worthy of [me]3562-the bridegroom . At the same time — not to deceive [you]1093-you — [I]3562-the bridegroom believe [I]3562-the bridegroom am worthy of [her]1058-tom gradgrind ’s daughter . So , [I]3562-the bridegroom thank [you]1093-you , on both [our]3626-our parts , for the good - will [you]1093-you have shown towards [us]3626-our ; and the best wish [I]3562-the bridegroom can give [the unmarried part of the present company]3627-the unmarried part of the present company , is this : [I]3562-the bridegroom hope [every bachelor]3628-every bachelor may find as good [a wife]3629-a wife as [I]3562-the bridegroom have found . And [I]3562-the bridegroom hope [every spinster]3630-every spinster may find as good a husband as [[my]3562-the bridegroom wife]3615-my wife has found . ’[3562-the bridegroom] Shortly after which oration , as [they]1102-they were going on a nuptial trip to [Lyons]31-lyons , in order that [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby might take the opportunity of seeing how [the Hands]3315-the hands got on in those parts , and whether [they]1102-they , too , required to be fed with gold spoons ; [the happy pair]1104-the happy pair departed for [the railroad]1105-the railroad . [The bride]1106-the bride , in [passing down - stairs]1107-passing down - stairs , dressed for [her]1106-the bride journey , found [Tom]157-tom gradgrind waiting for [her]1106-the bride — flushed , either with [his]157-tom gradgrind feelings , or the vinous part of the breakfast . ‘ What [a game girl]3632-a game girl [you]1106-the bride are , to be such [a first - rate sister]3633-a first - rate sister , [Loo]101-loo ! ’[157-tom gradgrind] whispered [Tom]157-tom gradgrind . [She]1106-the bride clung to [him]157-tom gradgrind as [she]1106-the bride should have clung to some far better nature that day , and was a little shaken in [her]1106-the bride reserved composure for the first time . ‘ [Old Bounderby]158-old bounderby ’s quite ready , ’[157-tom gradgrind] said [Tom]157-tom gradgrind . ‘ Time ’s up . Good - bye ! [I]157-tom gradgrind shall be on the look - out for [you]1108-you , when [you]1108-you come back . [I]157-tom gradgrind say , [[my]157-tom gradgrind dear]601-my dear [Loo]101-loo ! An’t it uncommonly jolly now ! ’[157-tom gradgrind] A sunny midsummer day . There was such a thing sometimes , even in [Coketown]4-coketown . Seen from a distance in such weather , [Coketown]4-coketown lay shrouded in a haze of [its]4-coketown own , which appeared impervious to the sun ’s rays . [You]1108-you only knew [the town]2838-the town was there , because [you]1108-you knew there could have been no such sulky blotch upon the prospect without [a town]2971-a town . A blur of soot and smoke , now confusedly tending this way , now that way , now aspiring to [the vault of Heaven]1111-the vault of heaven , now murkily creeping along [the earth]690-the earth , as the wind rose and fell , or changed its quarter : a dense formless jumble , with sheets of cross light in it , that showed nothing but masses of darkness : — [Coketown]4-coketown in the distance was suggestive of [itself]4-coketown , though not a brick of [it]4-coketown could be seen . The wonder was , it was there at all . It had been ruined so often , that it was amazing how it had borne so many shocks . Surely there never was such fragile china - ware as that of which [the millers of [Coketown]4-coketown]1113-the millers of coketown were made . Handle [them]1114-they never so lightly , and [they]1114-they fell to pieces with such ease that [you]1108-you might suspect [them]1114-they of having been flawed before . [They]1114-they were ruined , when [they]1114-they were required to send [labouring children]1115-labouring children to [school]1116-school ; [they]1114-they were ruined when [inspectors]1117-inspectors were appointed to look into [[their]1114-they works]1118-their works ; [they]1114-they were ruined , when [such inspectors]1119-such inspectors considered it doubtful whether [they]1114-they were quite justified in chopping [people]2821-people up with [their]1114-they machinery ; [they]1114-they were utterly undone , when it was hinted that perhaps [they]1114-they need not always make quite so much smoke . Besides [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s gold spoon which was generally received in [Coketown]4-coketown , another prevalent fiction was very popular [there]425-there . It took the form of a threat . Whenever [a Coketowner]1122-a coketowner felt [he]1122-a coketowner was ill - used — that is to say , whenever [he]1122-a coketowner was not left entirely alone , and it was proposed to hold [him]1122-a coketowner accountable for the consequences of any of [his]1122-a coketowner acts — [he]1122-a coketowner was sure to come out with the awful menace , that [he]1122-a coketowner would ‘ sooner pitch [[his]1122-a coketowner property]3635-his property into [the Atlantic]32-the atlantic . ’[1122-a coketowner] This had terrified [the Home Secretary]159-the home secretary within an inch of [his]159-the home secretary life , on several occasions . However , [the Coketowners]160-the coketowners were so patriotic after all , that [they]160-the coketowners never had pitched [[their]160-the coketowners property]1123-their property into [the Atlantic]32-the atlantic yet , but , on the contrary , had been kind enough to take mighty good care of it . So there it was , in the haze yonder ; and it increased and multiplied . [The streets]2975-the streets were hot and dusty on the summer day , and the sun was so bright that it even shone through the heavy vapour drooping over [Coketown]4-coketown , and could not be looked at steadily . [Stokers]1125-stokers emerged from low underground doorways into [factory yards]1126-factory yards , and sat on steps , and posts , and palings , wiping [their]1125-stokers swarthy visages , and contemplating coals . [The whole town]1127-the whole town seemed to be frying in oil . There was a stifling smell of hot oil everywhere . The steam - engines shone with it , the dresses of [the Hands]3315-the hands were soiled with it , [the mills throughout [their]1129-the mills throughout their many stories many stories]1129-the mills throughout their many stories oozed and trickled it . The atmosphere of [those Fairy palaces]1130-those fairy palaces was like the breath of [the simoom]1131-the simoom : and [[their]1130-those fairy palaces inhabitants]1132-their inhabitants , wasting with heat , toiled languidly in [the desert]1133-the desert . But no temperature made [the melancholy mad elephants]1134-the melancholy mad elephants more mad or more sane . [Their]1134-the melancholy mad elephants wearisome heads went up and down at the same rate , in hot weather and cold , wet weather and dry , fair weather and foul . The measured motion of [their]1134-the melancholy mad elephants shadows on the walls , was the substitute [Coketown]4-coketown had to show for the shadows of [rustling woods]1135-rustling woods ; while , for the summer hum of insects , it could offer , all the year round , from the dawn of Monday to the night of Saturday , the whirr of shafts and wheels . Drowsily [they]1134-the melancholy mad elephants whirred all through this sunny day , making [the passenger]1136-the passenger more sleepy and more hot as [he]1136-the passenger passed the humming walls of [the mills]944-the mills . Sun - blinds , and sprinklings of water , a little cooled [the main streets]1138-the main streets and [the shops]392-the shops ; but [the mills]944-the mills , and [the courts]1141-the courts and [alleys]1142-alleys , baked at a fierce heat . Down upon [the river]1143-the river that was black and thick with dye , [some [Coketown]4-coketown boys who were at large — a rare sight there]1144-some coketown boys who were at large — a rare sight there — rowed [a crazy boat]1145-a crazy boat , which made a spumous track upon the water as [it]1145-a crazy boat jogged along , while every dip of an oar stirred up vile smells . But the sun itself , however beneficent , generally , was less kind to [Coketown]4-coketown than hard frost , and rarely looked intently into any of [[its]4-coketown closer regions]1146-its closer regions without engendering more death than life . So does the eye of [Heaven]1147-heaven [itself]1148-itself become an evil eye , when incapable or sordid hands are interposed between it and the things it looks upon to bless . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit sat in [[her]126-mrs. sparsit afternoon apartment]1149-her afternoon apartment at [the Bank]33-the bank , on the shadier side of [the frying street]1150-the frying street . [Office]1151-office - hours were over : and at that period of the day , in warm weather , [she]126-mrs. sparsit usually embellished with [her]126-mrs. sparsit genteel presence , [a managerial board - room over [the public office]1153-the public office]1152-a managerial board - room over the public office . [[Her]126-mrs. sparsit own private sitting - room]1154-her own private sitting - room was a story higher , at the window of which post of observation [she]126-mrs. sparsit was ready , every morning , to greet [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , as [he]93-mr. bounderby came across [the road]2846-the road , with the sympathizing recognition appropriate to [a Victim]3610-a victim . [He]93-mr. bounderby had been married now a year ; and [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit had never released [him]93-mr. bounderby from [her]126-mrs. sparsit determined pity a moment . [The Bank]33-the bank offered no violence to the wholesome monotony of [the town]2838-the town . [It]1158-it was [another red brick house , with black outside shutters]1159-another red brick house , with black outside shutters , green inside blinds , a black street - door up two white steps , a brazen door - plate , and a brazen door - handle full stop . [It]1158-it was a size larger than [[Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s house]1160-mr. bounderby ’s house , as [other houses]1161-other houses were from a size to half - a - dozen sizes smaller ; in all other particulars , [it]1158-it was strictly according to pattern . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit was conscious that by coming in the evening - tide among the desks and writing implements , [she]126-mrs. sparsit shed a feminine , not to say also aristocratic , grace upon [the office]1162-the office . Seated , with [her]126-mrs. sparsit needlework or netting apparatus , at the window , [she]126-mrs. sparsit had a self - laudatory sense of correcting , by [her]126-mrs. sparsit ladylike deportment , the rude business aspect of [the place]2849-the place . With this impression of [her]126-mrs. sparsit interesting character upon [her]126-mrs. sparsit , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit considered [herself]126-mrs. sparsit , in some sort , the Bank Fairy . [The townspeople who , in [their]1164-the townspeople who , in their passing and repassing , saw her there passing and repassing , saw [her]126-mrs. sparsit there]1164-the townspeople who , in their passing and repassing , saw her there , regarded [her]126-mrs. sparsit as [the Bank Dragon keeping watch over the treasures of [the mine]1166-the mine]1165-the bank dragon keeping watch over the treasures of the mine . What those treasures were , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit knew as little as [they]1164-the townspeople who , in their passing and repassing , saw her there did . Gold and silver coin , precious paper , secrets that if divulged would bring vague destruction upon [vague persons]1167-vague persons ( generally , however , people whom [she]126-mrs. sparsit disliked ) , were the chief items in [her]126-mrs. sparsit ideal catalogue thereof . For the rest , [she]126-mrs. sparsit knew that after office - hours , [she]126-mrs. sparsit reigned supreme over all the office furniture , and over [a locked - up iron room with three locks]1168-a locked - up iron room with three locks , against the door of which strong chamber [the light porter]1169-the light porter laid [his]1169-the light porter head every night , on a truckle bed , that disappeared at cockcrow . Further , [she]126-mrs. sparsit was lady paramount over [certain vaults in [the basement]1171-the basement]1170-certain vaults in the basement , sharply spiked off from communication with [the predatory world]1172-the predatory world ; and over the relics of the current day ’s work , consisting of blots of ink , worn - out pens , fragments of wafers , and scraps of paper torn so small , that nothing interesting could ever be deciphered on them when [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit tried . Lastly , [she]126-mrs. sparsit was guardian over a little armoury of cutlasses and carbines , arrayed in vengeful order above one of the official chimney - pieces ; and over that respectable tradition never to be separated from a place of business claiming to be wealthy — a row of fire - buckets — [vessels calculated to be of no physical utility on any occasion]1173-vessels calculated to be of no physical utility on any occasion , but observed to exercise a fine moral influence , almost equal to bullion , on [most beholders]1174-most beholders . [A deaf serving - woman]1175-a deaf serving - woman and [the light porter]1169-the light porter completed [[Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s empire]1177-mrs. sparsit ’s empire . [The deaf serving - woman]1178-the deaf serving - woman was rumoured to be wealthy ; and a saying had for years gone about among [the lower orders of [Coketown]4-coketown]1179-the lower orders of coketown , that [she]126-mrs. sparsit would be murdered some night when [the Bank]3524-the bank was shut , for the sake of [her]126-mrs. sparsit money . It was generally considered , indeed , that [she]126-mrs. sparsit had been due some time , and ought to have fallen long ago ; but [she]126-mrs. sparsit had kept [her]126-mrs. sparsit life , and [her]126-mrs. sparsit situation , with an ill - conditioned tenacity that occasioned much offence and disappointment . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s tea was just set for [her]126-mrs. sparsit on a pert little table , with its tripod of legs in an attitude , which [she]126-mrs. sparsit insinuated after office - hours , into the company of the stern , leathern - topped , long board - table that bestrode the middle of [the room]2901-the room . With the usual exception . ’[77-bitzer] [He]77-bitzer held the respectable office of [general spy and informer]1190-general spy and informer in the establishment , for which volunteer service [he]77-bitzer received a present at Christmas , over and above [his]77-bitzer weekly wage . [He]77-bitzer had grown into [an extremely clear - headed , cautious , prudent young man , who was safe to rise in [the world]301-the world]1191-an extremely clear - headed , cautious , prudent young man , who was safe to rise in the world . [His]77-bitzer mind was so exactly regulated , that [he]77-bitzer had no affections or passions . All [his]77-bitzer proceedings were the result of the nicest and coldest calculation ; and it was not without cause that [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit habitually observed of [him]77-bitzer , that [he]77-bitzer was [a young man of the steadiest principle]1193-a young man of the steadiest principle [she]126-mrs. sparsit had ever known . Having satisfied [himself]77-bitzer , on [[his]77-bitzer father]3044-his father ’s death , that [[his]77-bitzer mother]2893-his mother had a right of settlement in [Coketown]4-coketown , [this excellent young economist]1196-this excellent young economist had asserted that right for [her]2893-his mother with such a steadfast adherence to the principle of the case , that [she]2893-his mother had been shut up in [the workhouse]1197-the workhouse ever since . It must be admitted that [he]77-bitzer allowed [her]2893-his mother half a pound of tea a year , which was weak in [him]77-bitzer : first , because all gifts have an inevitable tendency to pauperise [the recipient]1198-the recipient , and secondly , because [his]77-bitzer only reasonable transaction in that commodity would have been to buy it for as little as [he]77-bitzer could possibly give , and sell it for as much as [he]77-bitzer could possibly get ; it having been clearly ascertained by [philosophers]1199-philosophers that in this is comprised the whole duty of [man]2967-man — not a part of [man]2967-man ’s duty , but the whole . ‘ Pretty fair , [ma’am]361-ma’am . [The last party [I]0-i have alluded to]1223-the last party i have alluded to , is to be pitied , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’ said [Bitzer]77-bitzer . ‘[361-ma’am] Yes , [Bitzer]77-bitzer , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit . ‘[77-bitzer] [I]0-i have always pitied the delusion , always . ’ ‘[0-i] As to [an individual]1205-an individual , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’ said [Bitzer]77-bitzer , dropping [his]77-bitzer voice and drawing nearer , ‘[1205-an individual] [he]1205-an individual is as improvident as [any of [the people in [this town]1229-this town]1228-the people in this town]1227-any of the people in this town . But , since [you]361-ma’am do refer to [me]0-i , now look at [me]0-i , [ma’am]361-ma’am . [I]0-i have put by a little , [ma’am]361-ma’am , already . That gratuity which [I]0-i receive at Christmas , [ma’am]361-ma’am : [I]0-i never touch it . [I]0-i do n’t even go the length of [my]0-i wages , though they ’re not high , [ma’am]361-ma’am . Why ca n’t [they]1238-they do as [I]361-ma’am have done , [ma’am]361-ma’am ? What [one person]3667-one person can do , another can do . ’[361-ma’am] This , again , was among the fictions of [Coketown]4-coketown . [Any capitalist there , who had made sixty thousand pounds out of sixpence]1237-any capitalist there , who had made sixty thousand pounds out of sixpence , always professed to wonder why the sixty thousand nearest Hands did n’t each make sixty thousand pounds out of sixpence , and more or less reproached [them]1238-they every one for not accomplishing the little feat . What [I]0-i did [you]361-ma’am can do . Why do n’t [you]361-ma’am go and do it ? ‘ As to [their]1239-they wanting recreations , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’[77-bitzer] said [Bitzer]77-bitzer , ‘ it ’s stuff and nonsense . [I]77-bitzer do n’t want recreations . [I]77-bitzer never did , and [I]77-bitzer never shall ; [I]77-bitzer do n’t like ’em[77-bitzer] . As to [their]1239-they combining together ; there are many of [them]1239-they , [I]0-i have no doubt , that by watching and informing upon [one another]551-one another could earn a trifle now and then , whether in money or good will , and improve [their]1239-they livelihood . Then , why do n’t [they]1239-they improve it , [ma’am]361-ma’am ! [He]3670-the visitor stood whistling to [himself]3670-the visitor with all imaginable coolness , with [his]3670-the visitor hat still on , and a certain air of exhaustion upon [him]3670-the visitor , in part arising from excessive summer , and in part from excessive gentility . [She]126-mrs. sparsit sat at the window , when the sun began to sink behind the smoke ; [she]126-mrs. sparsit sat there , when the smoke was burning red , when the colour faded from it , when darkness seemed to rise slowly out of the ground , and creep upward , upward , up to the [house]3695-house - tops , up [the church steeple]3696-the church steeple , up to the summits of [the factory chimneys]3697-the factory chimneys , up to the sky . Without a candle in [the room]2901-the room , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit sat at the window , with [her]126-mrs. sparsit hands before [her]126-mrs. sparsit , not thinking much of the sounds of evening ; the whooping of [boys]2774-boys , the barking of dogs , the rumbling of wheels , the steps and voices of [passengers]3700-passengers , the shrill street cries , the clogs upon the pavement when it was [their]3701-their hour for going by , the shutting - up of [shop]3702-shop - shutters . Not until [the light porter]1169-the light porter announced that [her]126-mrs. sparsit nocturnal sweetbread was ready , did [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit arouse [herself]126-mrs. sparsit from [her]126-mrs. sparsit reverie , and convey [her]126-mrs. sparsit dense black eyebrows — by that time creased with meditation , as if [they]3704-they needed ironing out - up - [stairs]3306-stairs . ‘[1327-the players] O , [[you]1328-you Fool]1329-you fool ! ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , when [she]126-mrs. sparsit was alone at [her]126-mrs. sparsit supper . Whom [she]126-mrs. sparsit meant , [she]126-mrs. sparsit did not say ; but [she]126-mrs. sparsit could scarcely have meant the sweetbread . [The Gradgrind party]3706-the gradgrind party wanted assistance in cutting the throats of [the Graces]166-the graces . [They]3706-the gradgrind party went about recruiting ; and where could [they]3706-the gradgrind party enlist [recruits]3707-recruits more hopefully , than among [the fine gentlemen who , having found out everything to be worth nothing , were equally ready for anything]3708-the fine gentlemen who , having found out everything to be worth nothing , were equally ready for anything ? Moreover , [the healthy spirits who had mounted to this sublime height]3709-the healthy spirits who had mounted to this sublime height were attractive to [many of [the Gradgrind school]3711-the gradgrind school]3710-many of the gradgrind school . [They]3706-the gradgrind party liked [fine gentlemen]3712-fine gentlemen ; [they]3706-the gradgrind party pretended that [they]3706-the gradgrind party did not , but [they]3706-the gradgrind party did . [They]3706-the gradgrind party became exhausted in imitation of [them]3712-fine gentlemen ; and [they]3706-the gradgrind party yaw - yawed in [their]3706-the gradgrind party speech like [them]3712-fine gentlemen ; and [they]3706-the gradgrind party served out , with an enervated air , the little mouldy rations of political economy , on which [they]3706-the gradgrind party regaled [[their]3706-the gradgrind party disciples]3713-their disciples . There never before was seen on [earth]276-earth [such a wonderful hybrid race as was thus produced]3715-such a wonderful hybrid race as was thus produced . Among [the fine gentlemen not regularly belonging to [the Gradgrind school]3711-the gradgrind school]3716-the fine gentlemen not regularly belonging to the gradgrind school , there was [one of a good family]3718-one of a good family and a better appearance , with a happy turn of humour which had told immensely with [the House of Commons]2985-the house of commons on the occasion of [his]3718-one of a good family entertaining [it]2985-the house of commons with [his]3718-one of a good family ( and [the Board of Directors]3720-the board of directors ) view of a railway accident , in which [the most careful officers ever known]3721-the most careful officers ever known , employed by [the most liberal managers ever heard of , assisted by the finest mechanical contrivances ever devised , the whole in action on the best line ever constructed]3722-the most liberal managers ever heard of , assisted by the finest mechanical contrivances ever devised , the whole in action on the best line ever constructed , had killed [five people and wounded thirty - two]3723-five people and wounded thirty - two , by a casualty without which the excellence of the whole system would have been positively incomplete . Among [the slain]3724-the slain was a cow , and among the scattered articles unowned , [a widow]1282-a widow ’s cap . And [the honourable member]3726-the honourable member had so tickled [the House]2918-the house ( which has a delicate sense of humour ) by putting the cap on the cow , that it became impatient of any serious reference to [the Coroner]3728-the coroner ’s Inquest , and brought [the railway]1277-the railway off with Cheers and Laughter . Now , [this gentleman]277-this gentleman had [a younger brother of still better appearance than [himself]3718-one of a good family , who had tried life as [a Cornet of Dragoons]3732-a cornet of dragoons , and found it a bore ; and had afterwards tried it in the train of [an English minister abroad]3733-an english minister abroad]3731-a younger brother of still better appearance than himself , who had tried life as a cornet of dragoons , and found it a bore ; and had afterwards tried it in the train of an english minister abroad , and found it a bore ; and had then strolled to [Jerusalem]35-jerusalem , and got bored [there]425-there ; and had then gone yachting about [the world]301-the world , and got bored everywhere . To whom [this honourable and jocular , member fraternally]3736-this honourable and jocular , member fraternally said one day , ‘[167-mr. harthouse] [Jem]167-mr. harthouse , there ’s a good opening among [the hard Fact fellows]1330-the hard fact fellows , and [they]1330-the hard fact fellows want [men]545-men . [I]0-i wonder [you]167-mr. harthouse do n’t go in for statistics . ’ [Jem]167-mr. harthouse , rather taken by the novelty of the idea , and very hard up for a change , was as ready to ‘[167-mr. harthouse] go in ’ for statistics as for anything else . So , [he]167-mr. harthouse went in . [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom . ’ Within an hour of the receipt of this dispatch and [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse ’s card , [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby put on [his]93-mr. bounderby hat and went down to [the Hotel]1294-the hotel . There [he]93-mr. bounderby found [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse looking out of window , in a state of mind so disconsolate , that [he]93-mr. bounderby was already half - disposed to ‘[71-tom] go in ’ for something else . ‘[0-i] [My]0-i name , [sir]2771-sir , ’ said [[his]93-mr. bounderby visitor]3743-his visitor , ‘[2771-sir] is [Josiah Bounderby]97-bounderby , of [Coketown]4-coketown . ’ [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse was very happy indeed ( though [he]167-mr. harthouse scarcely looked so ) to have a pleasure [he]167-mr. harthouse had long expected . ‘[97-bounderby] [Coketown]4-coketown , [sir]2771-sir , ’ said [Bounderby]97-bounderby , obstinately taking a chair , ‘[97-bounderby] is not the kind of place [you]2771-sir have been accustomed to . [She]1360-the most remarkable girl mr. james harthouse had ever seen was so constrained , and yet so careless ; so reserved , and yet so watchful ; so cold and proud , and yet so sensitively ashamed of [[her]1360-the most remarkable girl mr. james harthouse had ever seen husband]2903-her husband ’s braggart humility — from which [she]1360-the most remarkable girl mr. james harthouse had ever seen shrunk as if every example of it were a cut or a blow ; that it was quite a new sensation to observe [her]1360-the most remarkable girl mr. james harthouse had ever seen . In face [she]1360-the most remarkable girl mr. james harthouse had ever seen was no less remarkable than in manner . [Her]1360-the most remarkable girl mr. james harthouse had ever seen features were handsome ; but their natural play was so locked up , that it seemed impossible to guess at [their]1355-they genuine expression . Utterly indifferent , perfectly self - reliant , never at a loss , and yet never at [her]1360-the most remarkable girl mr. james harthouse had ever seen ease , with [her]1360-the most remarkable girl mr. james harthouse had ever seen figure in company with [them]1355-they there , and [her]1360-the most remarkable girl mr. james harthouse had ever seen mind apparently quite alone — it was of no use ‘ going in ’[1363-the mistress of the house] yet awhile to comprehend [this girl]435-this girl , for [she]1360-the most remarkable girl mr. james harthouse had ever seen baffled all penetration . From [the mistress of [the house]2918-the house]1363-the mistress of the house , [the visitor]3670-the visitor glanced to [the house itself]1366-the house itself . There was no mute sign of [a woman]3397-a woman in [the room]2901-the room . No graceful little adornment , no fanciful little device , however trivial , anywhere expressed [her]3397-a woman influence . Cheerless and comfortless , boastfully and doggedly rich , there [the room]2901-the room stared at [[its]2901-the room present occupants]1370-its present occupants , unsoftened and unrelieved by the least trace of any womanly occupation . [I]1378-i assure [you]155-mrs. bounderby [I]1378-i attach not the least importance to any opinions . The result of the varieties of boredom [I]1378-i have undergone , is a conviction ( unless conviction is too industrious a word for the lazy sentiment [I]1378-i entertain on the subject ) , that any set of ideas will do just as much good as any other set , and just as much harm as any other set . There ’s [an English family with a charming Italian motto]3772-an english family with a charming italian motto . What will be , will be . It ’s the only truth going ! ’[1378-i] This vicious assumption of honesty in dishonesty — a vice so dangerous , so deadly , and so common — seemed , [he]1378-i observed , a little to impress [her]92-louisa in [his]1378-i favour . [He]1378-i followed up the advantage , by saying in [his]1378-i pleasantest manner : a manner to which [she]92-louisa might attach as much or as little meaning as [she]92-louisa pleased : ‘ The side that can prove anything in a line of units , tens , hundreds , and thousands , [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby , seems to [me]1378-i to afford the most fun , and to give [a man]484-a man the best chance . [I]1378-i am quite as much attached to it as if [I]1378-i believed it . [I]1378-i am quite ready to go in for it , to the same extent as if [I]1378-i believed it . The round of visits was made ; and [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , with a discreet use of [his]167-mr. harthouse blue coaching , came off triumphantly , though with a considerable accession of boredom . In the evening , [he]167-mr. harthouse found the dinner - table laid for four , but [they]1381-they sat down only three . It was an appropriate occasion for [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby to discuss the flavour of the hap’orth of stewed eels [he]93-mr. bounderby had purchased in [the streets]2975-the streets at eight years old ; and also of the inferior water , specially used for laying the dust , with which [he]93-mr. bounderby had washed down that repast . [He]93-mr. bounderby likewise entertained [[his]93-mr. bounderby guest]1383-his guest over the soup and fish , with the calculation that [he]93-mr. bounderby ( [Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby ) had eaten in [his]93-mr. bounderby youth at least three horses under the guise of [polonies and saveloys]1384-polonies and saveloys . These recitals , [Jem]167-mr. harthouse , in a languid manner , received with ‘ charming ! ’[1381-they] every now and then ; and [they]1381-they probably would have decided [him]167-mr. harthouse to ‘ go in ’[1381-they] for [Jerusalem]35-jerusalem again to - morrow morning , had [he]167-mr. harthouse been less curious respecting [Louisa]92-louisa . ‘ Is there nothing , ’[93-mr. bounderby] [he]93-mr. bounderby thought , glancing at [her]92-louisa as [she]92-louisa sat at the head of the table , where [her]92-louisa youthful figure , small and slight , but very graceful , looked as pretty as it looked misplaced ; ‘ is there nothing that will move that face ? ’[92-louisa] Yes ! By [Jupiter]168-jupiter , there was something , and here it was , in an unexpected shape . [Tom]71-tom appeared . [She]92-louisa changed as the door opened , and broke into a beaming smile . A beautiful smile . [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse might not have thought so much of it , but that [he]167-mr. harthouse had wondered so long at [her]92-louisa impassive face . [She]92-louisa put out [her]92-louisa hand — a pretty little soft hand ; and [her]92-louisa fingers closed upon [[her]92-louisa brother]2932-her brother ’s , as if [she]92-louisa would have carried them to [her]92-louisa lips . ‘ Ay , ay ? ’[3670-the visitor] thought [the visitor]3670-the visitor . ‘ [This whelp]3778-this whelp is the only creature [she]92-louisa cares for . [Tom]71-tom , love , [I]1388-her am telling [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse that [he]3779-your brother never saw [you]71-tom abroad . ’[1388-her] ‘ No such luck , [sir]2771-sir , ’[71-tom] said [Tom]71-tom . There was little enough in [him]71-tom to brighten [her]1388-her face , for [he]71-tom was [a sullen young fellow]1389-a sullen young fellow , and ungracious in [his]71-tom manner even to [her]1388-her . So much the greater must have been the solitude of [her]1388-her heart , and [her]1388-her need of [some one on whom to bestow it]1390-some one on whom to bestow it . ‘ So much the more is [this whelp]3778-this whelp [the only creature [she]1388-her has ever cared for]3785-the only creature she has ever cared for , ’[167-mr. harthouse] thought [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , turning it over and over . ‘ So much the more . So much the more . ’[167-mr. harthouse] Both in [[his]167-mr. harthouse sister]716-his sister ’s presence , and after [she]1388-her had left [the room]2901-the room , [the whelp]1387-the whelp took no pains to hide [his]1387-the whelp contempt for [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , whenever [he]1387-the whelp could indulge it without the observation of [that independent man]1394-that independent man , by making wry faces , or shutting one eye . Without responding to these telegraphic communications , [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse encouraged [him]1387-the whelp much in the course of the evening , and showed an unusual liking for [him]1387-the whelp . At last , when [he]1387-the whelp rose to return to [[his]1387-the whelp hotel]1395-his hotel , and was a little doubtful whether [he]1387-the whelp knew the way by night , [the whelp]1387-the whelp immediately proffered [his]1387-the whelp services as [guide]1397-guide , and turned out with [him]1387-the whelp to escort [him]1387-the whelp thither .

It was very remarkable that [a young gentleman who had been brought up under one continuous system of unnatural restraint]1398-a young gentleman who had been brought up under one continuous system of unnatural restraint , should be [a hypocrite]1399-a hypocrite ; but it was certainly the case with [Tom]71-tom . It was very strange that [a young gentleman who had never been left to [his]1400-a young gentleman who had never been left to his own guidance for five consecutive minutes , should be incapable at last of governing himself own guidance for five consecutive minutes , should be incapable at last of governing [himself]1400-a young gentleman who had never been left to his own guidance for five consecutive minutes , should be incapable at last of governing himself]1400-a young gentleman who had never been left to his own guidance for five consecutive minutes , should be incapable at last of governing himself ; but so it was with [Tom]71-tom . It was altogether unaccountable that [a young gentleman whose imagination had been strangled]1401-a young gentleman whose imagination had been strangled in [his]1400-a young gentleman who had never been left to his own guidance for five consecutive minutes , should be incapable at last of governing himself cradle , should be still inconvenienced by its ghost in the form of grovelling sensualities ; but [such a monster]1402-such a monster , beyond all doubt , was [Tom]71-tom . ‘ Do [you]71-tom smoke ? ’[167-mr. harthouse] asked [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , when [they]1403-they came to [the hotel]1294-the hotel . ‘ [I]71-tom believe [you]167-mr. harthouse ! ’[71-tom] said [Tom]71-tom . [He]71-tom could do no less than ask [Tom]71-tom up ; and [Tom]71-tom could do no less than go up . What with a cooling drink adapted to the weather , but not so weak as cool ; and what with a rarer tobacco than was to be bought in those parts ; [Tom]71-tom was soon in a highly free and easy state at [his]71-tom end of the sofa , and more than ever disposed to admire [[his]71-tom new friend]1405-his new friend at the other end . [Tom]71-tom blew [his]71-tom smoke aside , after [he]71-tom had been smoking a little while , and took an observation of [[his]71-tom friend]2921-his friend . ‘ [He]2921-his friend do n’t seem to care about [his]2921-his friend dress , ’[71-tom] thought [Tom]71-tom , ‘ and yet how capitally [he]2921-his friend does it . What [an easy swell]3786-an easy swell [he]2921-his friend is ! ’[71-tom] [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , happening to catch [Tom]71-tom ’s eye , remarked that [he]167-mr. harthouse drank nothing , and filled [his]167-mr. harthouse glass with [his]167-mr. harthouse own negligent hand . ‘ [Thank’ee]169-thank’ee , ’[71-tom] said [Tom]71-tom . ‘ [Thank’ee]169-thank’ee . Well , [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , [I]71-tom hope [you]167-mr. harthouse have had about a dose of [old Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby to - night . ’[71-tom] [Tom]71-tom said this with one eye shut up again , and looking over [his]71-tom glass knowingly , at [[his]167-mr. harthouse entertainer]1407-his entertainer . ‘ [A very good fellow]3787-a very good fellow indeed ! ’[71-tom] returned [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse . ‘ [You]167-mr. harthouse think so , do n’t [you]167-mr. harthouse ? ’[71-tom] said [Tom]71-tom . And shut up [his]71-tom eye again . [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse smiled ; and rising from [his]167-mr. harthouse end of the sofa , and lounging with [his]167-mr. harthouse back against the chimney - piece , so that [he]167-mr. harthouse stood before the empty fire - grate as [he]167-mr. harthouse smoked , in front of [Tom]71-tom and looking down at [him]71-tom , observed : ‘ What [a comical brother - in - law]3788-a comical brother - in - law [you]71-tom are ! ’[167-mr. harthouse] ‘ What [a comical brother - in - law old Bounderby]3789-a comical brother - in - law old bounderby is , [I]71-tom think [you]167-mr. harthouse mean , ’[71-tom] said [Tom]71-tom . ‘ [You]71-tom are a piece of caustic , [Tom]71-tom , ’[71-tom] retorted [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse . There was something so very agreeable in being so intimate with such a waistcoat ; in being called [Tom]71-tom , in such an intimate way , by such a voice ; in being on such off - hand terms so soon , with such a pair of whiskers ; that [Tom]71-tom was uncommonly pleased with [himself]71-tom . ‘ Oh ! [I]71-tom do n’t care for [old Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ’[71-tom] said [he]71-tom , ‘ if [you]167-mr. harthouse mean that . [I]71-tom have always called [old Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby by the same name when [I]71-tom have talked about [him]93-mr. bounderby , and [I]71-tom have always thought of [him]93-mr. bounderby in the same way . [I]71-tom am not going to begin to be polite now , about [old Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . It would be rather late in the day . ’[71-tom] ‘ Do n’t mind [me]167-mr. harthouse , ’[167-mr. harthouse] returned [James]167-mr. harthouse ; ‘ but take care when [[his]93-mr. bounderby wife]3471-his wife is by , [you]71-tom know . ’[167-mr. harthouse] ‘ [[His]93-mr. bounderby wife]3471-his wife ? ’[71-tom] said [Tom]71-tom . ‘ [[My]71-tom sister]738-my sister [Loo]101-loo ? O yes ! ’[71-tom] And [he]167-mr. harthouse laughed , and took a little more of the cooling drink . [James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse continued to lounge in [the same place]1408-the same place and attitude , smoking [his]167-mr. harthouse cigar in [his]167-mr. harthouse own easy way , and looking pleasantly at the whelp , as if [he]167-mr. harthouse knew [himself]167-mr. harthouse to be a kind of agreeable demon who had only to hover over [him]167-mr. harthouse , and [he]167-mr. harthouse must give up [his]167-mr. harthouse whole soul if required . It certainly did seem that [the whelp yielded to this influence]1409-the whelp yielded to this influence . [He]167-mr. harthouse looked at [[his]167-mr. harthouse companion]1410-his companion sneakingly , [he]167-mr. harthouse looked at [him]1410-his companion admiringly , [he]167-mr. harthouse looked at [him]1410-his companion boldly , and put up one leg on the sofa . ‘ [[My]71-tom sister]738-my sister [Loo]101-loo ? ’[71-tom] said [Tom]71-tom . ‘ [She]738-my sister never cared for [old Bounderby]101-loo . ’[71-tom] ‘ That ’s the past tense , [Tom]71-tom , ’[167-mr. harthouse] returned [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , striking the ash from [his]167-mr. harthouse cigar with [his]167-mr. harthouse little finger . ‘ [We]3794-we are in the present tense , now . ’[167-mr. harthouse] ‘ Verb neuter , not to care . Indicative mood , present tense . First person singular , [I]71-tom do not care ; [second person singular]3795-second person singular , [thou]3796-thou dost not care ; [third person singular]3797-third person singular , [she]738-my sister does not care , ’[71-tom] returned [Tom]71-tom . ‘ Good !
