Good - bye ! ’ It was but a hurried parting in [a common street]4085-a common street , yet it was a sacred remembrance to [these two common people]4086-these two common people . [Utilitarian economists]4087-utilitarian economists , [skeletons of [schoolmasters]4089-schoolmasters]4088-skeletons of schoolmasters , [Commissioners of Fact]2826-commissioners of fact , [genteel and used - up infidels]4091-genteel and used - up infidels , [gabblers of many little dog’s - eared creeds]4092-gabblers of many little dog’s - eared creeds , the poor [you]4093-you will have always with [you]4093-you . Cultivate in [them]4086-these two common people , while there is yet time , the utmost graces of the fancies and affections , to adorn [their]4086-these two common people lives so much in need of ornament ; or , in the day of [your]4093-you triumph , when romance is utterly driven out of [their]4086-these two common people souls , and [they]4086-these two common people and a bare existence stand face to face , Reality will take a wolfish turn , and make an end of [you]4093-you . [Stephen]144-stephen worked the next day , and the next , uncheered by a word from [any one]495-any one , and shunned in all [his]144-stephen comings and goings as before . At the end of the second day , [he]144-stephen saw [land]4095-land ; at the end of the third , [his]144-stephen loom stood empty . [He]144-stephen had overstayed [his]144-stephen hour in [the street]461-the street outside [the Bank]3524-the bank , on each of the two first evenings ; and nothing had happened there , good or bad . That [he]144-stephen might not be remiss in [his]144-stephen part of the engagement , [he]144-stephen resolved to wait full two hours , on this third and last night . There was [the lady who had once kept [[Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s house]1160-mr. bounderby ’s house]4098-the lady who had once kept mr. bounderby ’s house , sitting at the first - floor window as [he]144-stephen had seen [her]4098-the lady who had once kept mr. bounderby ’s house before ; and there was [the light porter]1169-the light porter , sometimes talking with [her]4098-the lady who had once kept mr. bounderby ’s house [there]425-there , and sometimes looking over the blind below which had Bank upon [it]425-there , and sometimes coming to the door and standing on the steps for a breath of air . When [he]144-stephen first came out , [Stephen]144-stephen thought [he]144-stephen might be looking for [him]144-stephen , and passed near ; but [the light porter]1169-the light porter only cast [his]1169-the light porter winking eyes upon [him]144-stephen slightly , and said nothing . Two hours were a long stretch of lounging about , after a long day ’s labour . [Stephen]144-stephen sat upon the step of a door , leaned against a wall under an archway , strolled up and down , listened for the church clock , stopped and watched [children]2848-children playing in [the street]461-the street . Some purpose or other is so natural to [every one]4105-every one , that [a mere loiterer]4106-a mere loiterer always looks and feels remarkable . When the first hour was out , [Stephen]144-stephen even began to have an uncomfortable sensation upon [him]144-stephen of being for the time a disreputable character . Then came the lamplighter , and two lengthening lines of light all down the long perspective of [the street]461-the street , until they were blended and lost in the distance . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit closed the first - floor window , drew down the blind , and went up - [stairs]3306-stairs . Presently , a light went up - stairs after [her]126-mrs. sparsit , passing first the fanlight of the door , and afterwards the two staircase windows , on its way up . By and by , one corner of [the second - floor blind]4109-the second - floor blind was disturbed , as if [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s eye were there ; also the other corner , as if [the light porter]1169-the light porter ’s eye were on that side . Still , no communication was made to [Stephen]144-stephen . Much relieved when the two hours were at last accomplished , [he]144-stephen went away at a quick pace , as a recompense for so much loitering . [He]144-stephen had only to take leave of [[his]144-stephen landlady]4039-his landlady , and lie down on [his]144-stephen temporary bed upon the floor ; for [his]144-stephen bundle was made up for to - morrow , and all was arranged for [his]144-stephen departure . [He]144-stephen meant to be clear of [the town]2838-the town very early ; before the Hands were in [the streets]2975-the streets . It was barely daybreak , when , with a parting look round [[his]144-stephen room]945-his room , mournfully wondering whether [he]144-stephen should ever see it again , [he]144-stephen went out . [The town]2838-the town was as entirely deserted as if [the inhabitants]4116-the inhabitants had abandoned [it]2838-the town , rather than hold communication with [him]144-stephen . Everything looked wan at that hour . Even the coming sun made but a pale waste in the sky , like a sad sea . By [the place where [Rachael]146-rachael lived , though it was not in [his]144-stephen way]4117-the place where rachael lived , though it was not in his way ; by [the red brick streets]4118-the red brick streets ; by [the great silent factories]4119-the great silent factories , not trembling yet ; by [the railway]1277-the railway , where the danger - lights were waning in the strengthening day ; by [the railway ’s crazy neighbourhood]4121-the railway ’s crazy neighbourhood , half pulled down and half built up ; by [scattered red brick villas]4122-scattered red brick villas , where the besmoked evergreens were sprinkled with a dirty powder , like [untidy snuff - takers]4123-untidy snuff - takers ; by coal - dust paths and many varieties of ugliness ; [Stephen]144-stephen got to [the top of [the hill]4125-the hill]4124-the top of the hill , and looked back . Day was shining radiantly upon [the town]2838-the town then , and the bells were going for the morning work . Domestic fires were not yet lighted , and the high chimneys had the sky to themselves . Puffing out their poisonous volumes , [they]4116-the inhabitants would not be long in hiding it ; but , for half an hour , some of the many windows were golden , which showed [the Coketown people]4127-the coketown people a sun eternally in eclipse , through a medium of smoked glass . So strange to turn from the chimneys to the birds . So strange , to have the road - dust on [his]144-stephen feet instead of the coal - grit . So strange to have lived to [his]144-stephen time of life , and yet to be beginning like [a boy this summer morning]4128-a boy this summer morning ! With these musings in [his]144-stephen mind , and [his]144-stephen bundle under [his]144-stephen arm , [Stephen]144-stephen took [his]144-stephen attentive face along [the high road]4129-the high road . And the trees arched over [him]144-stephen , whispering that [he]144-stephen left a true and loving heart behind . [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , ‘[0-i] going in ’ for [[his]167-mr. harthouse adopted party]4130-his adopted party , soon began to score . With the aid of a little more coaching for [the political sages]4131-the political sages , a little more genteel listlessness for the general society , and a tolerable management of the assumed honesty in dishonesty , most effective and most patronized of the polite deadly sins , [he]167-mr. harthouse speedily came to be considered of much promise . The not being troubled with earnestness was a grand point in [his]167-mr. harthouse favour , enabling [him]167-mr. harthouse to take to the hard Fact fellows with as good a grace as if [he]167-mr. harthouse had been born [one of [the tribe]4133-the tribe]4132-one of the tribe , and to throw [all other tribes]4134-all other tribes overboard , as [conscious hypocrites]4135-conscious hypocrites . ‘[0-i] Whom none of [us]1667-us believe , [[my]0-i dear]601-my dear [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby , and who do not believe [themselves]1669-themselves . The only difference between [us]1667-us and [the professors of virtue or benevolence , or philanthropy]1670-the professors of virtue or benevolence , or philanthropy — never mind the name — is , that [we]1667-us know it is all meaningless , and say so ; while [they]1670-the professors of virtue or benevolence , or philanthropy know it equally and will never say so . ’ Why should [she]155-mrs. bounderby be shocked or warned by this reiteration ? It was not so unlike [[her]155-mrs. bounderby father]2855-her father ’s principles , and [her]155-mrs. bounderby early training , that it need startle [her]155-mrs. bounderby . Where was the great difference between the two schools , when [each]2857-each chained [her]155-mrs. bounderby down to material realities , and inspired [her]155-mrs. bounderby with no faith in anything else ? What was there in [her]155-mrs. bounderby soul for [James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse to destroy , which [Thomas Gradgrind]71-tom had nurtured there in its state of innocence ! It was even the worse for [her]155-mrs. bounderby at this pass , that in [her]155-mrs. bounderby mind — implanted there before [[her]155-mrs. bounderby eminently practical father]4138-her eminently practical father began to form it — a struggling disposition to believe in a wider and nobler humanity than [she]155-mrs. bounderby had ever heard of , constantly strove with doubts and resentments . With doubts , because the aspiration had been so laid waste in [her]155-mrs. bounderby youth . With resentments , because of the wrong that had been done [her]155-mrs. bounderby , if it were indeed a whisper of the truth . Upon [a nature long accustomed to self - suppression , thus torn and divided , the Harthouse]4139-a nature long accustomed to self - suppression , thus torn and divided , the harthouse philosophy came as a relief and justification . Everything being hollow and worthless , [she]155-mrs. bounderby had missed nothing and sacrificed nothing . What did it matter , [she]155-mrs. bounderby had said to [[her]155-mrs. bounderby father]2855-her father , when [he]2855-her father proposed [[her]155-mrs. bounderby husband]2903-her husband . What did it matter , [she]155-mrs. bounderby said still . With a scornful self - reliance , [she]155-mrs. bounderby asked [herself]155-mrs. bounderby , What did anything matter — and went on . Towards what ? Step by step , onward and downward , towards some end , yet so gradually , that [she]155-mrs. bounderby believed [herself]155-mrs. bounderby to remain motionless . As to [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , whither [he]167-mr. harthouse tended , [he]167-mr. harthouse neither considered nor cared . [He]167-mr. harthouse had no particular design or plan before [him]167-mr. harthouse : no energetic wickedness ruffled [his]167-mr. harthouse lassitude . [He]167-mr. harthouse was as much amused and interested , at present , as it became so fine [a gentleman]1259-a gentleman to be ; perhaps even more than it would have been consistent with [his]167-mr. harthouse reputation to confess . Soon after [his]167-mr. harthouse arrival [he]167-mr. harthouse languidly wrote to [[his]167-mr. harthouse brother]3737-his brother , [the honourable and jocular member]4144-the honourable and jocular member , that [the Bounderbys]185-the bounderbys were ‘[93-mr. bounderby] great fun ; ’ and further , that [the female Bounderby]4145-the female bounderby , instead of being the Gorgon [he]167-mr. harthouse had expected , was young , and remarkably pretty . After that , [he]167-mr. harthouse wrote no more about [them]4146-their , and devoted [his]167-mr. harthouse leisure chiefly to [[their]4146-their house]4147-their house . [He]167-mr. harthouse was very often in [[their]4146-their house]4147-their house , in [his]167-mr. harthouse flittings and visitings about [the Coketown district]4149-the coketown district ; and was much encouraged by [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . It was quite in [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s gusty way to boast to all [[his]167-mr. harthouse world]4150-his world that [he]167-mr. harthouse did n’t care about [[your]4151-your highly connected people]4152-your highly connected people , but that if [[his]167-mr. harthouse wife]3471-his wife [[Tom Gradgrind]71-tom ’s daughter]1058-tom gradgrind ’s daughter did , [she]1058-tom gradgrind ’s daughter was welcome to [their]4146-their company . [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse began to think it would be a new sensation , if the face which changed so beautifully for the whelp , would change for [him]167-mr. harthouse . [He]167-mr. harthouse was quick enough to observe ; [he]167-mr. harthouse had a good memory , and did not forget a word of [the brother]4155-the brother ’s revelations . [He]167-mr. harthouse interwove them with everything [he]167-mr. harthouse saw of [the sister]4156-the sister , and [he]167-mr. harthouse began to understand [her]4156-the sister . To be sure , the better and profounder part of [her]4156-the sister character was not within [his]167-mr. harthouse scope of perception ; for in natures , as in [seas]4157-seas , depth answers unto depth ; but [he]167-mr. harthouse soon began to read the rest with [a student]4158-a student ’s eye . [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby had taken possession of [a house and grounds]4159-a house and grounds , about fifteen miles from [the town]2838-the town , and accessible within a mile or two , by a railway striding on many arches over [a wild country]4161-a wild country , undermined by [deserted coal - shafts]4162-deserted coal - shafts , and spotted at night by fires and black shapes of stationary engines at pits ’[93-mr. bounderby] mouths . [This country]1671-this country , gradually softening towards [the neighbourhood of [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s retreat]1672-the neighbourhood of mr. bounderby ’s retreat , there mellowed into [a rustic landscape , golden with heath , and snowy with hawthorn]1673-a rustic landscape , golden with heath , and snowy with hawthorn in the spring of the year , and tremulous with leaves and their shadows all the summer time . [The bank]3524-the bank had foreclosed a mortgage effected on [the property thus pleasantly situated]1675-the property thus pleasantly situated , by [one of [the Coketown magnates , who , in [his]1676-one of the coketown magnates , who , in his determination to make a shorter cut than usual to an enormous fortune , overspeculated himself by about two hundred thousand pounds . these accidents did sometimes happen in the best regulated families of coketown determination to make a shorter cut than usual to an enormous fortune]1677-the coketown magnates , who , in his determination to make a shorter cut than usual to an enormous fortune , overspeculated [himself]1676-one of the coketown magnates , who , in his determination to make a shorter cut than usual to an enormous fortune , overspeculated himself by about two hundred thousand pounds . these accidents did sometimes happen in the best regulated families of coketown by about two hundred thousand pounds . These accidents did sometimes happen in [the best regulated families of [Coketown]4-coketown]1678-the best regulated families of coketown]1676-one of the coketown magnates , who , in his determination to make a shorter cut than usual to an enormous fortune , overspeculated himself by about two hundred thousand pounds . these accidents did sometimes happen in the best regulated families of coketown , but [the bankrupts]1679-the bankrupts had no connexion whatever with [the improvident classes]1680-the improvident classes . It afforded [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby supreme satisfaction to instal [himself]93-mr. bounderby in [this snug little estate]1681-this snug little estate , and with demonstrative humility to grow cabbages in [the flower - garden]1682-the flower - garden . [He]93-mr. bounderby delighted to live , barrack - fashion , among the elegant furniture , and [he]93-mr. bounderby bullied the very pictures with [his]93-mr. bounderby origin . ‘ Why , [sir]2771-sir , ’[93-mr. bounderby] [he]93-mr. bounderby would say to [a visitor]1683-a visitor , ‘ [I]93-mr. bounderby am told that [Nickits]186-nickits , ’[93-mr. bounderby] [the late owner]1684-the late owner , ‘ gave seven hundred pound for [that Seabeach]4164-that seabeach . Now , to be plain with [you]4165-you , if [I]1684-the late owner ever , in the whole course of [my]1684-the late owner life , take seven looks at it , at a hundred pound a look , it will be as much as [I]1684-the late owner shall do . No , by [George]72-george ! [I]1684-the late owner do n’t forget that [I]1684-the late owner am [Josiah Bounderby]97-bounderby of [Coketown]4-coketown . For years upon years , the only pictures in [my]1684-the late owner possession , or that [I]1684-the late owner could have got into [my]1684-the late owner possession , by any means , unless [I]1684-the late owner stole ’em[1684-the late owner] , were the engravings of [a man]484-a man shaving [himself]484-a man in a boot , on the blacking bottles that [I]0-i was overjoyed to use in cleaning boots with , and that [I]0-i sold when they were empty for a farthing a - piece , and glad to get it ! ’ Then [he]0-i would address [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse in the same style . ‘[167-mr. harthouse] [Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , [you]167-mr. harthouse have a couple of horses down here . Bring half a dozen more if [you]167-mr. harthouse like , and [we]1686-we ’ll find room for [’em]4166-’em . There ’s stabling in [this place]729-this place for a dozen horses ; and unless [Nickits]186-nickits is belied , [he]186-nickits kept the full number . A round dozen of ’em[167-mr. harthouse] , [sir]2771-sir . When [that man]523-that man was [a boy]728-a boy , [he]523-that man went to [Westminster School]1690-westminster school . Went to [Westminster School]1690-westminster school as [[a King]3465-a king ’s Scholar]1693-a king ’s scholar , when [I]0-i was principally living on garbage , and sleeping in market baskets . Why , if [I]0-i wanted to keep a dozen horses — which [I]0-i do n’t , for one ’s enough for [me]0-i — [I]0-i could n’t bear to see ’em in [[their]4166-’em stalls here]4168-their stalls here , and think what [[my]2771-sir own lodging]4169-my own lodging used to be . [I]2771-sir could n’t look at ’em[2771-sir] , [sir]2771-sir , and not order ’em out . Yet so things come round . [You]4170-you see [this place]729-this place ; [you]4170-you know what sort of a place [it]729-this place is ; [you]4170-you are aware that there ’s not [a completer place of [its]729-this place size in [this kingdom]4173-this kingdom]4172-a completer place of its size in this kingdom or elsewhere — [I]0-i do n’t care where — and [here]366-here , got into the middle of [it]729-this place , like a maggot into a nut , is [Josiah Bounderby]97-bounderby . While [Nickits]186-nickits ( as [a man]484-a man came into [[my]0-i office]3153-my office , and told [me]0-i yesterday ) , [Nickits]186-nickits , who used to act in Latin , in the Westminster School plays , with [the chief - justices and nobility of [this country]1671-this country]4177-the chief - justices and nobility of this country applauding [him]186-nickits till [they]4177-the chief - justices and nobility of this country were black in the face , is drivelling at this minute — drivelling , [sir]2771-sir ! — in [a fifth floor]4180-a fifth floor , up [a narrow dark back street in [Antwerp]41-antwerp]4181-a narrow dark back street in antwerp . ’[0-i] It was among the leafy shadows of [this retirement]1695-this retirement , in the long sultry summer days , that [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse began to prove the face which had set [him]167-mr. harthouse wondering when [he]167-mr. harthouse first saw it , and to try if it would change for [him]167-mr. harthouse . ‘ [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby , [I]167-mr. harthouse esteem it a most fortunate accident that [I]167-mr. harthouse find [you]155-mrs. bounderby alone [here]366-here . [I]167-mr. harthouse have for some time had a particular wish to speak to [you]155-mrs. bounderby . ’[167-mr. harthouse] It was not by any wonderful accident that [he]167-mr. harthouse found [her]1696-i , the time of day being that at which [she]1696-i was always alone , and [the place]2849-the place being [[her]1696-i favourite resort]1698-her favourite resort . It was an opening in [a dark wood]1699-a dark wood , where some felled trees lay , and where [she]1696-i would sit watching the fallen leaves of last year , as [she]1696-i had watched the falling ashes at [home]2856-home . [He]167-mr. harthouse sat down beside [her]1696-i , with a glance at [her]1696-i face . ‘ [[Your]155-mrs. bounderby brother]3779-your brother . [[My]167-mr. harthouse young friend]4184-my young friend [Tom]71-tom — ’[167-mr. harthouse] [Her]1696-i colour brightened , and [she]1696-i turned to [him]167-mr. harthouse with a look of interest . ‘ [I]167-mr. harthouse never in [my]167-mr. harthouse life , ’[167-mr. harthouse] [he]167-mr. harthouse thought , ‘ saw anything so remarkable and so captivating as the lighting of those features ! ’[167-mr. harthouse] [His]167-mr. harthouse face betrayed [his]167-mr. harthouse thoughts — perhaps without betraying [him]167-mr. harthouse , for it might have been according to [its]1701-its instructions so to do . ‘ Pardon [me]1696-i . The expression of [your]155-mrs. bounderby sisterly interest is so beautiful — [Tom]71-tom should be so proud of it — [I]1696-i know this is inexcusable , but [I]1696-i am so compelled to admire . ’[1696-i] ‘ Being so impulsive , ’[1696-i] [she]1696-i said composedly . ‘ [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby , no : [you]167-mr. harthouse know [I]1696-i make no pretence with [you]167-mr. harthouse . [You]167-mr. harthouse know [I]1696-i am [a sordid piece of human nature]4185-a sordid piece of human nature , ready to sell [myself]1696-i at any time for any reasonable sum , and altogether incapable of any Arcadian proceeding whatever . ’[1696-i] ‘ [I]1696-i am waiting , ’[1696-i] [she]1696-i returned , ‘ for [your]167-mr. harthouse further reference to [[my]1696-i brother]1334-my brother . ’[1696-i] ‘ [You]167-mr. harthouse are rigid with [me]1696-i , and [I]1696-i deserve it . [I]1696-i am as worthless a dog as [you]167-mr. harthouse will find , except that [I]1696-i am not false — not false . But [you]167-mr. harthouse surprised and started [me]1696-i from [my]1696-i subject , which was [[your]167-mr. harthouse brother]3779-your brother . [I]1696-i have an interest in [him]3779-your brother . ’[1696-i] ‘ Have [you]167-mr. harthouse an interest in anything , [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse ? ’[1696-i] [she]1696-i asked , half incredulously and half gratefully . ‘ If [you]167-mr. harthouse had asked [me]1696-i when [I]1696-i first came [here]366-here , [I]1696-i should have said no . [I]1696-i must say now — even at the hazard of appearing to make a pretence , and of justly awakening [your]167-mr. harthouse incredulity — yes . ’[1696-i] [She]1696-i made a slight movement , as if [she]1696-i were trying to speak , but could not find voice ; at length [she]1696-i said , ‘ [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , [I]1696-i give [you]167-mr. harthouse credit for being interested in [[my]1696-i brother]1334-my brother . ’[1696-i] ‘ Thank [you]167-mr. harthouse . [I]1702-i claim to deserve it . [You]167-mr. harthouse know how little [I]1702-i do claim , but [I]1702-i will go that length . [You]167-mr. harthouse have done so much for [him]1334-my brother , [you]167-mr. harthouse are so fond of [him]1334-my brother ; [your]167-mr. harthouse whole life , [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby , expresses such charming self - forgetfulness on [his]1334-my brother account — pardon [me]1702-i again — [I]1702-i am running wide of the subject . [I]1702-i am interested in [him]1334-my brother for [his]1334-my brother own sake . ’[1702-i] [She]1702-i had made the slightest action possible , as if [she]1702-i would have risen in a hurry and gone away . [He]1703-he had turned the course of what [he]1703-he said at that instant , and [she]1702-i remained . ‘ [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby , ’[1703-he] [he]1703-he resumed , in a lighter manner , and yet with a show of effort in assuming it , which was even more expressive than the manner [he]1703-he dismissed ; ‘ it is no irrevocable offence in [a young fellow of [[your]155-mrs. bounderby brother]3779-your brother ’s years]4190-a young fellow of your brother ’s years , if [he]1334-my brother is heedless , inconsiderate , and expensive — a little dissipated , in the common phrase . Is [he]1334-my brother ? ’[1703-he] ‘ Yes . ’[1702-i] ‘ Allow [me]1702-i to be frank . Do [you]1703-he think [he]1334-my brother games at all ? ’[1702-i] ‘ [I]1702-i think [he]1334-my brother makes bets . ’[1702-i] [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse waiting , as if that were not [her]1702-i whole answer , [she]1702-i added , ‘ [I]1702-i know [he]1334-my brother does . ’[1702-i] ‘ Of course [he]1334-my brother loses ? ’[1702-i] ‘ Yes . ’[1702-i] ‘ [Everybody]404-everybody does lose who bets . May [I]1702-i hint at the probability of [your]1703-he sometimes supplying [him]1334-my brother with money for these purposes ? ’[1702-i] [She]1702-i sat , looking down ; but , at this question , raised [her]1702-i eyes searchingly and a little resentfully . ‘ Acquit [me]1702-i of impertinent curiosity , [[my]1702-i dear]601-my dear [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby . [I]1702-i think [Tom]71-tom may be gradually falling into trouble , and [I]1702-i wish to stretch out a helping hand to [him]71-tom from the depths of [my]1702-i wicked experience . — Shall [I]1702-i say again , for [his]71-tom sake ? Is that necessary ? ’[1702-i] [She]1702-i seemed to try to answer , but nothing came of it . ‘ Candidly to confess everything that has occurred to [me]167-mr. harthouse , ’[167-mr. harthouse] said [James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , again gliding with the same appearance of effort into [his]167-mr. harthouse more airy manner ; ‘ [I]167-mr. harthouse will confide to [you]1702-i [my]167-mr. harthouse doubt whether [he]71-tom has had many advantages . Whether — forgive [my]167-mr. harthouse plainness — whether any great amount of confidence is likely to have been established between [himself]71-tom and [[his]71-tom most worthy father]4194-his most worthy father . ’[167-mr. harthouse] ‘ [I]92-louisa do not , ’[92-louisa] said [Louisa]92-louisa , flushing with [her]92-louisa own great remembrance in that wise , ‘ think it likely . ’[92-louisa] ‘ Or , between [himself]71-tom , and — [I]92-louisa may trust to [your]1702-i perfect understanding of [my]92-louisa meaning , [I]92-louisa am sure — and [[his]71-tom highly esteemed brother - in - law]4195-his highly esteemed brother - in - law . ’[92-louisa] [She]92-louisa flushed deeper and deeper , and was burning red when [she]92-louisa replied in a fainter voice , ‘ [I]92-louisa do not think that likely , either . ’[92-louisa] ‘ [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby , ’[167-mr. harthouse] said [Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , after a short silence , ‘ may there be a better confidence between [yourself]92-louisa and [me]167-mr. harthouse ? [Tom]71-tom has borrowed a considerable sum of [you]92-louisa ? ’[167-mr. harthouse] ‘ [You]167-mr. harthouse will understand , [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , ’[92-louisa] [she]92-louisa returned , after some indecision : [she]92-louisa had been more or less uncertain , and troubled throughout the conversation , and yet had in the main preserved [her]92-louisa self - contained manner ; ‘ [you]167-mr. harthouse will understand that if [I]92-louisa tell [you]167-mr. harthouse what [you]167-mr. harthouse press to know , it is not by way of complaint or regret . [I]92-louisa would never complain of anything , and what [I]92-louisa have done [I]92-louisa do not in the least regret . ’[92-louisa] ‘ So spirited , too ! ’[167-mr. harthouse] thought [James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse . ‘ When [I]1704-you married , [I]1704-you found that [[my]1704-you brother]1334-my brother was even at that time heavily in debt . Heavily for [him]1334-my brother , [I]1704-you mean . Heavily enough to oblige [me]1704-you to sell some trinkets . They were no sacrifice . [I]1704-you sold them very willingly . [I]1704-you attached no value to [them]4197-them . [They]4197-them , were quite worthless to [me]1704-you . ’[1704-you] Either [she]1704-you saw in [his]167-mr. harthouse face that [he]167-mr. harthouse knew , or [she]1704-you only feared in [her]1704-you conscience that [he]167-mr. harthouse knew , that [she]1704-you spoke of some of [[her]1704-you husband]2903-her husband ’s gifts . [She]1704-you stopped , and reddened again . If [he]167-mr. harthouse had not known it before , [he]167-mr. harthouse would have known it then , though [he]167-mr. harthouse had been [a much duller man]1706-a much duller man than [he]167-mr. harthouse was . ‘ Since then , [I]1707-i have given [[my]1707-i brother]1334-my brother , at various times , what money [I]1707-i could spare : in short , what money [I]1707-i have had . Confiding in [you]1704-you at all , on the faith of the interest [you]1704-you profess for [him]1334-my brother , [I]1707-i will not do so by halves . Since [you]1704-you have been in the habit of visiting [here]366-here , [he]1334-my brother has wanted in one sum as much as a hundred pounds . [I]1707-i have not been able to give it to [him]1334-my brother . [I]1707-i have felt uneasy for the consequences of [his]1334-my brother being so involved , but [I]1707-i have kept these secrets until now , when [I]1707-i trust them to [your]1704-you honour . [I]1707-i have held no confidence with [any one]495-any one , because — [you]1704-you anticipated [my]1707-i reason just now . ’[1707-i] [She]1707-i abruptly broke off . [He]1708-he was [a ready man]1709-a ready man , and [he]1708-he saw , and seized , an opportunity here of presenting [her]1707-i own image to [her]1707-i , slightly disguised as [[her]1707-i brother]2932-her brother . ‘ [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby , though [a graceless person]4201-a graceless person , of [the world worldly]4202-the world worldly , [I]1711-i feel the utmost interest , [I]1711-i assure [you]1704-you , in what [you]1704-you tell [me]1711-i . [I]1711-i can not possibly be hard upon [[your]1704-you brother]3779-your brother . [I]1711-i understand and share the wise consideration with which [you]1704-you regard [his]3779-your brother errors . With all possible respect both for [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom and for [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , [I]1711-i think [I]1711-i perceive that [he]3779-your brother has not been fortunate in [his]3779-your brother training . Bred at a disadvantage towards the society in which [he]3779-your brother has [his]3779-your brother part to play , [he]3779-your brother rushes into these extremes for [himself]3779-your brother , from opposite extremes that have long been forced — with the very best intentions [we]4204-we have no doubt — upon [him]3779-your brother . [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s fine bluff English independence , though a most charming characteristic , does not — as [we]4204-we have agreed — invite confidence . If [I]1711-i might venture to remark that it is the least in [the world]301-the world deficient in that delicacy to which [a youth mistaken]4206-a youth mistaken , [a character]4207-a character misconceived , and abilities misdirected , would turn for relief and guidance , [I]1711-i should express what it presents to [my]1711-i own view . ’[1711-i] As [she]1711-i sat looking straight before [her]1711-i , across the changing lights upon the grass into the darkness of [the wood]1712-the wood beyond , [he]1713-i saw in [her]1711-i face [her]1711-i application of [his]1713-i very distinctly uttered words . ‘ All allowance , ’[1713-i] [he]1713-i continued , ‘ must be made . [I]1713-i have one great fault to find with [Tom]71-tom , however , which [I]1713-i can not forgive , and for which [I]1713-i take [him]71-tom heavily to account . ’[1713-i] [Louisa]92-louisa turned [her]92-louisa eyes to [his]1713-i face , and asked [him]1713-i what fault was that ? ‘ Perhaps , ’[1713-i] [he]1713-i returned , ‘ [I]1713-i have said enough . Perhaps it would have been better , on the whole , if no allusion to it had escaped [me]1713-i . ’[1713-i] ‘ [You]1713-i alarm [me]92-louisa , [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse . Pray let [me]92-louisa know it . ’[92-louisa] ‘ To relieve [you]92-louisa from needless apprehension — and as this confidence regarding [[your]92-louisa brother]3779-your brother , which [I]1713-i prize [I]1713-i am sure above all possible things , has been established between [us]4209-us — [I]1713-i obey . [I]1713-i can not forgive [him]71-tom for not being more sensible in every word , look , and act of [his]71-tom life , of the affection of [[his]71-tom best friend]4210-his best friend ; of the devotion of [[his]71-tom best friend]4210-his best friend ; of [her]4210-his best friend unselfishness ; of [her]4210-his best friend sacrifice . The return [he]71-tom makes [her]4210-his best friend , within [my]1713-i observation , is a very poor one . What [she]4210-his best friend has done for [him]71-tom demands [his]71-tom constant love and gratitude , not [his]71-tom ill - humour and caprice . [Careless fellow]4212-careless fellow as [I]1713-i am , [I]1713-i am not so indifferent , [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby , as to be regardless of this vice in [[your]155-mrs. bounderby brother]3779-your brother , or inclined to consider it a venial offence . ’[1713-i] [The wood]1712-the wood floated before [her]1715-her , for [her]1715-her eyes were suffused with tears . They rose from a deep well , long concealed , and [her]1715-her heart was filled with acute pain that found no relief in them . ‘ In a word , it is to correct [[your]155-mrs. bounderby brother]3779-your brother in this , [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby , that [I]1716-i must aspire . [My]1716-i better knowledge of [his]71-tom circumstances , and [my]1716-i direction and advice in extricating [them]4215-them — rather valuable , [I]1716-i hope , as coming from a scapegrace on a much larger scale — will give [me]1716-i some influence over [him]71-tom , and all [I]1716-i gain [I]1716-i shall certainly use towards this end . [I]1716-i have said enough , and more than enough . [I]1716-i seem to be protesting that [I]1716-i am [a sort of good fellow]4216-a sort of good fellow , when , upon [my]1716-i honour , [I]1716-i have not the least intention to make any protestation to that effect , and openly announce that [I]1716-i am nothing of the sort . [Yonder]187-yonder , among the trees , ’[1716-i] [he]1716-i added , having lifted up [his]1716-i eyes and looked about ; for [he]1716-i had watched [her]1717-her closely until now ; ‘ is [[your]1717-her brother]3779-your brother [himself]71-tom ; no doubt , just come down . As [he]71-tom seems to be loitering in this direction , it may be as well , perhaps , to walk towards [him]71-tom , and throw [ourselves]1718-ourselves in [his]71-tom way . [He]71-tom has been very silent and doleful of late . Perhaps , [his]71-tom brotherly conscience is touched — if there are such things as consciences . Though , upon [my]1716-i honour , [I]1716-i hear of them much too often to believe in them . ’[1716-i] [He]1716-i assisted [her]1717-her to rise , and [she]1717-her took [his]1716-i arm , and [they]1718-ourselves advanced to meet [the whelp]1387-the whelp . [He]1716-i was idly beating the branches as [he]1716-i lounged along : or [he]1716-i stooped viciously to rip the moss from the trees with [his]1716-i stick . [He]1716-i was startled when [they]1720-they came upon [him]1716-i while [he]1716-i was engaged in this latter pastime , and [his]1716-i colour changed . ‘ [Halloa]104-halloa ! ’[1716-i] [he]1716-i stammered ; ‘ [I]1716-i did n’t know [you]104-halloa were [here]366-here . ’[1716-i] ‘ Whose name , [Tom]71-tom , ’[167-mr. harthouse] said [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , putting [his]167-mr. harthouse hand upon [his]1716-i shoulder and turning [him]1716-i , so that [they]1720-they all three walked towards [the house]2918-the house together , ‘ have [you]1716-i been carving on the trees ? ’[1716-i] ‘ Whose name ? ’[71-tom] returned [Tom]71-tom . ‘ Oh ! [You]1716-i mean what [girl]2800-girl ’s name ? ’[71-tom] ‘ [You]1716-i have a suspicious appearance of inscribing some fair creature ’s on the bark , [Tom]71-tom . ’[1716-i]

‘ Not much of that , [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , unless [some fair creature with a slashing fortune at [her]4220-some fair creature with a slashing fortune at her own disposal own disposal]4220-some fair creature with a slashing fortune at her own disposal would take a fancy to [me]71-tom . Or [she]4220-some fair creature with a slashing fortune at her own disposal might be as ugly as [she]4220-some fair creature with a slashing fortune at her own disposal was rich , without any fear of losing [me]71-tom . [I]71-tom ’d carve [her]4220-some fair creature with a slashing fortune at her own disposal name as often as [she]4220-some fair creature with a slashing fortune at her own disposal liked . ’[71-tom] ‘ [I]1716-i am afraid [you]71-tom are [mercenary]4221-mercenary , [Tom]71-tom . ’[1716-i] ‘ Mercenary , ’[71-tom] repeated [Tom]71-tom . ‘ Who is not [mercenary]4221-mercenary ? Ask [[my]71-tom sister]738-my sister . ’[71-tom] ‘ Have [you]71-tom so proved it to be a failing of [mine]92-louisa , [Tom]71-tom ? ’[92-louisa] said [Louisa]92-louisa , showing no other sense of [his]71-tom discontent and ill - nature . ‘ [You]71-tom know whether the cap fits [you]71-tom , [Loo]101-loo , ’[2932-her brother] returned [[her]92-louisa brother]2932-her brother sulkily . ‘ If it does , [you]71-tom can wear it . ’[2932-her brother] ‘ [Tom]71-tom is misanthropical to - day , as [all bored people]4224-all bored people are now and then , ’[167-mr. harthouse] said [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse . ‘ Do n’t believe [him]71-tom , [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby . [He]71-tom knows much better . [I]167-mr. harthouse shall disclose some of [his]71-tom opinions of [you]71-tom , privately expressed to [me]167-mr. harthouse , unless [he]71-tom relents a little . ’[167-mr. harthouse] ‘ At all events , [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , ’[71-tom] said [Tom]71-tom , softening in [his]71-tom admiration of [[his]71-tom patron]1723-his patron , but shaking [his]71-tom head sullenly too , ‘ [you]71-tom ca n’t tell [her]1723-his patron that [I]71-tom ever praised [her]1723-his patron for being [mercenary]4221-mercenary . [I]71-tom may have praised [her]1723-his patron for being the contrary , and [I]71-tom should do it again , if [I]71-tom had as good reason . However , never mind this now ; it ’s not very interesting to [you]71-tom , and [I]71-tom am sick of the subject . ’[71-tom] [They]1724-they walked on to [the house]2918-the house , where [Louisa]92-louisa quitted [[her]92-louisa visitor]1726-her visitor ’s arm and went in . [He]71-tom stood looking after [her]92-louisa , as [she]92-louisa ascended the steps , and passed into the shadow of the door ; then put [his]71-tom hand upon [[her]92-louisa brother]2932-her brother ’s shoulder again , and invited [him]71-tom with a confidential nod to a walk in [the garden]1728-the garden . ‘ [Tom]71-tom , [[my]1724-they fine fellow]4226-my fine fellow , [I]1724-they want to have a word with [you]71-tom . ’[1724-they] [They]1724-they had stopped among a disorder of roses — it was part of [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s humility to keep [Nickits]186-nickits ’s roses on a reduced scale — and [Tom]71-tom sat down on [a terrace - parapet]1729-a terrace - parapet , plucking buds and picking them to pieces ; while [[his]71-tom powerful Familiar]1730-his powerful familiar stood over [him]71-tom , with a foot upon the parapet , and [his]71-tom figure easily resting on the arm supported by that knee . [They]1724-they were just visible from [her]1730-his powerful familiar window . Perhaps [she]1730-his powerful familiar saw them . ‘ [Tom]71-tom , what ’s the matter ? ’[1730-his powerful familiar] ‘ Oh ! [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , ’[71-tom] said [Tom]71-tom with a groan , ‘ [I]1730-his powerful familiar am hard up , and bothered out of [my]1730-his powerful familiar life . ’[1730-his powerful familiar] ‘ [[My]1730-his powerful familiar good fellow]888-my good fellow , so am [I.]1730-his powerful familiar ’[1730-his powerful familiar] ‘ [You]167-mr. harthouse ! ’[71-tom] returned [Tom]71-tom . ‘ [You]167-mr. harthouse are the picture of independence . [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , [I]71-tom am in a horrible mess . [You]167-mr. harthouse have no idea what a state [I]71-tom have got [myself]71-tom into — what a state [[my]71-tom sister]738-my sister might have got [me]71-tom out of , if [she]738-my sister would only have done it . ’[71-tom] [He]71-tom took to biting the rosebuds now , and tearing them away from [his]71-tom teeth with a hand that trembled like [an infirm old man]1731-an infirm old man ’s . After one exceedingly observant look at [him]71-tom , [[his]71-tom companion]1410-his companion relapsed into [his]71-tom lightest air . ‘ [Tom]71-tom , [you]71-tom are inconsiderate : [you]71-tom expect too much of [[your]71-tom sister]354-your sister . [You]71-tom have had money of [her]354-your sister , [you]71-tom dog , [you]71-tom know [you]71-tom have . ’[1410-his companion] ‘ Well , [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , [I]1733-i know [I]1733-i have . How else was [I]1733-i to get it ? Here ’s [old Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby always boasting that at [my]1733-i age [he]93-mr. bounderby lived upon twopence a month , or something of that sort . Here ’s [[my]1733-i father]4230-my father drawing what [he]4230-my father calls a line , and tying [me]1733-i down to it from [a baby]3262-a baby , neck and heels . Here ’s [[[my]1733-i mother]367-my mother who never has anything of [her]367-my mother own , except [her]367-my mother complaints . What is [a fellow]4234-a fellow to do for money , and where am [I]1733-i to look for it , if not to [[my]1733-i sister]738-my sister]4233-my mother who never has anything of her own , except her complaints . what is a fellow to do for money , and where am i to look for it , if not to my sister ? ’[1733-i] [He]1733-i was almost crying , and scattered the buds about by dozens . [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse took [him]1733-i persuasively by the coat . ‘ But , [[my]167-mr. harthouse dear]601-my dear [Tom]71-tom , if [[your]71-tom sister]354-your sister has not got it — ’[167-mr. harthouse] ‘ Not got it , [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse ? [I]167-mr. harthouse do n’t say [she]354-your sister has got it . [I]167-mr. harthouse may have wanted more than [she]354-your sister was likely to have got . But then [she]354-your sister ought to get it . [She]354-your sister could get it . It ’s of no use pretending to make a secret of matters now , after what [I]167-mr. harthouse have told [you]71-tom already ; [you]71-tom know [she]354-your sister did n’t marry [old Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby for [her]354-your sister own sake , or for [his]93-mr. bounderby sake , but for [my]167-mr. harthouse sake . Then why does n’t [she]354-your sister get what [I]167-mr. harthouse want , out of [him]93-mr. bounderby , for [my]167-mr. harthouse sake ? [She]354-your sister is not obliged to say what [she]354-your sister is going to do with it ; [she]354-your sister is sharp enough ; [she]354-your sister could manage to coax it out of [him]93-mr. bounderby , if [she]354-your sister chose . Then why does n’t [she]354-your sister choose , when [I]167-mr. harthouse tell [her]354-your sister of what consequence it is ? But no . There [she]354-your sister sits in [[his]93-mr. bounderby company]3114-his company like a stone , instead of making [herself]354-your sister agreeable and getting it easily . [I]167-mr. harthouse do n’t know what [you]4239-you may call this , but [I]167-mr. harthouse call it unnatural conduct . ’[167-mr. harthouse] There was a piece of ornamental water immediately below the parapet , on the other side , into which [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse had a very strong inclination to pitch [Mr. Thomas Gradgrind junior]71-tom , as [the injured men of [Coketown]4-coketown]1734-the injured men of coketown threatened to pitch [[their]1734-the injured men of coketown property]1123-their property into [the Atlantic]32-the atlantic . But [he]167-mr. harthouse preserved [his]167-mr. harthouse easy attitude ; and nothing more solid went over the stone balustrades than the accumulated rosebuds now floating about , a little surface - island . ‘ [[My]167-mr. harthouse dear]601-my dear [Tom]71-tom , ’[167-mr. harthouse] said [Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , ‘ let [me]167-mr. harthouse try to be [[your]71-tom banker]4241-your banker . ’[167-mr. harthouse] ‘ For [God]147-god ’s sake , ’[71-tom] replied [Tom]71-tom , suddenly , ‘ do n’t talk about [bankers]4242-bankers ! ’[71-tom] And very white [he]71-tom looked , in contrast with the roses . Very white . [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , as [a thoroughly well - bred man]1736-a thoroughly well - bred man , accustomed to the best society , was not to be surprised — [he]167-mr. harthouse could as soon have been affected — but [he]167-mr. harthouse raised [his]167-mr. harthouse eyelids a little more , as if they were lifted by a feeble touch of wonder . Albeit it was as much against the precepts of [[his]167-mr. harthouse school]314-his school to wonder , as it was against the doctrines of [the Gradgrind College]42-the gradgrind college . ‘ What is the present need , [Tom]71-tom ? [Three figures]4243-three figures ? Out with [them]4243-three figures . Say what [they]4243-three figures are . ’[167-mr. harthouse] ‘ [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , ’[71-tom] returned [Tom]71-tom , now actually crying ; and [his]71-tom tears were better than [his]71-tom injuries , however pitiful a figure [he]71-tom made : ‘ it ’s too late ; the money is of no use to [me]1738-a true friend at present . [I]1738-a true friend should have had it before to be of use to [me]1738-a true friend . But [I]1738-a true friend am very much obliged to [you]71-tom ; [you]71-tom ’re[1738-a true friend] [a true friend]1738-a true friend . ’ [A true friend]1738-a true friend ! ‘[1738-a true friend] Whelp , whelp ! ’ thought [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , lazily ; ‘[1738-a true friend] what an Ass [you]71-tom are ! ’ ‘[1738-a true friend] And [I]0-i take [your]71-tom offer as a great kindness , ’ said [Tom]71-tom , grasping [his]71-tom hand . ‘[0-i] As a great kindness , [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse . ’ ‘[167-mr. harthouse] Well , ’ returned [the other]287-the other , ‘[0-i] it may be of more use by and by . And , [[my]0-i good fellow]888-my good fellow , if [you]888-my good fellow will open [your]888-my good fellow bedevilments to [me]0-i when they come thick upon [you]888-my good fellow , [I]0-i may show [you]888-my good fellow better ways out of them than [you]888-my good fellow can find for [yourself]888-my good fellow . ’ ‘[0-i] Thank [you]71-tom , ’ said [Tom]71-tom , shaking [his]71-tom head dismally , and chewing rosebuds . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i wish [I]0-i had known [you]71-tom sooner , [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse . ’ ‘[167-mr. harthouse] Now , [you]888-my good fellow see , [Tom]71-tom , ’ said [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse in conclusion , [himself]167-mr. harthouse tossing over a rose or two , as a contribution to [the island]4246-the island , which was always drifting to the wall as if it wanted to become a part of [the mainland]4247-the mainland : ‘[71-tom] [every man]828-every man is selfish in everything [he]828-every man does , and [I]0-i am exactly like the rest of [my]0-i fellow - creatures . [I]0-i am desperately intent ; ’ the languor of [his]167-mr. harthouse desperation being quite tropical ; ‘[0-i] on [your]888-my good fellow softening towards [[your]888-my good fellow sister]354-your sister — which [you]888-my good fellow ought to do ; and on [your]888-my good fellow being a more loving and agreeable sort of brother — which [you]888-my good fellow ought to be . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i will be , [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse . ’ ‘[167-mr. harthouse] No time like the present , [Tom]71-tom . Begin at once . ’ ‘[0-i] Certainly [I]0-i will . And [[my]0-i sister]738-my sister [Loo]101-loo shall say so . ’ ‘[101-loo] Having made which bargain , [Tom]71-tom , ’ said [Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , clapping [him]71-tom on the shoulder again , with an air which left [him]71-tom at liberty to infer — as [he]71-tom did , [poor fool]4248-poor fool — that this condition was imposed upon [him]71-tom in mere careless good nature to lessen [his]71-tom sense of obligation , ‘[71-tom] [we]1743-we will tear [ourselves]1743-we asunder until dinner - time . ’ When [Tom]71-tom appeared before dinner , though [his]71-tom mind seemed heavy enough , [his]71-tom body was on the alert ; and [he]71-tom appeared before [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby came in . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i did n’t mean to be cross , [Loo]101-loo , ’ [he]0-i said , giving [her]101-loo [his]0-i hand , and kissing [her]101-loo . ‘[101-loo] [I]0-i know [you]101-loo are fond of [me]0-i , and [you]101-loo know [I]0-i am fond of [you]101-loo . ’ After this , there was a smile upon [Louisa]92-louisa ’s face that day , for some one else . Alas , for [some one else]4249-some one else ! ‘[0-i] So much the less is the whelp the only creature that [she]101-loo cares for , ’ thought [James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , reversing the reflection of [his]167-mr. harthouse first day ’s knowledge of [her]101-loo pretty face . ‘[0-i] So much the less , so much the less . ’ The next morning was too bright a morning for sleep , and [James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse rose early , and sat in the pleasant bay window of [[his]167-mr. harthouse dressing - room]4250-his dressing - room , smoking the rare tobacco that had had so wholesome an influence on [[his]167-mr. harthouse young friend]3057-his young friend . Reposing in the sunlight , with the fragrance of [his]167-mr. harthouse eastern pipe about [him]167-mr. harthouse , and the dreamy smoke vanishing into the air , so rich and soft with summer odours , [he]167-mr. harthouse reckoned up [his]167-mr. harthouse advantages as an idle winner might count [his]167-mr. harthouse gains . [He]167-mr. harthouse was not at all bored for the time , and could give [his]167-mr. harthouse mind to it . [He]167-mr. harthouse had established a confidence with [her]101-loo , from which [[her]101-loo husband]2903-her husband was excluded . [He]167-mr. harthouse had established a confidence with [her]101-loo , that absolutely turned upon [her]101-loo indifference towards [[her]101-loo husband]2903-her husband , and the absence , now and at all times , of any congeniality between [them]4254-them . [He]167-mr. harthouse had artfully , but plainly , assured [her]101-loo that [he]167-mr. harthouse knew [her]101-loo heart in its last most delicate recesses ; [he]167-mr. harthouse had come so near to [her]101-loo through its tenderest sentiment ; [he]167-mr. harthouse had associated [himself]167-mr. harthouse with that feeling ; and the barrier behind which [she]101-loo lived , had melted away . All very odd , and very satisfactory ! And yet [he]167-mr. harthouse had not , even now , any earnest wickedness of purpose in [him]167-mr. harthouse . Publicly and privately , it were much better for the age in which [he]167-mr. harthouse lived , that [he]167-mr. harthouse and [the legion of whom [he]167-mr. harthouse was [one]2888-one]4255-the legion of whom he was one were designedly bad , than indifferent and purposeless . It is the drifting icebergs setting with any current anywhere , that wreck [the ships]4257-the ships . When [the Devil]188-the devil goeth about like a roaring lion , [he]188-the devil goeth about in a shape by which [few but savages and hunters]4258-few but savages and hunters are attracted . But , when [he]188-the devil is trimmed , smoothed , and varnished , according to the mode ; when [he]188-the devil is aweary of vice , and aweary of virtue , used up as to brimstone , and used up as to bliss ; then , whether [he]188-the devil take to the serving out of red tape , or to the kindling of red fire , [he]188-the devil is [the very Devil]4259-the very devil . So [James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse reclined in the window , indolently smoking , and reckoning up the steps [he]167-mr. harthouse had taken on [the road by which [he]167-mr. harthouse happened to be travelling]4260-the road by which he happened to be travelling . The end to which it led was before [him]167-mr. harthouse , pretty plainly ; but [he]167-mr. harthouse troubled [himself]167-mr. harthouse with no calculations about it . What will be , will be . As [he]167-mr. harthouse had rather a long ride to take that day — for there was a public occasion ‘[0-i] to do ’ at some distance , which afforded a tolerable opportunity of going in for [the Gradgrind men]4261-the gradgrind men — [he]167-mr. harthouse dressed early and went down to breakfast . [He]167-mr. harthouse was anxious to see if [she]4262-she had relapsed since the previous evening . No . [He]167-mr. harthouse resumed where [he]167-mr. harthouse had left off . There was a look of interest for [him]167-mr. harthouse again . [He]167-mr. harthouse got through the day as much ( or as little ) to [his]167-mr. harthouse own satisfaction , as was to be expected under the fatiguing circumstances ; and came riding back at six o’clock . There was a sweep of some half - mile between [the lodge]641-the lodge and [the house]2918-the house , and [he]167-mr. harthouse was riding along at a foot pace over the smooth gravel , once [Nickits]186-nickits ’s , when [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby burst out of the shrubbery , with such violence as to make [his]93-mr. bounderby horse shy across [the road]2846-the road . ‘[0-i] [Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse ! ’ cried [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . ‘[167-mr. harthouse] Have [you]167-mr. harthouse heard ? ’ ‘[167-mr. harthouse] Heard what ? ’ said [Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , soothing [his]167-mr. harthouse horse , and inwardly favouring [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby with no good wishes . ‘[167-mr. harthouse] Then [you]167-mr. harthouse have n’t heard ! ’ ‘[167-mr. harthouse] [I]0-i have heard [you]167-mr. harthouse , and so has [this brute]1744-this brute . [I]0-i have heard nothing else . ’ [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , red and hot , planted [himself]93-mr. bounderby in the centre of the path before the horse ’s head , to explode [his]93-mr. bounderby bombshell with more effect . ‘[0-i] [The Bank]3524-the bank ’s robbed ! ’ ‘[167-mr. harthouse] [You]167-mr. harthouse do n’t mean it ! ’ ‘[167-mr. harthouse] Robbed last night , [sir]2771-sir . Robbed in an extraordinary manner . Robbed with a false key . ’ ‘[167-mr. harthouse] Of much ? ’ [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , in [his]93-mr. bounderby desire to make the most of it , really seemed mortified by being obliged to reply , ‘[167-mr. harthouse] Why , no ; not of very much . But it might have been . ’ ‘[0-i] Of how much ? ’ ‘[0-i] Oh ! as a sum — if [you]167-mr. harthouse stick to a sum — of not more than a hundred and fifty pound , ’ said [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , with impatience . ‘[0-i] But it ’s not the sum ; it ’s the fact . It ’s the fact of [the Bank]3524-the bank being robbed , that ’s the important circumstance . [I]0-i am surprised [you]167-mr. harthouse do n’t see it . ’ ‘[167-mr. harthouse] [[My]0-i dear]601-my dear [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ’ said [James]167-mr. harthouse , dismounting , and giving [his]0-i bridle to [[his]0-i servant]846-his servant , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i do see it ; and am as overcome as [you]93-mr. bounderby can possibly desire [me]0-i to be , by the spectacle afforded to [my]0-i mental view . Nevertheless , [I]0-i may be allowed , [I]0-i hope , to congratulate [you]93-mr. bounderby — which [I]0-i do with all [my]0-i soul , [I]0-i assure [you]93-mr. bounderby — on [your]93-mr. bounderby not having sustained a greater loss . ’ ‘[0-i] Thank’ee , ’ replied [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , in a short , ungracious manner . ‘[0-i] But [I]0-i tell [you]93-mr. bounderby what . It might have been twenty thousand pound . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i suppose it might . ’ ‘[0-i] Suppose it might ! By [the Lord]1749-the lord , [you]93-mr. bounderby may suppose so . By [George]72-george ! ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , with sundry menacing nods and shakes of [his]93-mr. bounderby head . ‘[72-george] It might have been twice twenty . There ’s no knowing what it would have been , or would n’t have been , as it was , but for [the fellows]1750-the fellows ’ being disturbed . ’[92-louisa] [Louisa]92-louisa had come up now , and [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , and [Bitzer]77-bitzer . ‘ Here ’s [[Tom Gradgrind]71-tom ’s daughter]1058-tom gradgrind ’s daughter knows pretty well what it might have been , if [you]93-mr. bounderby do n’t , ’[93-mr. bounderby] blustered [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . ‘ [Dropped]189-dropped , [sir]2771-sir , as if [she]1751-her was shot when [I]93-mr. bounderby told [her]1751-her ! Never knew [her]1751-her do such a thing before . Does [her]1751-her credit , under the circumstances , in [my]93-mr. bounderby opinion ! ’[93-mr. bounderby] [She]1751-her still looked faint and pale . [James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse begged [her]1751-her to take [his]167-mr. harthouse arm ; and as [they]1752-they moved on very slowly , asked [her]1751-her how the robbery had been committed . ‘ Why , [I]93-mr. bounderby am going to tell [you]93-mr. bounderby , ’[93-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , irritably giving [his]93-mr. bounderby arm to [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit . ‘ If [you]93-mr. bounderby had n’t been so mighty particular about the sum , [I]93-mr. bounderby should have begun to tell [you]93-mr. bounderby before . [You]93-mr. bounderby know [this lady]619-this lady ( for [she]619-this lady is [a lady]4270-a lady ) , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ? ’[93-mr. bounderby] ‘ [I]167-mr. harthouse have already had the honour — ’[167-mr. harthouse] ‘ Very well . And [this young man]4271-this young man , [Bitzer]77-bitzer , [you]93-mr. bounderby saw [him]4271-this young man too on the same occasion ? ’[167-mr. harthouse] [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse inclined [his]167-mr. harthouse head in assent , and [Bitzer]77-bitzer knuckled [his]77-bitzer forehead . ‘ Very well . [They]4272-they live at [the Bank]3524-the bank . [You]93-mr. bounderby know [they]4272-they live at [the Bank]33-the bank , perhaps ? Very well . Yesterday afternoon , at the close of business hours , everything was put away as usual . In [the iron room that [this young fellow]4275-this young fellow sleeps outside of]4274-the iron room that this young fellow sleeps outside of , there was never mind how much . In the little safe in [[young Tom]71-tom ’s closet]4276-young tom ’s closet , the safe used for petty purposes , there was a hundred and fifty odd pound . ’[77-bitzer] ‘ A hundred and fifty - four , seven , one , ’[77-bitzer] said [Bitzer]77-bitzer . ‘ Come ! ’[93-mr. bounderby] retorted [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , stopping to wheel round upon [him]77-bitzer , ‘ let ’s have none of [your]77-bitzer interruptions . It ’s enough to be robbed while [you]77-bitzer ’re[93-mr. bounderby] snoring because [you]77-bitzer ’re too comfortable , without being put right with [your]77-bitzer four seven ones . [I]77-bitzer did n’t snore , [myself]77-bitzer , when [I]77-bitzer was [your]77-bitzer age , let [me]77-bitzer tell [you]77-bitzer . [I]77-bitzer had n’t victuals enough to snore . And [I]77-bitzer did n’t four seven one . Not if [I]77-bitzer knew it . ’[77-bitzer] [Bitzer]77-bitzer knuckled [his]77-bitzer forehead again , in a sneaking manner , and seemed at once particularly impressed and depressed by the instance last given of [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s moral abstinence . ‘ A hundred and fifty odd pound , ’[93-mr. bounderby] resumed [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . ‘ That sum of money , [young Tom]71-tom locked in [[his]71-tom safe]4277-his safe , not a very strong safe , but that ’s no matter now . Everything was left , all right . Some time in the night , while [this young fellow]4275-this young fellow snored — [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , [ma’am]361-ma’am , [you]126-mrs. sparsit say [you]126-mrs. sparsit have heard [him]4275-this young fellow snore ? ’[93-mr. bounderby] ‘ [Sir]2771-sir , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] returned [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘ [I]126-mrs. sparsit can not say that [I]126-mrs. sparsit have heard [him]4275-this young fellow precisely snore , and therefore must not make that statement . But on winter evenings , when [he]4275-this young fellow has fallen asleep at [his]4275-this young fellow table , [I]126-mrs. sparsit have heard [him]4275-this young fellow , what [I]126-mrs. sparsit should prefer to describe as partially choke . [I]126-mrs. sparsit have heard [him]4275-this young fellow on such occasions produce sounds of a nature similar to what may be sometimes heard in Dutch clocks . Not , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , with a lofty sense of giving strict evidence , ‘ that [I]126-mrs. sparsit would convey any imputation on [his]4275-this young fellow moral character . Far from it . [I]126-mrs. sparsit have always considered [Bitzer]77-bitzer [a young man of the most upright principle]4281-a young man of the most upright principle ; and to that [I]126-mrs. sparsit beg to bear [my]126-mrs. sparsit testimony . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] ‘ Well ! ’[93-mr. bounderby] said [the exasperated Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ‘ while [he]4275-this young fellow was snoring , or choking , or Dutch - clocking , or something or other — being asleep — [some fellows]1010-some fellows , somehow , whether previously concealed in [the house]2918-the house or not remains to be seen , got to [young Tom]71-tom ’s safe , forced it , and abstracted the contents . Being then disturbed , [they]1010-some fellows made off ; letting [themselves]1010-some fellows out at the main door , and double - locking it again ( it was double - locked , and the key under [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s pillow ) with a false key , which was picked up in [the street]461-the street near [the Bank]3524-the bank , about twelve o’clock to - day . No alarm takes place , till [this chap]4286-this chap , [Bitzer]77-bitzer , turns out this morning , and begins to open and prepare [the offices]4287-the offices for business . Then , looking at [Tom]71-tom ’s safe , [he]4275-this young fellow sees the door ajar , and finds the lock forced , and the money gone . ’[93-mr. bounderby] ‘ Where is [Tom]71-tom , by the by ? ’[167-mr. harthouse] asked [Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , glancing round . ‘ [He]4275-this young fellow has been helping [the police]4288-the police , ’[93-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ‘ and stays behind at [the Bank]3524-the bank . [I]93-mr. bounderby wish [these fellows]4290-these fellows had tried to rob [me]93-mr. bounderby when [I]93-mr. bounderby was at [his]4275-this young fellow time of life . [They]4290-these fellows would have been out of pocket if [they]4290-these fellows had invested eighteenpence in the job ; [I]93-mr. bounderby can tell [’em]4291-’em[93-mr. bounderby] that . ’ ‘[93-mr. bounderby] Is [anybody]2887-anybody suspected ? ’ ‘[2887-anybody] Suspected ? [I]0-i should think there was [somebody]3148-somebody suspected . [Egod]190-egod ! ’ said [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , relinquishing [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s arm to wipe [his]93-mr. bounderby heated head . ‘[190-egod] [[Josiah Bounderby]97-bounderby of [Coketown]4-coketown]390-josiah bounderby of coketown is not to be plundered and [nobody]365-nobody suspected . No , thank [you]0-i ! ’ Might [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse inquire Who was suspected ? ‘[0-i] Well , ’ said [Bounderby]97-bounderby , stopping and facing about to confront [them]1757-the scoundrels concerned all , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i ’ll tell [you]0-i . It ’s not to be mentioned everywhere ; it ’s not to be mentioned anywhere : in order that [the scoundrels concerned]1757-the scoundrels concerned ( there ’s [a gang of ’em]4292-a gang of ’em ) may be thrown off [their]1757-the scoundrels concerned guard . So take this in confidence . Now wait a bit . ’[4292-a gang of ’em] [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby wiped [his]93-mr. bounderby head again . ‘ What should [you]0-i say to ; ’[93-mr. bounderby] here [he]93-mr. bounderby violently exploded : ‘ to a Hand being in it ? ’[93-mr. bounderby] ‘ [I]167-mr. harthouse hope , ’[167-mr. harthouse] said [Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , lazily , ‘ not [[our]1757-the scoundrels concerned friend]3876-our friend [Blackpot]191-blackpot ? ’[167-mr. harthouse] ‘ Say Pool instead of [Pot]192-pot , [sir]2771-sir , ’[93-mr. bounderby] returned [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ‘ and that ’s [the man]516-the man . ’[92-louisa] [Louisa]92-louisa faintly uttered some word of incredulity and surprise . ‘ O yes ! [I]93-mr. bounderby know ! ’[93-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , immediately catching at the sound . ‘ [I]93-mr. bounderby know ! [I]93-mr. bounderby am used to that . [I]93-mr. bounderby know all about it . [They]4296-they are [the finest people in [the world]301-the world]4297-the finest people in the world , [these fellows]4290-these fellows are . [They]4296-they have got the gift of the gab , [they]4296-they have . [They]4296-they only want to have [their]4296-they rights explained to [them]4296-they , [they]4296-they do . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , [ma’am]361-ma’am , [I]0-i appeal to [you]361-ma’am .
