[Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , in point of high connexions , [you]361-ma’am are on a level with [the aristocracy]1763-the aristocracy , — did [I]0-i say , or did [I]0-i not say , to [that fellow]1760-that fellow , “ [you]361-ma’am ca n’t hide the truth from [me]0-i : [you]361-ma’am are not the kind of fellow [I]0-i like ; [you]361-ma’am ’ll come to no good ” ? ’ ‘[2771-sir] Assuredly , [sir]2771-sir , ’ returned [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘[2771-sir] [you]2771-sir did , in a highly impressive manner , give [him]1760-that fellow such an admonition . ’ ‘[2771-sir] When [he]1760-that fellow shocked [you]361-ma’am , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’ said [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ; ‘[1760-that fellow] when [he]1760-that fellow shocked [your]361-ma’am feelings ? ’ ‘[1760-that fellow] Yes , [sir]2771-sir , ’ returned [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , with a meek shake of [her]126-mrs. sparsit head , ‘[1760-that fellow] [he]1760-that fellow certainly did so . Though [I]0-i do not mean to say but that [my]0-i feelings may be weaker on such points — more foolish if the term is preferred — than they might have been , if [I]0-i had always occupied [my]0-i present position . ’ [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby stared with a bursting pride at [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , as much as to say , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i am [the proprietor of [this female]1769-this female]1768-the proprietor of this female , and [she]1769-this female ’s worth [your]361-ma’am attention , [I]0-i think . ’ Then , resumed [his]93-mr. bounderby discourse . ‘[1769-this female] [You]361-ma’am can recall for [yourself]361-ma’am , [Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , what [I]0-i said to [him]1760-that fellow when [you]361-ma’am saw [him]1760-that fellow . [I]0-i did n’t mince the matter with [him]1760-that fellow . [I]0-i am never mealy with ’em . [I]0-i KNOW ’em[0-i] . Very well , [sir]2771-sir . Three days after that , [he]1760-that fellow bolted . Went off , [nobody]365-nobody knows where : as [[my]0-i mother]367-my mother did in [my]0-i infancy — only with this difference , that [he]1760-that fellow is a worse subject than [[my]0-i mother]367-my mother , if possible . What did [he]1760-that fellow do before [he]1760-that fellow went ? What do [you]361-ma’am say ; ’ [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , with [his]93-mr. bounderby hat in [his]93-mr. bounderby hand , gave a beat upon the crown at every little division of [his]93-mr. bounderby sentences , as if it were a tambourine ; ‘[361-ma’am] to [his]1760-that fellow being seen — night after night — watching [the Bank]3524-the bank ? — to [his]1760-that fellow lurking about there — after dark ? — To its striking [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit — that [he]1760-that fellow could be lurking for no good — To [her]367-my mother calling [Bitzer]77-bitzer ’s attention to [him]1760-that fellow , and [their]1775-their both taking notice of [him]1760-that fellow — And to its appearing on inquiry to - day — that [he]1760-that fellow was also noticed by [the neighbours]1776-the neighbours ? ’ Having come to the climax , [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , like [an oriental dancer]4303-an oriental dancer , put [his]93-mr. bounderby tambourine on [his]93-mr. bounderby head . ‘[367-my mother] Suspicious , ’ said [James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , ‘[367-my mother] certainly . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i think so , [sir]2771-sir , ’ said [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , with a defiant nod . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i think so . But there are more of ’em in it . There ’s [an old woman]452-an old woman . [One]2888-one never hears of these things till the mischief ’s done ; all sorts of defects are found out in the stable door after the horse is stolen ; there ’s [an old woman]452-an old woman turns up now . [An old woman who seems to have been flying into [town]439-town on a broomstick , every now and then]4307-an old woman who seems to have been flying into town on a broomstick , every now and then . [She]452-an old woman watches [the place]2849-the place a whole day before [this fellow]4310-this fellow begins , and on the night when [you]2771-sir saw [him]4310-this fellow , [she]452-an old woman steals away with [him]4310-this fellow and holds a council with [him]4310-this fellow — [I]1778-a person suppose , to make [her]452-an old woman report on going off duty , and be damned to [her]452-an old woman . ’[1778-a person] There was such [a person]1778-a person in [the room]2901-the room that night , and [she]1780-she shrunk from observation , thought [Louisa]92-louisa . ‘ This is not all of ’em[1780-she] , even as [we]1781-we already know ’em , ’[93-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , with many nods of hidden meaning . ‘ But [I]93-mr. bounderby have said enough for the present . [You]2771-sir ’ll have the goodness to keep it quiet , and mention it to [no one]3086-no one . It may take time , but [we]1781-we shall have ’em[93-mr. bounderby] . It ’s policy to give ’em line enough , and there ’s no objection to that . ’[93-mr. bounderby] ‘ Of course , [they]4312-they will be punished with the utmost rigour of the law , as notice - boards observe , ’[167-mr. harthouse] replied [James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , ‘ and serve [them]4312-they right . [Fellows who go in for [Banks]164-banks]4313-fellows who go in for banks must take the consequences . If there were no consequences , [we]1781-we should all go in for [Banks]164-banks . ’[93-mr. bounderby] [He]93-mr. bounderby had gently taken [Louisa]92-louisa ’s parasol from [her]92-louisa hand , and had put it up for [her]92-louisa ; and [she]92-louisa walked under its shade , though the sun did not shine there . ‘ For the present , [Loo Bounderby]101-loo , ’[2903-her husband] said [[her]92-louisa husband]2903-her husband , ‘ here ’s [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit to look after . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s nerves have been acted upon by this business , and [she]126-mrs. sparsit ’ll stay [here]366-here a day or two . So make [her]126-mrs. sparsit comfortable . ’[2903-her husband] ‘ Thank [you]93-mr. bounderby very much , [sir]2771-sir , ’[1783-that discreet lady] [that discreet lady]1783-that discreet lady observed , ‘ but pray do not let [My]1783-that discreet lady comfort be a consideration . Anything will do for [Me]1783-that discreet lady . ’[1783-that discreet lady] It soon appeared that if [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit had a failing in [her]126-mrs. sparsit association with [that domestic establishment]1784-that domestic establishment , it was that [she]126-mrs. sparsit was so excessively regardless of [herself]126-mrs. sparsit and regardful of [others]3223-others , as to be a nuisance . On being shown [[her]126-mrs. sparsit chamber]1786-her chamber , [she]126-mrs. sparsit was so dreadfully sensible of its comforts as to suggest the inference that [she]126-mrs. sparsit would have preferred to pass the night on the mangle in [the laundry]1787-the laundry . True , [the Powlers]129-the powlers and [the Scadgerses]1788-the scadgerses were accustomed to splendour , ‘ but it is [my]126-mrs. sparsit duty to remember , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit was fond of observing with a lofty grace : particularly when [any of [the domestics]1790-the domestics]1789-any of the domestics were present , ‘ that what [I]126-mrs. sparsit was , [I]126-mrs. sparsit am no longer . Indeed , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [she]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘ if [I]126-mrs. sparsit could altogether cancel the remembrance that [Mr. Sparsit]128-mr. sparsit was [a Powler]3120-a powler , or that [I]126-mrs. sparsit [myself]126-mrs. sparsit am related to [the Scadgers family]4317-the scadgers family ; or if [I]126-mrs. sparsit could even revoke the fact , and make [myself]126-mrs. sparsit [a person of common descent and ordinary connexions]4318-a person of common descent and ordinary connexions ; [I]126-mrs. sparsit would gladly do so . [I]126-mrs. sparsit should think it , under existing circumstances , right to do so . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] The same Hermitical state of mind led to [her]126-mrs. sparsit renunciation of made dishes and wines at dinner , until fairly commanded by [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby to take them ; when [she]126-mrs. sparsit said , ‘ Indeed [you]93-mr. bounderby are very good , [sir]2771-sir ; ’[126-mrs. sparsit] and departed from a resolution of which [she]126-mrs. sparsit had made rather formal and public announcement , to ‘ wait for the simple mutton . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] [She]126-mrs. sparsit was likewise deeply apologetic for wanting the salt ; and , feeling amiably bound to bear out [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby to the fullest extent in the testimony [he]93-mr. bounderby had borne to [her]126-mrs. sparsit nerves , occasionally sat back in [her]126-mrs. sparsit chair and silently wept ; at which periods a tear of large dimensions , like a crystal ear - ring , might be observed ( or rather , must be , for it insisted on public notice ) sliding down [her]126-mrs. sparsit Roman nose . But [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s greatest point , first and last , was [her]126-mrs. sparsit determination to pity [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . There were occasions when in looking at [him]93-mr. bounderby [she]126-mrs. sparsit was involuntarily moved to shake [her]126-mrs. sparsit head , as who would say , ‘ Alas , poor [Yorick]194-yorick ! ’[126-mrs. sparsit] After allowing [herself]126-mrs. sparsit to be betrayed into these evidences of emotion , [she]126-mrs. sparsit would force a lambent brightness , and would be fitfully cheerful , and would say , ‘ [You]93-mr. bounderby have still good spirits , [sir]2771-sir , [I]126-mrs. sparsit am thankful to find ; ’[126-mrs. sparsit] and would appear to hail it as a blessed dispensation that [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby bore up as [he]93-mr. bounderby did . One idiosyncrasy for which [she]126-mrs. sparsit often apologized , [she]126-mrs. sparsit found it excessively difficult to conquer . [She]126-mrs. sparsit had a curious propensity to call [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby ‘ [Miss Gradgrind]132-miss gradgrind , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] and yielded to it some three or four score times in the course of the evening . [Her]126-mrs. sparsit repetition of this mistake covered [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit with modest confusion ; but indeed , [she]126-mrs. sparsit said , it seemed so natural to say [Miss Gradgrind]132-miss gradgrind : whereas , to persuade [herself]126-mrs. sparsit that [the young lady whom [she]126-mrs. sparsit had had the happiness of knowing from [a child]436-a child]1791-the young lady whom she had had the happiness of knowing from a child could be really and truly [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby , [she]126-mrs. sparsit found almost impossible . It was a further singularity of this remarkable case , that the more [she]126-mrs. sparsit thought about it , the more impossible it appeared ; ‘ the differences , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] [she]126-mrs. sparsit observed , ‘ being such . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] In [the drawing - room]3300-the drawing - room after dinner , [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby tried the case of the robbery , examined [the witnesses]1794-the witnesses , made notes of the evidence , found [the suspected persons]1795-the suspected persons guilty , and sentenced [them]1795-the suspected persons to the extreme punishment of the law . That done , [Bitzer]77-bitzer was dismissed to [town]439-town with instructions to recommend [Tom]71-tom to come [home]2856-home by [the mail - train]1798-the mail - train . When candles were brought , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit murmured , ‘ Do n’t be low , [sir]2771-sir . Pray let [me]126-mrs. sparsit see [you]2771-sir cheerful , [sir]2771-sir , as [I]126-mrs. sparsit used to do . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , upon whom these consolations had begun to produce the effect of making [him]93-mr. bounderby , in a bull - headed blundering way , sentimental , sighed like some large sea - animal . ‘ [I]126-mrs. sparsit can not bear to see [you]2771-sir so , [sir]2771-sir , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit . ‘ Try a hand at backgammon , [sir]2771-sir , as [you]2771-sir used to do when [I]126-mrs. sparsit had the honour of living under [your]2771-sir roof . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] ‘ [I]93-mr. bounderby have n’t played backgammon , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’[93-mr. bounderby] said [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ‘ since that time . ’[93-mr. bounderby] ‘ No , [sir]2771-sir , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , soothingly , ‘ [I]126-mrs. sparsit am aware that [you]2771-sir have not . [I]126-mrs. sparsit remember that [Miss Gradgrind]132-miss gradgrind takes no interest in the game . But [I]126-mrs. sparsit shall be happy , [sir]2771-sir , if [you]2771-sir will condescend . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] [They]1799-they played near a window , opening on [the garden]1728-the garden . It was a fine night : not moonlight , but sultry and fragrant . [Louisa]92-louisa and [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse strolled out into [the garden]1728-the garden , where [their]1799-they voices could be heard in the stillness , though not what [they]1799-they said . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , from [[her]126-mrs. sparsit place at [the backgammon board]1803-the backgammon board]1802-her place at the backgammon board , was constantly straining [her]126-mrs. sparsit eyes to pierce the shadows without . ‘ What ’s the matter , [ma’am]361-ma’am ? ’[93-mr. bounderby] said [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ; ‘ [you]361-ma’am do n’t see a Fire , do [you]361-ma’am ? ’[93-mr. bounderby] ‘ Oh dear no , [sir]2771-sir , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] returned [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘ [I]126-mrs. sparsit was thinking of the dew . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] ‘ What have [you]361-ma’am got to do with the dew , [ma’am]361-ma’am ? ’[93-mr. bounderby] said [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . ‘ It ’s not [myself]93-mr. bounderby , [sir]2771-sir , ’[93-mr. bounderby] returned [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘ [I]126-mrs. sparsit am fearful of [Miss Gradgrind]132-miss gradgrind ’s taking cold . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] ‘ [She]132-miss gradgrind never takes cold , ’[93-mr. bounderby] said [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . ‘ Really , [sir]2771-sir ? ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit . And was affected with a cough in [her]126-mrs. sparsit throat . When the time drew near for retiring , [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby took a glass of water . ‘ Oh , [sir]2771-sir ? ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit . ‘ Not [your]2771-sir sherry warm , with lemon - peel and nutmeg ? ’[126-mrs. sparsit] ‘ Why , [I]93-mr. bounderby have got out of the habit of taking it now , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’[93-mr. bounderby] said [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . ‘ The more ’s the pity , [sir]2771-sir , ’[93-mr. bounderby] returned [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ; ‘ [you]2771-sir are losing all [your]2771-sir good old habits . Cheer up , [sir]2771-sir ! If [Miss Gradgrind]132-miss gradgrind will permit [me]126-mrs. sparsit , [I]126-mrs. sparsit will offer to make it for [you]2771-sir , as [I]126-mrs. sparsit have often done . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] [Miss Gradgrind]132-miss gradgrind readily permitting [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit to do anything [she]126-mrs. sparsit pleased , [that considerate lady]1804-that considerate lady made the beverage , and handed it to [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . ‘ It will do [you]2771-sir good , [sir]2771-sir . It will warm [your]2771-sir heart . It is the sort of thing [you]2771-sir want , and ought to take , [sir]2771-sir . ’[93-mr. bounderby] And when [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby said , ‘ [Your]126-mrs. sparsit health , [ma’am]361-ma’am ! ’[126-mrs. sparsit] [she]126-mrs. sparsit answered with great feeling , ‘ Thank [you]2771-sir , [sir]2771-sir . The same to [you]2771-sir , and happiness also . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] Finally , [she]126-mrs. sparsit wished [him]93-mr. bounderby good night , with great pathos ; and [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby went to bed , with a maudlin persuasion that [he]93-mr. bounderby had been crossed in something tender , though [he]93-mr. bounderby could not , for [his]93-mr. bounderby life , have mentioned what it was . Long after [Louisa]92-louisa had undressed and lain down , [she]92-louisa watched and waited for [[her]92-louisa brother]2932-her brother ’s coming [home]2856-home . That could hardly be , [she]92-louisa knew , until an hour past midnight ; but in the country silence , which did anything but calm the trouble of [her]92-louisa thoughts , time lagged wearily . At last , when the darkness and stillness had seemed for hours to thicken one another , [she]92-louisa heard the bell at the gate . [She]92-louisa felt as though [she]92-louisa would have been glad that it rang on until daylight ; but it ceased , and the circles of its last sound spread out fainter and wider in the air , and all was dead again . [She]92-louisa waited yet some quarter of an hour , as [she]92-louisa judged . Then [she]92-louisa arose , put on a loose robe , and went out of [[her]92-louisa room]1807-her room in the dark , and up the staircase to [[[her]92-louisa brother]2932-her brother ’s room]1809-her brother ’s room . [His]2932-her brother door being shut , [she]92-louisa softly opened it and spoke to [him]2932-her brother , approaching [his]2932-her brother bed with a noiseless step . [She]92-louisa kneeled down beside it , passed [her]92-louisa arm over [his]2932-her brother neck , and drew [his]2932-her brother face to [hers]92-louisa . [She]92-louisa knew that [he]2932-her brother only feigned to be asleep , but [she]92-louisa said nothing to [him]2932-her brother . [He]2932-her brother started by and by as if [he]2932-her brother were just then awakened , and asked who that was , and what was the matter ? ‘ [Tom]71-tom , have [you]71-tom anything to tell [me]2932-her brother ? If ever [you]71-tom loved [me]2932-her brother in [your]71-tom life , and have anything concealed from every one besides , tell it to [me]2932-her brother . ’[2932-her brother] ‘ [I]92-louisa do n’t know what [you]71-tom mean , [Loo]101-loo . [You]71-tom have been dreaming . ’[92-louisa] ‘ [[My]92-louisa dear brother]4341-my dear brother : ’[92-louisa] [she]92-louisa laid [her]92-louisa head down on [his]2932-her brother pillow , and [her]92-louisa hair flowed over [him]2932-her brother as if [she]92-louisa would hide [him]2932-her brother from every one but [herself]92-louisa : ‘ is there nothing that [you]71-tom have to tell [me]92-louisa ? Is there nothing [you]71-tom can tell [me]92-louisa if [you]71-tom will ? [You]71-tom can tell [me]92-louisa nothing that will change [me]92-louisa . O [Tom]71-tom , tell [me]92-louisa the truth ! ’[92-louisa] ‘ [I]92-louisa do n’t know what [you]71-tom mean , [Loo]101-loo ! ’[92-louisa] ‘ As [you]71-tom lie here alone , [[my]1810-i dear]601-my dear , in the melancholy night , so [you]71-tom must lie somewhere one night , when even [I]1810-i , if [I]1810-i am living then , shall have left [you]71-tom . As [I]1810-i am here beside [you]71-tom , barefoot , unclothed , undistinguishable in darkness , so must [I]1810-i lie through all the night of [my]1810-i decay , until [I]1810-i am dust . In the name of that time , [Tom]71-tom , tell [me]1810-i the truth now ! ’[1810-i] ‘ What is it [you]71-tom want to know ? ’[1810-i] ‘ [You]71-tom may be certain ; ’[1810-i] in the energy of [her]1810-i love [she]1810-i took [him]1811-you to [her]1810-i bosom as if [he]1811-you were [a child]436-a child ; ‘ that [I]1810-i will not reproach [you]1811-you . [You]1811-you may be certain that [I]1810-i will be compassionate and true to [you]1811-you . [You]1811-you may be certain that [I]1810-i will save [you]1811-you at whatever cost . O [Tom]71-tom , have [you]71-tom nothing to tell [me]1810-i ? [Whisper]195-whisper very softly . Say only “ yes , ” and [I]1810-i shall understand [you]71-tom ! ’[1810-i] [She]1810-i turned [her]1810-i ear to [his]1811-you lips , but [he]1811-you remained doggedly silent . ‘ Not a word , [Tom]71-tom ? ’[1810-i] ‘ How can [I]1810-i say Yes , or how can [I]1810-i say No , when [I]1810-i do n’t know what [you]71-tom mean ? [Loo]101-loo , [you]71-tom are [a brave , kind girl]4343-a brave , kind girl , worthy [I]1810-i begin to think of [a better brother]4344-a better brother than [I]1810-i am . But [I]1810-i have nothing more to say . Go to bed , go to bed . ’[1810-i] ‘ [You]1811-you are tired , ’[1810-i] [she]1810-i whispered presently , more in [her]1810-i usual way . ‘ Yes , [I]1810-i am quite tired out . ’[1810-i] ‘ [You]1811-you have been so hurried and disturbed to - day . Have any fresh discoveries been made ? ’[1810-i] ‘ Only those [you]1811-you have heard of , from — [him]1811-you . ’[1810-i] ‘ [Tom]71-tom , have [you]1811-you said to [any one]495-any one that [we]4346-we made a visit to [those people]4347-those people , and that [we]4346-we saw [those three together]4348-those three together ? ’[1810-i] ‘ No . Did n’t [you]1811-you [yourself]1811-you particularly ask [me]1810-i to keep it quiet when [you]1811-you asked [me]1810-i to go [there]425-there with [you]1811-you ? ’[1810-i] ‘ Yes . But [I]1810-i did not know then what was going to happen . ’[1810-i] ‘ Nor [I]1810-i neither . How could [I]1810-i ? ’[1810-i] [He]1813-he was very quick upon [her]1814-her with this retort . ‘ Ought [I]716-his sister to say , after what has happened , ’[716-his sister] said [[his]1813-he sister]716-his sister , standing by the bed — [she]716-his sister had gradually withdrawn [herself]716-his sister and risen , ‘ that [I]716-his sister made that visit ? Should [I]716-his sister say so ? Must [I]716-his sister say so ? ’[716-his sister] ‘ Good Heavens , [Loo]101-loo , ’[2932-her brother] returned [[her]1814-her brother]2932-her brother , ‘ [you]101-loo are not in the habit of asking [my]2932-her brother advice . Say what [you]101-loo like . If [you]101-loo keep it to [yourself]101-loo , [I]2932-her brother shall keep it to [myself]2932-her brother . If [you]101-loo disclose it , there ’s an end of it . ’[2932-her brother] It was too dark for either to see [the other]287-the other ’s face ; but [each]2857-each seemed very attentive , and to consider before speaking . ‘ [Tom]71-tom , do [you]71-tom believe [the man [I]2857-each gave the money to]4350-the man i gave the money to , is really implicated in this crime ? ’[2857-each] ‘ [I]1819-i do n’t know . [I]1819-i do n’t see why [he]4350-the man i gave the money to should n’t be . ’[1819-i] ‘ [He]4350-the man i gave the money to seemed to [me]1819-i [an honest man]4351-an honest man . ’[1819-i] ‘ [Another person]4352-another person may seem to [you]71-tom dishonest , and yet not be so . ’[1819-i] There was a pause , for [he]1819-i had hesitated and stopped . ‘ In short , ’[71-tom] resumed [Tom]71-tom , as if [he]71-tom had made up [his]71-tom mind , ‘ if [you]101-loo come to that , perhaps [I]71-tom was so far from being altogether in [his]4350-the man i gave the money to favour , that [I]71-tom took [him]4350-the man i gave the money to outside the door to tell [him]4350-the man i gave the money to quietly , that [I]71-tom thought [he]4350-the man i gave the money to might consider [himself]4350-the man i gave the money to very well off to get such a windfall as [he]4350-the man i gave the money to had got from [[my]71-tom sister]738-my sister , and that [I]71-tom hoped [he]4350-the man i gave the money to would make good use of it . [You]101-loo remember whether [I]71-tom took [him]4350-the man i gave the money to out or not . [I]71-tom say nothing against [the man]516-the man ; [he]4350-the man i gave the money to may be [a very good fellow]3787-a very good fellow , for anything [I]71-tom know ; [I]71-tom hope [he]4350-the man i gave the money to is . ’[71-tom] ‘ Was [he]4350-the man i gave the money to offended by what [you]71-tom said ? ’[71-tom] ‘ No , [he]4350-the man i gave the money to took it pretty well ; [he]4350-the man i gave the money to was civil enough . Where are [you]1821-you , [Loo]101-loo ? ’[1820-i] [He]1820-i sat up in bed and kissed [her]1821-you . ‘ Good night , [[my]1820-i dear]601-my dear , good night . ’[1820-i] ‘ [You]71-tom have nothing more to tell [me]71-tom ? ’[71-tom] ‘ No . What should [I]71-tom have ? [You]71-tom would n’t have [me]71-tom tell [you]71-tom a lie ! ’[71-tom] ‘ [I]1820-i would n’t have [you]1820-i do that to - night , [Tom]71-tom , of all the nights in [your]1820-i life ; many and much happier as [I]1820-i hope they will be . ’[1820-i] ‘ Thank [you]1822-she , [[my]71-tom dear]601-my dear [Loo]101-loo . [I]71-tom am so tired , that [I]71-tom am sure [I]71-tom wonder [I]71-tom do n’t say anything to get to sleep . Go to bed , go to bed . ’[71-tom] Kissing [her]1822-she again , [he]1823-his turned round , drew the coverlet over [his]1823-his head , and lay as still as if that time had come by which [she]1822-she had adjured [him]1823-his . [She]1822-she stood for some time at the bedside before [she]1822-she slowly moved away . [She]1822-she stopped at the door , looked back when [she]1822-she had opened it , and asked [him]1823-his if [he]1823-his had called [her]1822-she ? But [he]1823-his lay still , and [she]1822-she softly closed the door and returned to [[her]1822-she room]1807-her room . Then [the wretched boy]1825-the wretched boy looked cautiously up and found [her]1822-she gone , crept out of bed , fastened [his]1823-his door , and threw [himself]1823-his upon [his]1823-his pillow again : tearing [his]1823-his hair , morosely crying , grudgingly loving [her]1822-she , hatefully but impenitently spurning [himself]1823-his , and no less hatefully and unprofitably spurning all the good in [the world]301-the world . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , lying by to recover the tone of [her]126-mrs. sparsit nerves in [[Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s retreat]1827-mr. bounderby ’s retreat , kept such a sharp look - out , night and day , under [her]126-mrs. sparsit Coriolanian eyebrows , that [her]126-mrs. sparsit eyes , like a couple of lighthouses on [an iron - bound coast]1828-an iron - bound coast , might have warned [all prudent mariners]1829-all prudent mariners from that bold rock [her]126-mrs. sparsit Roman nose and [the dark and craggy region in [its]1831-its neighbourhood]1830-the dark and craggy region in its neighbourhood , but for the placidity of [her]126-mrs. sparsit manner . Although it was hard to believe that [her]126-mrs. sparsit retiring for the night could be anything but a form , so severely wide awake were those classical eyes of [hers]126-mrs. sparsit , and so impossible did it seem that [her]126-mrs. sparsit rigid nose could yield to any relaxing influence , yet [her]126-mrs. sparsit manner of sitting , smoothing [her]126-mrs. sparsit uncomfortable , not to say , gritty mittens ( they were constructed of a cool fabric like a meat - safe ) , or of ambling to unknown places of destination with [her]126-mrs. sparsit foot in [her]126-mrs. sparsit cotton stirrup , was so perfectly serene , that [most observers]1832-most observers would have been constrained to suppose [her]126-mrs. sparsit a dove , embodied by some freak of nature , in the earthly tabernacle of a bird of the hook - beaked order . [She]126-mrs. sparsit was [a most wonderful woman]1833-a most wonderful woman for prowling about [the house]2918-the house . How [she]126-mrs. sparsit got from story to story was a mystery beyond solution . [A lady so decorous in [herself]126-mrs. sparsit]1835-a lady so decorous in herself , and so highly connected , was not to be suspected of dropping over the banisters or sliding down them , yet [her]126-mrs. sparsit extraordinary facility of locomotion suggested the wild idea . Another noticeable circumstance in [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit was , that [she]126-mrs. sparsit was never hurried . [She]126-mrs. sparsit would shoot with consummate velocity from the roof to [the hall]2924-the hall , yet would be in full possession of [her]126-mrs. sparsit breath and dignity on the moment of [her]126-mrs. sparsit arrival [there]425-there . Neither was [she]126-mrs. sparsit ever seen by human vision to go at a great pace . [She]126-mrs. sparsit took very kindly to [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , and had some pleasant conversation with [him]167-mr. harthouse soon after [her]126-mrs. sparsit arrival . [She]126-mrs. sparsit made [him]167-mr. harthouse [her]126-mrs. sparsit stately curtsey in [the garden]1728-the garden , one morning before breakfast . ‘ It appears but yesterday , [sir]2771-sir , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘ that [I]126-mrs. sparsit had the honour of receiving [you]2771-sir at [the Bank]3524-the bank , when [you]2771-sir were so good as to wish to be made acquainted with [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s address . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] ‘ An occasion , [I]167-mr. harthouse am sure , not to be forgotten by [myself]167-mr. harthouse in the course of Ages , ’[167-mr. harthouse] said [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , inclining [his]167-mr. harthouse head to [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit with the most indolent of all possible airs . ‘ [We]4360-we live in a singular world , [sir]2771-sir , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit . ‘ [I]126-mrs. sparsit have had the honour , by a coincidence of which [I]126-mrs. sparsit am proud , to have made a remark , similar in effect , though not so epigrammatically expressed . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] ‘ A singular world , [I]126-mrs. sparsit would say , [sir]2771-sir , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] pursued [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ; after acknowledging the compliment with a drooping of [her]126-mrs. sparsit dark eyebrows , not altogether so mild in its expression as [her]126-mrs. sparsit voice was in its dulcet tones ; ‘ as regards the intimacies [we]4360-we form at one time , with [individuals]4363-individuals [we]4360-we were quite ignorant of , at another . [I]126-mrs. sparsit recall , [sir]2771-sir , that on that occasion [you]2771-sir went so far as to say [you]2771-sir were actually apprehensive of [Miss Gradgrind]132-miss gradgrind . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] ‘ [Your]2771-sir memory does [me]1839-my more honour than [my]1839-my insignificance deserves . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s talent for — in fact for anything requiring accuracy — with a combination of strength of mind — and [Family]196-family — is too habitually developed to admit of any question . ’[1839-my] [He]1839-my was almost falling asleep over this compliment ; it took [him]1839-my so long to get through , and [his]1839-my mind wandered so much in the course of its execution . ‘ [You]2771-sir found [Miss Gradgrind]132-miss gradgrind — [I]126-mrs. sparsit really can not call [her]132-miss gradgrind [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby ; it ’s very absurd of [me]126-mrs. sparsit — as youthful as [I]126-mrs. sparsit described [her]132-miss gradgrind ? ’[126-mrs. sparsit] asked [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , sweetly . ‘ [You]2771-sir drew [her]132-miss gradgrind portrait perfectly , ’[167-mr. harthouse] said [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse . ‘ Presented [her]132-miss gradgrind dead image . ’[167-mr. harthouse] ‘ Very engaging , [sir]2771-sir , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , causing [her]126-mrs. sparsit mittens slowly to revolve over [one another]551-one another . ‘ Highly so . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] ‘ It used to be considered , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘ that [Miss Gradgrind]132-miss gradgrind was wanting in animation , but [I]126-mrs. sparsit confess [she]132-miss gradgrind appears to [me]126-mrs. sparsit considerably and strikingly improved in that respect . This again made [the excellent woman]1845-the excellent woman vastly sentimental . [She]1845-the excellent woman was so humble withal , that when [Louisa]92-louisa appeared , [she]92-louisa rose , protesting [she]92-louisa never could think of sitting in that place under existing circumstances , often as [she]92-louisa had had the honour of making [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s breakfast , before [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind — [she]95-mrs. gradgrind begged pardon , [she]95-mrs. gradgrind meant to say [Miss Bounderby]197-miss bounderby — [she]95-mrs. gradgrind hoped to be excused , but [she]95-mrs. gradgrind really could not get it right yet , though [she]95-mrs. gradgrind trusted to become familiar with it by and by — had assumed [her]95-mrs. gradgrind present position . It was only ( [she]95-mrs. gradgrind observed ) because [Miss Gradgrind]132-miss gradgrind happened to be a little late , and [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s time was so very precious , and [she]95-mrs. gradgrind knew it of old to be so essential that [he]93-mr. bounderby should breakfast to the moment , that [she]95-mrs. gradgrind had taken the liberty of complying with [his]93-mr. bounderby request ; long as [his]93-mr. bounderby will had been a law to [her]95-mrs. gradgrind . ‘ There ! What does it matter ? ’[92-louisa] Nothing more was said on this theme , and [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse was soon idly gay on indifferent subjects . But from this day , the Sparsit action upon [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby threw [Louisa]92-louisa and [James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse more together , and strengthened the dangerous alienation from [[her]92-louisa husband]2903-her husband and confidence against [him]1847-you with another , into which [she]92-louisa had fallen by degrees so fine that [she]92-louisa could not retrace them if [she]92-louisa tried . But whether [she]92-louisa ever tried or no , lay hidden in [her]92-louisa own closed heart . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit was so much affected on this particular occasion , that , assisting [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby to [his]93-mr. bounderby hat after breakfast , and being then alone with [him]93-mr. bounderby in [the hall]2924-the hall , [she]92-louisa imprinted a chaste kiss upon [his]93-mr. bounderby hand , murmured ‘ [[My]92-louisa benefactor]4385-my benefactor ! ’[92-louisa] and retired , overwhelmed with grief . Yet it is an indubitable fact , within the cognizance of this history , that five minutes after [he]93-mr. bounderby had left [the house]2918-the house in the self - same hat , [the same descendant of [the Scadgerses]198-the scadgerses and connexion by matrimony of [the Powlers]129-the powlers]1851-the same descendant of the scadgerses and connexion by matrimony of the powlers , shook [her]92-louisa right - hand mitten at [his]93-mr. bounderby portrait , made a contemptuous grimace at that work of art , and said ‘ Serve [you]92-louisa right , [you]92-louisa Noodle , and [I]92-louisa am glad of it . ’[92-louisa] [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby had not been long gone , when [Bitzer]77-bitzer appeared . [Bitzer]77-bitzer had come down by [train]1852-train , shrieking and rattling over the long line of arches that bestrode [the wild country of past and present coal - pits]1853-the wild country of past and present coal - pits , with an express from [Stone Lodge]3-stone lodge . It was a hasty note to inform [Louisa]92-louisa that [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind lay very ill . [She]95-mrs. gradgrind had never been well within [[her]95-mrs. gradgrind daughter]1854-her daughter ’s knowledge ; but , [she]95-mrs. gradgrind had declined within the last few days , had continued sinking all through the night , and was now as nearly dead , as [her]95-mrs. gradgrind limited capacity of being in any state that implied the ghost of an intention to get out of it , allowed . Accompanied by the lightest of [porters]1855-porters , fit colourless servitor at [Death]199-death ’s door when [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind knocked , [Louisa]92-louisa rumbled to [Coketown]4-coketown , over [the coal - pits]1856-the coal - pits past and present , and was whirled into its smoky jaws . [She]92-louisa dismissed [the messenger]1857-the messenger to [his]1857-the messenger own devices , and rode away to [[her]92-louisa old home]1858-her old home . [She]92-louisa had seldom been [there]425-there since [her]92-louisa marriage . [[Her]92-louisa father]2855-her father was usually sifting and sifting at [[his]2855-her father parliamentary cinder - heap in [London]8-london]1861-his parliamentary cinder - heap in london ( without being observed to turn up many precious articles among the rubbish ) , and was still hard at it in [the national dust - yard]1862-the national dust - yard . [[Her]92-louisa mother]744-her mother had taken it rather as a disturbance than otherwise , to be visited , as [she]744-her mother reclined upon [her]744-her mother sofa ; [young people]1864-young people , [Louisa]92-louisa felt [herself]92-louisa all unfit for ; [Sissy]76-sissy [she]92-louisa had never softened to again , since the night when [the stroller ’s child]1865-the stroller ’s child had raised [her]1865-the stroller ’s child eyes to look at [[Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s intended wife]1866-mr. bounderby ’s intended wife . [She]92-louisa had no inducements to go back , and had rarely gone . Neither , as [she]92-louisa approached [[her]92-louisa old home]1858-her old home now , did any of the best influences of [old home]1868-old home descend upon [her]92-louisa . The dreams of childhood — its airy fables ; its graceful , beautiful , humane , impossible adornments of [the world beyond]1869-the world beyond : so good to be believed in once , so good to be remembered when outgrown , for then the least among [them]1870-them rises to the stature of a great Charity in the heart , suffering [little children]1871-little children to come into the midst of it , and to keep with [their]1871-little children pure hands a garden in the stony ways of [this world]3460-this world , wherein it were better for all [the children of [Adam]43-adam]1873-the children of adam that [they]1873-the children of adam should oftener sun [themselves]1873-the children of adam , simple and trustful , and not worldly - wise — what had [she]92-louisa to do with these ? Remembrances of how [she]92-louisa had journeyed to the little that [she]92-louisa knew , by the enchanted roads of what [she]92-louisa and millions of [innocent creatures]1874-innocent creatures had hoped and imagined ; of how , first coming upon Reason through the tender light of Fancy , [she]92-louisa had seen [it]1875-it [a beneficent god]1876-a beneficent god , deferring to gods as great as itself ; not a grim Idol , cruel and cold , with its victims bound hand to foot , and its big dumb shape set up with a sightless stare , never to be moved by anything but so many calculated tons of leverage — what had [she]92-louisa to do with these ? [Her]92-louisa remembrances of [home]2856-home and childhood were remembrances of the drying up of every spring and fountain in [her]92-louisa young heart as it gushed out . The golden waters were not there . They were flowing for the fertilization of [the land]3918-the land where grapes are gathered from thorns , and figs from thistles . [She]92-louisa went , with a heavy , hardened kind of sorrow upon [her]92-louisa , into [the house]2918-the house and into [[[her]92-louisa mother]744-her mother ’s room]1881-her mother ’s room . Since the time of [her]92-louisa leaving [home]2856-home , [Sissy]76-sissy had lived with [the rest of [the family]3509-the family]1883-the rest of the family on equal terms . [Sissy]76-sissy was at [[her]76-sissy mother]744-her mother ’s side ; and [Jane]100-jane , [[her]76-sissy sister]1886-her sister , now ten or twelve years old , was in [the room]2901-the room . There was great trouble before it could be made known to [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind that [[her]95-mrs. gradgrind eldest child]1888-her eldest child was [there]425-there . [She]95-mrs. gradgrind reclined , propped up , from mere habit , on a couch : as nearly in [her]95-mrs. gradgrind old usual attitude , as anything so helpless could be kept in . [She]95-mrs. gradgrind had positively refused to take to [[her]95-mrs. gradgrind bed]1890-her bed ; on the ground that if [she]95-mrs. gradgrind did , [she]95-mrs. gradgrind would never hear the last of it . [Her]95-mrs. gradgrind feeble voice sounded so far away in [her]95-mrs. gradgrind bundle of shawls , and the sound of another voice addressing [her]95-mrs. gradgrind seemed to take such a long time in getting down to [her]95-mrs. gradgrind ears , that [she]95-mrs. gradgrind might have been lying at the bottom of a well . [The poor lady]1891-the poor lady was nearer Truth than [she]95-mrs. gradgrind ever had been : which had much to do with it . On being told that [Mrs. Bounderby]155-mrs. bounderby was [there]425-there , [she]95-mrs. gradgrind replied , at cross - purposes , that [she]95-mrs. gradgrind had never called [him]1893-him by that name since [he]1893-him married [Louisa]92-louisa ; that pending [her]95-mrs. gradgrind choice of an objectionable name , [she]95-mrs. gradgrind had called [him]1893-him [J]200-j ; and that [she]95-mrs. gradgrind could not at present depart from that regulation , not being yet provided with a permanent substitute . [Louisa]92-louisa had sat by [her]95-mrs. gradgrind for some minutes , and had spoken to [her]95-mrs. gradgrind often , before [she]92-louisa arrived at a clear understanding who it was . [She]92-louisa then seemed to come to it all at once . ‘ Well , [[my]95-mrs. gradgrind dear]601-my dear , ’[95-mrs. gradgrind] said [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind , ‘ and [I]95-mrs. gradgrind hope [you]601-my dear are going on satisfactorily to [yourself]601-my dear . It was all [[your]601-my dear father]2783-your father ’s doing . [He]2783-your father set [his]2783-your father heart upon it . And [he]2783-your father ought to know . ’[95-mrs. gradgrind] ‘ [I]95-mrs. gradgrind want to hear of [you]601-my dear , [mother]3218-mother ; not of [myself]95-mrs. gradgrind . ’[95-mrs. gradgrind] ‘ [You]601-my dear want to hear of [me]95-mrs. gradgrind , [[my]95-mrs. gradgrind dear]601-my dear ? That ’s something new , [I]95-mrs. gradgrind am sure , when [anybody]2887-anybody wants to hear of [me]95-mrs. gradgrind . Not at all well , [Louisa]92-louisa . Very faint and giddy . ’[95-mrs. gradgrind] ‘ Are [you]92-louisa in pain , [dear mother]4391-dear mother ? ’[95-mrs. gradgrind] ‘ [I]95-mrs. gradgrind think there ’s a pain somewhere in [the room]2901-the room , ’[95-mrs. gradgrind] said [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind , ‘ but [I]95-mrs. gradgrind could n’t positively say that [I]95-mrs. gradgrind have got it . ’[95-mrs. gradgrind] After this strange speech , [she]95-mrs. gradgrind lay silent for some time . [Louisa]92-louisa , holding [her]92-louisa hand , could feel no pulse ; but kissing it , could see a slight thin thread of life in fluttering motion . ‘ [You]92-louisa very seldom see [[your]92-louisa sister]354-your sister , ’[95-mrs. gradgrind] said [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind . ‘ [She]354-your sister grows like [you]92-louisa . [I]92-louisa wish [you]92-louisa would look at [her]354-your sister . [Sissy]76-sissy , bring [her]354-your sister here . ’[92-louisa] [She]92-louisa was brought , and stood with [her]92-louisa hand in [[her]92-louisa sister]1886-her sister ’s . [Louisa]92-louisa had observed [her]92-louisa with [her]92-louisa arm round [Sissy]76-sissy ’s neck , and [she]92-louisa felt the difference of this approach . ‘ Do [you]92-louisa see the likeness , [Louisa]92-louisa ? ’[92-louisa] ‘ Yes , [mother]3218-mother . [I]95-mrs. gradgrind should think [her]354-your sister like [me]95-mrs. gradgrind . But — ’[95-mrs. gradgrind] ‘ Eh ! Yes , [I]95-mrs. gradgrind always say so , ’[95-mrs. gradgrind] [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind cried , with unexpected quickness . ‘ And that reminds [me]95-mrs. gradgrind . [I]95-mrs. gradgrind — [I]95-mrs. gradgrind want to speak to [you]92-louisa , [[my]95-mrs. gradgrind dear]601-my dear . [Sissy]76-sissy , [[my]95-mrs. gradgrind good girl]4396-my good girl , leave [us]4397-us alone a minute . ’[95-mrs. gradgrind] [Louisa]92-louisa had relinquished the hand : had thought that [[her]92-louisa sister]1886-her sister ’s was a better and brighter face than [hers]92-louisa had ever been : had seen in it , not without a rising feeling of resentment , even in [that place]1896-that place and at that time , something of the gentleness of the other face in [the room]2901-the room ; [the sweet face with the trusting eyes , made paler than watching and sympathy made it , by the rich dark hair]1898-the sweet face with the trusting eyes , made paler than watching and sympathy made it , by the rich dark hair . Left alone with [[her]92-louisa mother]744-her mother , [Louisa]92-louisa saw [her]1886-her sister lying with an awful lull upon [her]1886-her sister face , like one who was floating away upon some great water , all resistance over , content to be carried down [the stream]1900-the stream . [She]92-louisa put the shadow of a hand to [her]92-louisa lips again , and recalled [her]1886-her sister . ‘ [You]92-louisa were going to speak to [me]92-louisa , [mother]3218-mother . ’[92-louisa] ‘ Eh ? Yes , to be sure , [[my]92-louisa dear]601-my dear . [You]601-my dear know [[your]601-my dear father]2783-your father is almost always away now , and therefore [I]92-louisa must write to [him]2783-your father about it . ’[92-louisa] ‘ About what , [mother]3218-mother ? Do n’t be troubled . About what ? ’[92-louisa] ‘ [You]601-my dear must remember , [[my]92-louisa dear]601-my dear , that whenever [I]92-louisa have said anything , on any subject , [I]92-louisa have never heard the last of it : and consequently , that [I]92-louisa have long left off saying anything . ’[92-louisa] ‘ [I]92-louisa can hear [you]601-my dear , [mother]3218-mother . ’[92-louisa] But , it was only by dint of bending down to [her]1901-her ear , and at the same time attentively watching the lips as they moved , that [she]1901-her could link such faint and broken sounds into any chain of connexion . ‘ [You]601-my dear learnt a great deal , [Louisa]92-louisa , and so did [[your]601-my dear brother]3779-your brother . Ologies of all kinds from morning to night . If there is any Ology left , of any description , that has not been worn to rags in [this house]684-this house , all [I]1901-her can say is , [I]1901-her hope [I]1901-her shall never hear its name . ’[1901-her] ‘ [I]92-louisa can hear [you]601-my dear , [mother]3218-mother , when [you]601-my dear have strength to go on . ’[92-louisa] This , to keep [her]1901-her from floating away . ‘ But there is something — not an Ology at all — that [[your]601-my dear father]2783-your father has missed , or forgotten , [Louisa]92-louisa . [I]92-louisa do n’t know what it is . [I]92-louisa have often sat with [Sissy]76-sissy near [me]92-louisa , and thought about it . [I]92-louisa shall never get its name now . But [[your]601-my dear father]2783-your father may . It makes [me]92-louisa restless . [I]92-louisa want to write to [him]2783-your father , to find out for [God]147-god ’s sake , what it is . Give [me]92-louisa a pen , give [me]92-louisa a pen . ’[92-louisa] Even the power of restlessness was gone , except from the poor head , which could just turn from side to side . [She]1901-her fancied , however , that [her]1901-her request had been complied with , and that the pen [she]1901-her could not have held was in [her]1901-her hand . It matters little what figures of wonderful no - meaning [she]1901-her began to trace upon [her]1901-her wrappers . The hand soon stopped in the midst of [them]1902-them ; the light that had always been feeble and dim behind the weak transparency , went out ; and even [Mrs. Gradgrind]95-mrs. gradgrind , emerged from the shadow in which [man]2967-man walketh and disquieteth [himself]2967-man in vain , took upon [her]95-mrs. gradgrind the dread solemnity of [the sages and patriarchs]1904-the sages and patriarchs . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s nerves being slow to recover [their]1902-them tone , [the worthy woman]1905-the worthy woman made a stay of some weeks in duration at [[Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby ’s retreat]1827-mr. bounderby ’s retreat , where , notwithstanding [her]1901-her anchorite turn of mind based upon [her]1901-her becoming consciousness of [her]1901-her altered station , [she]1901-her resigned [herself]1901-her with noble fortitude to lodging , as one may say , in clover , and feeding on [the fat of [the land]3918-the land]1907-the fat of the land . During the whole term of this recess from the guardianship of [the Bank]3524-the bank , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit was a pattern of consistency ; continuing to take such pity on [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby to [his]93-mr. bounderby face , as is rarely taken on [man]2967-man , and to call [his]93-mr. bounderby portrait a Noodle to its face , with the greatest acrimony and contempt . [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , having got it into [his]93-mr. bounderby explosive composition that [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit was [a highly superior woman]1911-a highly superior woman to perceive that [he]93-mr. bounderby had that general cross upon [him]93-mr. bounderby in [his]93-mr. bounderby deserts ( for [he]93-mr. bounderby had not yet settled what it was ) , and further that [Louisa]92-louisa would have objected to [her]126-mrs. sparsit as [a frequent visitor]1912-a frequent visitor if it had comported with [his]93-mr. bounderby greatness that [she]126-mrs. sparsit should object to anything [he]93-mr. bounderby chose to do , resolved not to lose sight of [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit easily . So when [her]126-mrs. sparsit nerves were strung up to the pitch of again consuming sweetbreads in solitude , [he]93-mr. bounderby said to [her]126-mrs. sparsit at the dinner - table , on the day before [her]126-mrs. sparsit departure , ‘ [I]93-mr. bounderby tell [you]126-mrs. sparsit what , [ma’am]361-ma’am ; [you]126-mrs. sparsit shall come down here of a Saturday , while the fine weather lasts , and stay till Monday . ’[93-mr. bounderby] To which [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit returned , in effect , though not of the Mahomedan persuasion : ‘ To hear is to obey . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] Now , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit was not [a poetical woman]1913-a poetical woman ; but [she]126-mrs. sparsit took an idea in the nature of an allegorical fancy , into [her]126-mrs. sparsit head . Much watching of [Louisa]92-louisa , and much consequent observation of [her]92-louisa impenetrable demeanour , which keenly whetted and sharpened [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s edge , must have given [her]126-mrs. sparsit as it were a lift , in the way of inspiration . [She]126-mrs. sparsit erected in [her]126-mrs. sparsit mind a mighty Staircase , with a dark pit of shame and ruin at the bottom ; and down [those stairs]1914-those stairs , from day to day and hour to hour , [she]126-mrs. sparsit saw [Louisa]92-louisa coming . It became the business of [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s life , to look up at [her]126-mrs. sparsit staircase , and to watch [Louisa]92-louisa coming down . Sometimes slowly , sometimes quickly , sometimes several steps at one bout , sometimes stopping , never turning back . If [she]126-mrs. sparsit had once turned back , it might have been the death of [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit in spleen and grief . [She]126-mrs. sparsit had been descending steadily , to the day , and on the day , when [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby issued the weekly invitation recorded above . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit was in good spirits , and inclined to be conversational . ‘ And pray , [sir]2771-sir , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [she]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘ if [I]126-mrs. sparsit may venture to ask a question appertaining to any subject on which [you]2771-sir show reserve — which is indeed hardy in [me]126-mrs. sparsit , for [I]126-mrs. sparsit well know [you]2771-sir have a reason for everything [you]2771-sir do — have [you]2771-sir received intelligence respecting the robbery ? ’[126-mrs. sparsit] ‘ Why , [ma’am]361-ma’am , no ; not yet . Under the circumstances , [I]93-mr. bounderby did n’t expect it yet . [Rome]44-rome was n’t built in a day , [ma’am]361-ma’am . ’[93-mr. bounderby] ‘ Very true , [sir]2771-sir , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , shaking [her]126-mrs. sparsit head . ‘ Nor yet in a week , [ma’am]361-ma’am . ’[126-mrs. sparsit] ‘ No , indeed , [sir]2771-sir , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] returned [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , with a gentle melancholy upon [her]126-mrs. sparsit . ‘ In a similar manner , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’[93-mr. bounderby] said [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ‘ [I]93-mr. bounderby can wait , [you]361-ma’am know . If [Romulus]201-romulus and [Remus]202-remus could wait , [Josiah Bounderby]97-bounderby can wait . [They]4417-they were better off in [their]4417-they youth than [I]93-mr. bounderby was , however . [They]4417-they had a she - wolf for [a nurse]4418-a nurse ; [I]93-mr. bounderby had only a she - wolf for [a grandmother]4419-a grandmother . [She]126-mrs. sparsit did n’t give any milk , [ma’am]361-ma’am ; [she]126-mrs. sparsit gave bruises . [She]126-mrs. sparsit was a regular [Alderney]45-alderney at that . ’[93-mr. bounderby] ‘ Ah ! ’[126-mrs. sparsit] [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit sighed and shuddered . ‘ No , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’[97-bounderby] continued [Bounderby]97-bounderby , ‘ [I]97-bounderby have not heard anything more about it . It ’s in hand , though ; and [young Tom]71-tom , who rather sticks to business at present — something new for [him]71-tom ; [he]71-tom had n’t the schooling [I]97-bounderby had — is helping . [My]97-bounderby injunction is , Keep it quiet , and let it seem to blow over . Do what [you]361-ma’am like under the rose , but do n’t give a sign of what [you]361-ma’am ’re[97-bounderby] about ; or half a hundred of ’em will combine together and get [this fellow who has bolted , out of reach for good]4422-this fellow who has bolted , out of reach for good . Keep it quiet , and [the thieves]4423-the thieves will grow in confidence by little and little , and [we]4424-we shall have ’em[361-ma’am] . ’ ‘[361-ma’am] Very sagacious indeed , [sir]2771-sir , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit . ‘[2771-sir] Very interesting . [The old woman [you]2771-sir mentioned]1916-the old woman you mentioned , [sir]2771-sir — ’ ‘[1916-the old woman you mentioned] [The old woman [I]0-i mentioned]1918-the old woman i mentioned , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’ said [Bounderby]97-bounderby , cutting the matter short , as it was nothing to boast about , ‘[1918-the old woman i mentioned] is not laid hold of ; but , [she]1916-the old woman you mentioned may take [her]1916-the old woman you mentioned oath [she]1916-the old woman you mentioned will be , if that is any satisfaction to [her]1916-the old woman you mentioned villainous old mind . In the mean time , [ma’am]361-ma’am , [I]0-i am of opinion , if [you]361-ma’am ask [me]0-i [my]0-i opinion , that the less [she]1916-the old woman you mentioned is talked about , the better . ’ The same evening , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , in [her]126-mrs. sparsit chamber window , resting from [her]126-mrs. sparsit packing operations , looked towards [[her]126-mrs. sparsit great staircase]4425-her great staircase and saw [Louisa]92-louisa still descending . [She]126-mrs. sparsit sat by [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , in an alcove in [the garden]1728-the garden , talking very low ; [he]167-mr. harthouse stood leaning over [her]126-mrs. sparsit , as [they]4427-they whispered together , and [his]167-mr. harthouse face almost touched [her]126-mrs. sparsit hair . ‘[361-ma’am] If not quite ! ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , straining [her]126-mrs. sparsit hawk ’s eyes to the utmost . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit was too distant to hear a word of [their]4427-they discourse , or even to know that [they]4427-they were speaking softly , otherwise than from the expression of [their]4427-they figures ; but what [they]4427-they said was this : ‘[1921-you] [You]1921-you recollect [the man]516-the man , [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse ? ’ ‘[167-mr. harthouse] Oh , perfectly ! ’ ‘[516-the man] [His]516-the man face , and [his]516-the man manner , and what [he]516-the man said ? ’ ‘[516-the man] Perfectly . And [an infinitely dreary person]1923-an infinitely dreary person [he]516-the man appeared to [me]0-i to be . Lengthy and prosy in the extreme . It was knowing to hold forth , in the humble - virtue school of eloquence ; but , [I]0-i assure [you]1924-you [I]0-i thought at the time , “ [[My]0-i good fellow]888-my good fellow , [you]888-my good fellow are over - doing this ! ” ’ ‘[888-my good fellow] It has been very difficult to [me]0-i to think ill of [that man]523-that man . ’ ‘[92-louisa] [[My]0-i dear]601-my dear [Louisa]92-louisa — as [Tom]71-tom says . ’ Which [he]71-tom never did say . ‘[71-tom] [You]92-louisa know no good of [the fellow]1928-the fellow ? ’ ‘[92-louisa] No , certainly . ’ ‘[92-louisa] Nor of [any other such person]1929-any other such person ? ’ ‘[92-louisa] How can [I]0-i , ’ [she]92-louisa returned , with more of [her]92-louisa first manner on [her]92-louisa than [he]71-tom had lately seen , ‘[0-i] when [I]0-i know nothing of [them]1930-them , [men]545-men or [women]3196-women ? ’ ‘[0-i] [[My]0-i dear]601-my dear [Louisa]92-louisa , then consent to receive the submissive representation of [[your]92-louisa devoted friend]1934-your devoted friend , who knows something of several varieties of [his]1934-your devoted friend excellent fellow - creatures — for excellent [they]1935-they are , [I]0-i am quite ready to believe , in spite of such little foibles as always helping [themselves]1935-they to what [they]1935-they can get hold of . [This fellow]4310-this fellow talks . Well ; [every fellow]1937-every fellow talks . [He]4310-this fellow professes morality . Well ; all sorts of humbugs profess morality . From [the House of Commons]46-the house of commons to [the House of Correction]2845-the house of correction , there is a general profession of morality , except among [[our]1939-our people]3021-our people ; it really is that exception which makes [[our]1939-our people]3021-our people quite reviving . [You]92-louisa saw and heard the case . Here was [one of the fluffy classes pulled up extremely short by [[my]0-i esteemed friend]1943-my esteemed friend [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby — who , as [we]1939-our know , is not possessed of that delicacy which would soften so tight a hand]1942-one of the fluffy classes pulled up extremely short by my esteemed friend mr. bounderby — who , as we know , is not possessed of that delicacy which would soften so tight a hand . [The member of the fluffy classes]1944-the member of the fluffy classes was injured , exasperated , left [the house]2918-the house grumbling , met [somebody who proposed to [him]4310-this fellow to go in for some share in this Bank business]1946-somebody who proposed to him to go in for some share in this bank business , went in , put something in [his]4310-this fellow pocket which had nothing in it before , and relieved [his]4310-this fellow mind extremely . Really [he]4310-this fellow would have been [an uncommon]1947-an uncommon , instead of [a common , fellow]1948-a common , fellow , if [he]4310-this fellow had not availed [himself]4310-this fellow of such an opportunity . Or [he]4310-this fellow may have originated it altogether , if [he]4310-this fellow had the cleverness . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i almost feel as though it must be bad in [me]0-i , ’ returned [Louisa]92-louisa , after sitting thoughtful awhile , ‘[0-i] to be so ready to agree with [you]4310-this fellow , and to be so lightened in [my]0-i heart by what [you]4310-this fellow say . ’ ‘[0-i] [I]0-i only say what is reasonable ; nothing worse . [I]0-i have talked it over with [[my]0-i friend]508-my friend [Tom]71-tom more than once — of course [I]0-i remain on terms of perfect confidence with [Tom]71-tom — and [he]71-tom is quite of [my]0-i opinion , and [I]0-i am quite of [his]71-tom . Will [you]4310-this fellow walk ? ’ [They]4428-they strolled away , among [the lanes]4429-the lanes beginning to be indistinct in the twilight — [she]92-louisa leaning on [his]4310-this fellow arm — and [she]92-louisa little thought how [she]92-louisa was going down , down , down , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s staircase . Night and day , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit kept it standing . When [Louisa]92-louisa had arrived at the bottom and disappeared in [the gulf]4430-the gulf , it might fall in upon [her]92-louisa if it would ; but , until then , there it was to be , [a Building]4431-a building , before [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s eyes . And there [Louisa]92-louisa always was , upon [it]4431-a building . And always gliding down , down , down ! [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit saw [James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse come and go ; [she]126-mrs. sparsit heard of [him]167-mr. harthouse here and there ; [she]126-mrs. sparsit saw the changes of the face [he]167-mr. harthouse had studied ; [she]126-mrs. sparsit , too , remarked to a nicety how and when it clouded , how and when it cleared ; [she]126-mrs. sparsit kept [her]126-mrs. sparsit black eyes wide open , with no touch of pity , with no touch of compunction , all absorbed in interest . In the interest of seeing [her]126-mrs. sparsit , ever drawing , with no hand to stay [her]126-mrs. sparsit , nearer and nearer to [the bottom of [this new Giant ’s Staircase]4433-this new giant ’s staircase]4432-the bottom of this new giant ’s staircase . With all [her]126-mrs. sparsit deference for [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby as contradistinguished from [his]93-mr. bounderby portrait , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit had not the smallest intention of interrupting the descent . Eager to see it accomplished , and yet patient , [she]126-mrs. sparsit waited for the last fall , as for the ripeness and fulness of the harvest of [her]126-mrs. sparsit hopes . Hushed in expectancy , [she]126-mrs. sparsit kept [her]126-mrs. sparsit wary gaze upon the stairs ; and seldom so much as darkly shook [her]126-mrs. sparsit right mitten ( with [her]126-mrs. sparsit fist in it ) , at the figure coming down . [The figure]3351-the figure descended [the great stairs]4435-the great stairs , steadily , steadily ; always verging , like a weight in deep water , to [the black gulf at the bottom]4436-the black gulf at the bottom . [Mr. Gradgrind]71-tom , apprised of [[his]71-tom wife]3471-his wife ’s decease , made an expedition from [London]8-london , and buried [her]3471-his wife in a business - like manner . [He]71-tom then returned with promptitude to [the national cinder - heap]4438-the national cinder - heap , and resumed [his]71-tom sifting for the odds and ends [he]71-tom wanted , and [his]71-tom throwing of the dust about into the eyes of [other people who wanted other odds and ends]4439-other people who wanted other odds and ends — in fact resumed [his]71-tom parliamentary duties . In the meantime , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit kept unwinking watch and ward . Separated from [her]126-mrs. sparsit staircase , all the week , by the length of [iron road]4440-iron road dividing [Coketown]4-coketown from [the country house]4441-the country house , [she]126-mrs. sparsit yet maintained [her]126-mrs. sparsit cat - like observation of [Louisa]92-louisa , through [[her]92-louisa husband]2903-her husband , through [[her]92-louisa brother]2932-her brother , through [James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , through the outsides of letters and packets , through everything animate and inanimate that at any time went near the stairs . ‘[1950-you] [Your]1950-you foot on the last step , [[my]0-i lady]3656-my lady , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , apostrophizing [the descending figure]4444-the descending figure , with the aid of [her]126-mrs. sparsit threatening mitten , ‘[1950-you] and all [your]1950-you art shall never blind [me]0-i . ’ Art or nature though , the original stock of [Louisa]92-louisa ’s character or the graft of circumstances upon it , — [her]92-louisa curious reserve did baffle , while it stimulated , one as sagacious as [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit . There were times when [Mr. James Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse was not sure of [her]126-mrs. sparsit . There were times when [he]167-mr. harthouse could not read the face [he]167-mr. harthouse had studied so long ; and when [this lonely girl]4445-this lonely girl was a greater mystery to [him]167-mr. harthouse , than [any woman of [the world]301-the world with a ring of satellites to help [her]4445-this lonely girl]4446-any woman of the world with a ring of satellites to help her . So the time went on ; until it happened that [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby was called away from [home]2856-home by business which required [his]93-mr. bounderby presence elsewhere , for three or four days . It was on a Friday that [he]93-mr. bounderby intimated this to [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit at [the Bank]3524-the bank , adding : ‘[1950-you] But [you]1950-you ’ll go down to - morrow , [ma’am]361-ma’am , all the same . [You]1950-you ’ll go down just as if [I]0-i was [there]425-there . It will make no difference to [you]1950-you . ’ ‘[361-ma’am] Pray , [sir]2771-sir , ’ returned [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , reproachfully , ‘[0-i] let [me]0-i beg [you]2771-sir not to say that . [Your]2771-sir absence will make a vast difference to [me]0-i , [sir]2771-sir , as [I]0-i think [you]2771-sir very well know . ’ ‘[0-i] Well , [ma’am]361-ma’am , then [you]361-ma’am must get on in [my]0-i absence as well as [you]361-ma’am can , ’ said [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , not displeased . ‘[93-mr. bounderby] [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , ’ retorted [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘[93-mr. bounderby] [your]2771-sir will is to [me]0-i a law , [sir]2771-sir ; otherwise , it might be [my]0-i inclination to dispute [your]2771-sir kind commands , not feeling sure that it will be quite so agreeable to [Miss Gradgrind]132-miss gradgrind to receive [me]0-i , as it ever is to [your]2771-sir own munificent hospitality . But [you]2771-sir shall say no more , [sir]2771-sir . [I]0-i will go , upon [your]2771-sir invitation . ’ ‘[0-i] Why , when [I]0-i invite [you]361-ma’am to [[my]0-i house]695-my house , [ma’am]361-ma’am , ’ said [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , opening [his]93-mr. bounderby eyes , ‘[0-i] [I]0-i should hope [you]361-ma’am want no other invitation . ’ ‘[0-i] No , indeed , [sir]2771-sir , ’ returned [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘[2771-sir] [I]0-i should hope not . Say no more , [sir]2771-sir . [I]0-i would , [sir]2771-sir , [I]0-i could see [you]2771-sir gay again . ’ ‘[2771-sir] What do [you]361-ma’am mean , [ma’am]361-ma’am ? ’ blustered [Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby . ‘[2771-sir] [Sir]2771-sir , ’ rejoined [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘[2771-sir] there was wo nt to be an elasticity in [you]2771-sir which [I]0-i sadly miss . Be buoyant , [sir]2771-sir ! ’ [Mr. Bounderby]93-mr. bounderby , under the influence of this difficult adjuration , backed up by [her]126-mrs. sparsit compassionate eye , could only scratch [his]93-mr. bounderby head in a feeble and ridiculous manner , and afterwards assert [himself]93-mr. bounderby at a distance , by being heard to bully [the small fry of business]4450-the small fry of business all the morning . ‘[77-bitzer] [Bitzer]77-bitzer , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit that afternoon , when [[her]126-mrs. sparsit patron]597-her patron was gone on [his]597-her patron journey , and [the Bank]3524-the bank was closing , ‘[77-bitzer] present [my]0-i compliments to [young Mr. Thomas]71-tom , and ask [him]71-tom if [he]71-tom would step up and partake of a lamb chop and walnut ketchup , with a glass of India ale ? ’ [Young Mr. Thomas]71-tom being usually ready for anything in that way , returned a gracious answer , and followed on [its]4453-its heels . ‘[71-tom] [Mr. Thomas]71-tom , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘[71-tom] these plain viands being on table , [I]0-i thought [you]71-tom might be tempted . ’ ‘[0-i] Thank’ee , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ’ said [the whelp]1387-the whelp . And gloomily fell to . ‘[126-mrs. sparsit] How is [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse , [Mr. Tom]71-tom ? ’ asked [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit . ‘[71-tom] Oh , [he]167-mr. harthouse ’s all right , ’ said [Tom]71-tom . ‘[71-tom] Where may [he]167-mr. harthouse be at present ? ’ [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit asked in a light conversational manner , after mentally devoting the whelp to [the Furies]203-the furies for being so uncommunicative . ‘[167-mr. harthouse] [He]167-mr. harthouse is shooting in [Yorkshire]47-yorkshire , ’ said [Tom]71-tom . ‘[167-mr. harthouse] Sent Loo a basket half as big as [a church]1967-a church , yesterday . ’ ‘[1968-the kind of gentleman] [The kind of gentleman]1968-the kind of gentleman , now , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , sweetly , ‘[1968-the kind of gentleman] whom one might wager to be a good shot ! ’ ‘[204-crack] [Crack]204-crack , ’ said [Tom]71-tom . [He]167-mr. harthouse had long been [a down - looking young fellow]4455-a down - looking young fellow , but this characteristic had so increased of late , that [he]167-mr. harthouse never raised [his]167-mr. harthouse eyes to any face for three seconds together . [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit consequently had ample means of watching [his]167-mr. harthouse looks , if [she]126-mrs. sparsit were so inclined . ‘[204-crack] [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse is a great favourite of mine , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘[167-mr. harthouse] as indeed [he]167-mr. harthouse is of [most people]1969-most people . May [we]1970-we expect to see [him]167-mr. harthouse again shortly , [Mr. Tom]71-tom ? ’ ‘[71-tom] Why , [I]0-i expect to see [him]167-mr. harthouse to - morrow , ’ returned [the whelp]1387-the whelp . ‘[0-i] Good news ! ’ cried [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , blandly . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i have got an appointment with [him]167-mr. harthouse to meet [him]167-mr. harthouse in the evening at [the station here]1971-the station here , ’ said [Tom]71-tom , ‘[0-i] and [I]0-i am going to dine with [him]167-mr. harthouse afterwards , [I]0-i believe . [He]167-mr. harthouse is not coming down to [the country house]4441-the country house for a week or so , being due somewhere else . At least , [he]167-mr. harthouse says so ; but [I]0-i should n’t wonder if [he]167-mr. harthouse was to stop here over Sunday , and stray that way . ’ ‘[167-mr. harthouse] Which reminds [me]0-i ! ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit . ‘[167-mr. harthouse] Would [you]71-tom remember a message to [[your]71-tom sister]354-your sister , [Mr. Tom]71-tom , if [I]0-i was to charge [you]71-tom with one ? ’ ‘[0-i] Well ? [I]0-i ’ll try , ’ returned [the reluctant whelp]4457-the reluctant whelp , ‘[0-i] if it is n’t a long un . ’ ‘[0-i] It is merely [my]0-i respectful compliments , ’ said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , ‘[0-i] and [I]0-i fear [I]0-i may not trouble [her]354-your sister with [my]0-i society this week ; being still a little nervous , and better perhaps by [my]0-i poor self . ’ ‘[101-loo] Oh ! If that ’s all , ’ observed [Tom]71-tom , ‘[101-loo] it would n’t much matter , even if [I]0-i was to forget it , for [Loo]101-loo ’s not likely to think of [you]71-tom unless [she]101-loo sees [you]71-tom . ’ Having paid for [his]71-tom entertainment with this agreeable compliment , [he]71-tom relapsed into a hangdog silence until there was no more [India]26-india ale left , when [he]71-tom said , ‘[101-loo] Well , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , [I]0-i must be off ! ’ and went off . Next day , Saturday , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit sat at [her]126-mrs. sparsit window all day long looking at [the customers]4458-the customers coming in and out , watching [the postmen]4459-the postmen , keeping an eye on the general traffic of [the street]461-the street , revolving many things in [her]126-mrs. sparsit mind , but , above all , keeping [her]126-mrs. sparsit attention on [her]126-mrs. sparsit staircase . The evening come , [she]126-mrs. sparsit put on [her]126-mrs. sparsit bonnet and shawl , and went quietly out : having [her]126-mrs. sparsit reasons for hovering in a furtive way about [the station by which [a passenger]4462-a passenger would arrive from [Yorkshire]47-yorkshire]4461-the station by which a passenger would arrive from yorkshire , and for preferring to peep into [it]1974-it round pillars and corners , and out of [ladies]667-ladies ’[126-mrs. sparsit] waiting - room windows , to appearing in [its]1974-it precincts openly . [Tom]71-tom was in attendance , and loitered about until [the expected train]1975-the expected train came in . It brought no [Mr. Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse . [Tom]71-tom waited until [the crowd]1976-the crowd had dispersed , and the bustle was over ; and then referred to a posted list of [trains]1977-trains , and took counsel with [porters]1855-porters . That done , [he]71-tom strolled away idly , stopping in [the street]461-the street and looking up [it]461-the street and down it , and lifting [his]71-tom hat off and putting it on again , and yawning and stretching [himself]71-tom , and exhibiting all the symptoms of mortal weariness to be expected in one who had still to wait until [the next train]1980-the next train should come in , an hour and forty minutes hence . ‘ This is a device to keep [him]71-tom out of the way , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] said [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit , starting from the dull office window whence [she]126-mrs. sparsit had watched [him]71-tom last . ‘ [Harthouse]167-mr. harthouse is with [[his]71-tom sister]716-his sister now ! ’[126-mrs. sparsit] It was the conception of an inspired moment , and [she]126-mrs. sparsit shot off with [her]126-mrs. sparsit utmost swiftness to work it out . [[The station]3414-the station for [the country house]4441-the country house]1982-the station for the country house was at [the opposite end of [the town]2838-the town]1984-the opposite end of the town , the time was short , [the road]2846-the road not easy ; but [she]126-mrs. sparsit was so quick in pouncing on [a disengaged coach]1987-a disengaged coach , so quick in darting out of [it]1987-a disengaged coach , producing [her]126-mrs. sparsit money , seizing [her]126-mrs. sparsit ticket , and diving into [the train]1988-the train , that [she]126-mrs. sparsit was borne along the arches spanning the land of coal - pits past and present , as if [she]126-mrs. sparsit had been caught up in a cloud and whirled away . All the journey , immovable in the air though never left behind ; plain to the dark eyes of [her]126-mrs. sparsit mind , as the electric wires which ruled a colossal strip of music - paper out of the evening sky , were plain to the dark eyes of [her]126-mrs. sparsit body ; [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit saw [her]126-mrs. sparsit staircase , with the figure coming down . Very near the bottom now . Upon the brink of [the abyss]1989-the abyss . An overcast September evening , just at nightfall , saw beneath its drooping eyelids [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit glide out of [[her]126-mrs. sparsit carriage]1990-her carriage , pass down the wooden steps of [the little station]1991-the little station into [a stony road]1992-a stony road , cross [it]1992-a stony road into [a green lane]1993-a green lane , and become hidden in a summer - growth of leaves and branches . One or two late birds sleepily chirping in [their]1994-their nests , and a bat heavily crossing and recrossing [her]126-mrs. sparsit , and the reek of [her]126-mrs. sparsit own tread in the thick dust that felt like velvet , were all [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit heard or saw until [she]126-mrs. sparsit very softly closed a gate . [She]126-mrs. sparsit went up to [the house]2918-the house , keeping within the shrubbery , and went round [it]2918-the house , peeping between the leaves at the lower windows . [Most of them]1996-most of them were open , as they usually were in such warm weather , but there were no lights yet , and all was silent . [She]126-mrs. sparsit tried [the garden]1728-the garden with no better effect . [She]126-mrs. sparsit thought of the wood , and stole towards [it]2918-the house , heedless of long grass and briers : of worms , snails , and slugs , and all the creeping things that be . With [her]126-mrs. sparsit dark eyes and [her]126-mrs. sparsit hook nose warily in advance of [her]126-mrs. sparsit , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit softly crushed [her]126-mrs. sparsit way through the thick undergrowth , so intent upon [her]126-mrs. sparsit object that [she]126-mrs. sparsit probably would have done no less , if the wood had been a wood of adders . Hark ! The smaller birds might have tumbled out of [their]1994-their nests , fascinated by the glittering of [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ’s eyes in the gloom , as [she]126-mrs. sparsit stopped and listened . Low voices close at hand . [His]1998-he voice and [hers]126-mrs. sparsit . The appointment was a device to keep [the brother]4155-the brother away ! There [they]2000-them were yonder , by the felled tree . Bending low among the dewy grass , [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit advanced closer to [them]2000-them . [She]126-mrs. sparsit drew [herself]126-mrs. sparsit up , and stood behind a tree , like [Robinson Crusoe]206-robinson crusoe in [his]206-robinson crusoe ambuscade against [the savages]2001-the savages ; so near to [them]2000-them that at a spring , and that [no great one]2002-no great one , [she]126-mrs. sparsit could have touched [them]2000-them both . [He]1998-he was there secretly , and had not shown [himself]1998-he at [the house]2918-the house . [He]1998-he had come on horseback , and must have passed through [the neighbouring fields]2004-the neighbouring fields ; for [his]1998-he horse was tied to the meadow side of the fence , within a few paces . ‘ [[My]1998-he dearest love]4465-my dearest love , ’[1998-he] said [he]1998-he , ‘ what could [I]1998-he do ? Knowing [you]4465-my dearest love were alone , was it possible that [I]1998-he could stay away ? ’[1998-he] ‘ [You]4465-my dearest love may hang [your]4465-my dearest love head , to make [yourself]4465-my dearest love the more attractive ; [I]126-mrs. sparsit do n’t know what [they]4466-they see in [you]4465-my dearest love when [you]4465-my dearest love hold it up , ’[126-mrs. sparsit] thought [Mrs. Sparsit]126-mrs. sparsit ; ‘ but [you]4465-my dearest love little think , [[my]126-mrs. sparsit dearest love]4465-my dearest love , whose eyes are on [you]4465-my dearest love ! ’[126-mrs. sparsit] That [she]126-mrs. sparsit hung [her]126-mrs. sparsit head , was certain . [She]126-mrs. sparsit urged [him]1998-he to go away , [she]126-mrs. sparsit commanded [him]1998-he to go away ; but [she]126-mrs. sparsit neither turned [her]126-mrs. sparsit face to [him]1998-he , nor raised it . Yet it was remarkable that [she]126-mrs. sparsit sat as still as ever [the amiable woman in [ambuscade]48-ambuscade]2005-the amiable woman in ambuscade had seen [her]126-mrs. sparsit sit , at any period in [her]126-mrs. sparsit life .
